text: One of my best friends friend took me to Mission Cliffs for my first time rock wall climbing experience. I had such a fun time and will be looking forward to going there again! My friend and I went to Mission Cliffs around 1:30pm on a Saturday afternoon. Rock climbing has become pretty trendy in the past few years, so it was no surprise to me that Mission Cliffs was super busy. Even though it was busy, we had no problem finding the space to climb the proper grade for me. I've never been to an indoor rock climbing gym to begin with, so I was super impressed by the overall facility as I had no expectations. Since Mission Cliffs spanned a whole block, essentially one whole side of the gym was the rock wall. The rock wall had areas either just for top rope climbing or lead climbing as well as areas that allowed for both. There was also a designated bouldering section at one end of the gym. I loved the small lounge area that you climb up to, where you could get a bird's eye view of the place. What I liked about Mission Cliffs was that it was a one stop shop for all around fitness. The main attraction there was, of course, the rock climbing, but Mission Cliffs has a section for weight training, a cycling room, a yoga studio, and several treadmills and cardio machines around the facility. Lastly, the check-in process was easy, and customer service was excellent. Everyone working the reception area greeted us, and Jordan, who sized my shoes and provided my harness, was the nicest guy ever.

Discrimination at Mission Cliffs. This morning I was made to feel like a criminal when I went to check out Mission Cliffs Gym for my office. This morning I was told I couldn't take my purse with me. Is that because I will be stealing gym equipment? The front desk clerk for the 2nd time said he couldn't show me around the gym. I was there a few weeks ago in business attire. This morning I came from my own gym in my gym clothes heading to work a block away where I manage a start-up. Last time, maybe it was too busy at 5:15p but this morning I thought I would have a better chance to view the space before I make the decision to pay for a gym for our employees. I am just baffled at the bullshit with some of these boutique businesses in the bay. Am I too black, are they just rude & don't five a fuck or am I too fat to come and work out? Jeeezzz! Ill take our business elsewhere. I never see any other black people here anyway. Maybe that's the sign I should have been looking for in the first place.

I love this gym BUT it's overcrowded & it hasn't grown in the ways that matter most in order to compensate for the crowding. Pro: free access to other touchstone gyms. Con: nothing near my house/the west side of San Francisco (I live in haight-Ashbury & it's a stretch to get myself to this part of the mission). What is needed/would make it more worth it: a more efficient layout utilizing the cubic ft of space in this large facility for a larger weight area, more accessible/less crowded bouldering area, & better space to hangout & not feel as if we're crawling on top of one another. Seems like there's a ton of space for relatively few folks who lead climb. Can we use some of the space near there for the checkin stand, & build out the weight lifting area? Please! And we need cleaner, larger saunas. I don't think those have improved since the gym was expanded.Honestly, I went to Brooklyn boulders in Somerville, MA (near Cambridge/Boston) & loved the atmosphere so much that it got me addicted to the scene. Do what they're doing and you'll have a gym I'd never feel pressure to leave!

After nearly two solid years with Berkeley Ironworks and what started out as a promising transition to Mission Cliffs when I moved to SF, I've finally decided to end my Touchtone membership for good. Ironworks was the gym we all needed but didn't deserve. MC - I've given you seven months but you've let me down with your overcrowded yoga classes, stinky bathrooms and lackluster routes and now I must bid you adieu. Let's hope PG delivers.
Convenient location in the mission compared to PG. Routes are set pretty frequently with interesting problems and it's not too crowded as long as you lead.

For my Birthday I requested to do Rock Climbing. Mission Cliffs is located in a local warehouse in the Mission. Upon entering tons of kids laughing, adults with serious faces, and majority of the patrons having fun. Positive atmosphere, great learning environment, and awesome instructors. Checking in without a hassle and signing waivers electronically. Our instructor (which I forgot her name) was the best!! We learned all about safety, tie a rope, and the necessities of our gear.After 45mins of Instructions, we were on our own. I give major props who come in and seize the day rope climbing. I have to admit a bit nervous due to the high walls and looking down. But in all we had the best time!Thank you again Mission Cliffs!

I am docking a score because Jody has moved on and her replacement for Tue/Thurs is Laura. While Laura is nice, she is disorganized, forgetful, and a novice instructor. I would really love to have some more variety for the highly coveted Tue/Thur spot and for management to acknowledge that a lot of their patrons were dedicated to coming to MC because of the quality of instruction from Jody. Please find a better replacement!

Came here for my first time and overall I'd say it was alright. I was used to going to Planet Granite in Sunnyvale but this location is now near my new place so I wanted to give it a try. Not the best customer service. Decent rental shoes - they didn't stink. And personally think it's a small facility. I also didn't like the layout of the rocks. It was also pretty packed. But on the flip side there were some awesome folks that were bouldering. It's always nice to make new friends doing something you love.

Mission cliffs is in a very convenient location, close to my home and work. The routes are all set really nicely which is a big plus. However, very consistently, every time I go to mission cliffs, the staff who work there are not very friendly and a little unpleasant to interact with. I really make the effort to interact as little as possible with them. I plan to keep going because the location is convenient and the routes are very nice. I just don't really enjoy the staff on hand. Otherwise it's a good gym.

I'm not a member of Touchstone, though I do have a punchcard. Since I don't live in the area, it's always a treat to stop by Mission Cliffs for a climbing session when I'm in SF. Their routes tend to be greasy (do they ever wash the holds!?), but I like the fact that they have a large proportion of climbs that are leadable versus PG. Their remodel hugely increased the roped climbing area, and I especially love the Lead Only overhung Walltopia section where they get creative with the harder climbs. The locker room and bathroom facilities are a bit on the cramped side, but they have soap, shampoo, and towels, so no complaints!

Signed up for a beginner's class which comes with shoes/harness and learned so much. Great for first timers who want to learn how to climb safely and correctly. The staff and facilities are so nice and I would highly recommend. It fills up fast on the weekends though so start your day early if you want to have your pick of walls.

I've joined Mission Cliff last year to climb and attend yoga classes. It is everything you need from a gym: conveniently located, with spacious top roping areas, reasonably priced, positive atmosphere. I am saddened to give a poor review, but the young yoga instructor who teaches most of the morning classes on weekdays, Laura, is unfortunately the absolute worst instructor I've came across in 14 years of yoga practice. Beside being extremely patronizing, talking trash about other instructors, constantly bragging about how good she is, and inviting students to attend classes she teaches in other studios, her routines are absolute nonsense: she constantly skips poses on one side and confuses left and right, her poses sometimes escalates into advanced sequences without a proper warmup inviting injuries to happen, she does not give any time to fix form, doesn't seem to care about alignment or corrections, and instead of adapting to the pace of the class, she simply keeps barreling (and talking non stop) through her very confused sequences. I like all the other instructors and wish I could give Mission Cliff a 5 stars, but I really need to to be able to practice yoga in the morning without injuries or having to listen at the instructor's complains.

This is a really spacious rock climbing gym located in the Mission.This review is specifically for the bouldering area. It's a bit smaller than other bouldering gyms but gets the job done at least. The employees here are nice and the patrons are patient to wait their turn.I wish the shoe area where you stow your belongings was a little more organized and the bouldering area a little bigger. It can get messy when people don't have an orderly place for stowage.

I used to come here often before the remodel but now it's great and amazing. However some of the staff could be a little more friendly. It seems like the thing to do for all the touchstone establishments is to hire nonhelpful bitchy millennials. Keep in mind bitchy millennials, our day passes, rental fees and memberships help pay for your paychecks.

I was looking for a rock climbing gym and in SF there are only 2 to choose from. When checking out mission cliffs, there were probably 30 bikes outside (not a good sign). It was jam packed at 5pm. There were a decent amount of top roping areas, but most were taken. They also have bouldering walls, but not as many as planet granite. Overall a decent gym but it is right in the middle of the mission.

Everything you need for a gym, but the interpersonal experience with staff is unpleasant, and I feel like the place would really benefit from nicer workers. I've been to Mission Cliffs for two summers now, but this time, signing up for the membership again, the two staff members who helped me were 1) unwilling to help cancel a transaction once I saw that there was a summer deal, after I had paid for the regular membership 2) genuinely unhappy when I asked if I could pay for both my friend and I's membership on my card. He looked me straight in the eye with the expression you'd give your mother who won't let you go out at night, "You should have told me that earlier." Really hard to let this one pass. The other guy, I asked, "Is it really hard to do that?" (that as in change my charge) Him without looking me in the eye: "Yeah, we would have to cancel the whole transaction and everything... -continues to do something else-" Didn't know that what I was paying for was not up to me. Really unhappy with the service here, but I'll be back for the weights, bouldering when it's not too crowded, sauna, showers, and towel service.

Weird experience I've been rock climbing with my two toddlers in mission bayI decided to try this one closer to home They asked me about age of my kids and I said 1.5 and 3. I inquired and they said they have appropriate stuffAfter I paid $47, they asked me to take a training.  I had my kids wait with nanny while I undergo training.  They finally said after 15 mins that I wasn't ready.  I wish they asked me if I had prior experience with Belay.  If they expected an expert climber to lift up his 1.5 year old in the air...They said kids can play without going too high.  There was nothing even possible for them to climb.  I would pay money to see a 1.5 year old climbing these.  The answer is that they are not equipped for kids that young.Result;  I wasted an hour, frustrated my kids and paid $47.  We ended up again at the other place and proof point they had wonderful timeRECOMMENDATION:  set expectations before you take people money. And your place is for advanced climbers not little kids

While I cannot comment on "routes" of the climbing and what-not as I am complete novice and am going to take roping classes--being a very, very OUT trans-woman, I can comment on this gym being a safe & legitimate spot for genderqueer and nonbinary individuals to do their fitness thing without feeling judged or uncomfortable. Yes, the hardbodies that meander this popular gym can be intimidating and even overwhelming, but for the most part those chiseled abs and sculpted biceps are attached to educated & open-minded people that are more focused on their routine than who is sharing the space in their locker-room.I especially like the professionalism and patience of the staff.  They work extremely well with scared newbies like me and heck--you really can't beat the monthly price.  For such a great rate you can really monopolize a full-body workout while taking advantage of classes offered by highly trained teachers in climbing, yoga, cycling and so much more. I am very, very into it.. :)

I'm so grateful this gym is close to me! I usually top rope and this place has enough variation to keep me interested. They change the routes every few weeks so you don't get bored for too long. The bouldering area, weight room and yoga classes are pretty limited though. For those other perks, I definitely prefer Planet Granite in the Presidio.. I was a member there for years until the drive across town made me switch to MC.

Here's to all the renovations.I used to come here years ago and switched to Planet Granite. Now I'll never go back to PG.The new walls are expansive, well lit, and challenging. The work out area is surprisingly good. And all the cardio machines scattered about are a great add. Love the yoga room and the spin as well, but I really go for the climbing.Only go in the AM (6:30) because you don't have to wait for routes, so I can't speak to crowds at other times.PS: Love the names they use and the themes (GOP candidates, GNR and Ac/DC tracks, etc)If I had one complaint, it would to put in some super technical routes with some stemming in the three or four places you can actually put them. It's nice to break up routes with a stem to stretch out and give you arms and legs a break.

I had a great experience rock climbing and boldering here with my co-workers! I took the belay class with 4 of my other co-workers and the instructor was really kind, informative, and easy to understand. I forgot his name but he was buff and cute LOL kudos to you sir! He helped to teach us how to tie knots and securely help each other climb the walls. I felt confident in my belaying abilities after taking the class and was able to assist people as they climbed! This gym is really nice and has a bunch of different walls for people of all levels. There's also a boldering pit in the back that was clean, challenging, and fun. I think my group got a day pass which was $25 but I'm not sure how much the rest of the course was. I looked up the prices today and saw that membership is around $100 dollars a month. Would do it if I become a more active climber. Overall a fun and challenging experience at a very nice and clean area!

Found my new gym!  This place is great with a combo of (mostly) climbing, basic gym equipment, weights, yoga classes, and cardio classes.  For $77/mth, it's a steal!  Especially compared to places like Equinox, which while it has amaaazing facilities, charges a monthly fee that could feed a small village ($200+ per month)....but no hate, haha.What really sold me was the incredibly helpful and cool staff who helped me navigate my first experience bouldering, as well as the members who were nice enough to help me through my first climbs.  There is definitely a congenial culture here...it's not just a place to get your sweat on :)Caveats....classes are not as frequent as a gym's schedule...maybe 4-6 classes daily.  Mostly yoga and not as many cardio classes.  Works for me but consider this depending on your workout style.  I would say this place is for the person who who likes a combo of outdoorsy type of activity mixed with a little bit of gym.

I don't understand how this gym is rated so highly compared to the other gyms I've been to here in the Bay and elsewhere. Comparing Mission Cliffs to others there isn't much they offer in terms of climbing/bouldering. First, the belay testing. It didn't seem as if there were any standards they followed. A woman before me was tested by one of the staff members and the woman being tested seemed a bit iffy on a few minor things and she seemed to pass fine due to her experience and technique. My husband and I, on the other hand, had a different staff member test us and while our belay technique, tying in, and safety checks were all fine - save for maybe forgetting the 6" or less rule of slack, when I hardly had any slack (honestly who remembers that exact number?) -  we only received temporary cards. When questioning this member what exactly we missed they could not give us a straight answer. Just give me a solid answer rather than bumming around the issue -- "Uhhh well we test differently than PG..." Ok I guess? Did it look like I was putting someone in danger? Was my belay method off? So I know for next time when I come in again. I would've been less irked if they told me what exactly went wrong. On top of this both members who were testing did not even ask us or others what the safety commands were when tied in or belaying.I understand not giving a permanent belay card to someone who clearly does not know what they're doing for safety reasons but as someone who has been climbing for 4 years indoors and outdoors and felt that my checks and technique were competent enough (and received praising responses from said member who tested us) I seriously couldn't understand why. Routes: it seems like MC has very soft/inflated ratings. I understand routes are at the discretion of the setters but climbing a 5.9 to warm up felt like a 5.6/5.7 with no variation (climbing up a ladder as another user pointed out). Climbing at Planet Granite (all three in SF, Sunnyvale, and Belmont), Dog Patch Boulders, and others outside of SF they felt consistent except for here. On top of the routes they hardly have anything less than 5.10a. Every single wall in MC is rated 5.10a or higher; at least this was on the day I went in, I don't know how it is when they switch up the routes. I counted maybe only 5 or so routes rated lower ranging 5.6-5.9. Where are people supposed to warm up? Stand in line on those so few routes and wait? What about people who are not yet ready to go to higher ratings? The soft ratings could also be in part of this, so while you feel like you're climbing 5.10a and above you're actually climbing 5.8 or so....In addition to that there were routes where it felt like people would be climbing/descending on top of each other. And there were tons of people standing around getting in the way of climbers. I hardly saw any staff members walk the floor to check on people and their technique/safety. This is pretty standard at any gym I've climbed at. I wanted to point this out because I saw a few people being sloppy. There were two people who were on a route and the person climbing the route had his phone out face timing someone! This dude straight up had his phone out and low and behold, he slipped (from halfway up the route) and ended up swinging hard/whipping and getting himself and his belay partner tied up with the people next to him. Grossly incompetent and someone could've been hurt had he swung into someone. I seriously wanted to go up to these guys and tell them how stupid they were being by doing that.Overall I don't know if I'll be back. We were really looking forward to finally coming here because my husband and I live close and it's more convenient than going all the way to PG. Who knows what will happen and the "luck" we will receive when taking our belay test again; if we ever return. Waste of $50.

Honestly I love climbing so anywhere I can climb is already a winner in my book. MC has a nicer facility than Dogpatch. The locker rooms are larger, theres fitness classes, bouldering, rope climbing, and tons of workout equipment. What more do you need?! I will say that there aren't as many community events (if any?? Not sure, haven't heard of any other than classes or competitions but I've just switched to touchstone a few months ago) as Planet Granite, my favorite gym of all time (PG had weekly events, bouldering leagues, etc). The staff here isn't as friendly as at PG and for some reason they keep giving me temporary belay cards...even though I've been climbing indoors & out for 2+ years. Not sure if it's cuz I learned how to climb somewhere else or what cuz I definitely haven't gotten the figure 8 knot wrong or forgotten any safety checks either...they don't tell me why they won't give me a normal belay card, I've asked lol. Maybe because I don't climb there regularly (I'm more of a boulderer)? Idk. The belay test takes like 5-10 minutes so it's not a huge hassle to take it before climbing. It does get pretty darn crowded in the rope area though. But good range of climbs and there are a lot of interesting problems. Not a big fan of the bouldering area though. It's small and cramped. I'd just go to dogpatch if I really wanted to boulder.  Monthly membership does get you into all the touchstone gyms though which is pretty sweet! ALSO it's cheaper than PG now. And you get fitness classes, yoga, AND CLIMBING. What a deal! It's really close to a bunch of bars and restaurants which is nice is ya wanna hang after climbing. Southern Pacific is literally around the corner. Sightglass & Atlas Cafe are super close too. Also plenty of bike parking outside. Overall pretty nice gym, despite the crowds.

Came here for the first time with my sister and my younger cousin. We came here on a Wednesday afternoon and there was no crowd at all. We got lucky with street parking with a short walk to the entrance. We paid $20 each (including $5 for rental). First impression was this place is definitely smaller than Planet Granite in the Marina. They have a wall worth of climbing routes mostly consisting of 5.10a and higher routes. I felt like they had more routes for professionals, which makes sense, but if you are coming here as a beginner/intermediate there are limited routes. I also felt like some of their rankings were a little off - I climbed a 5.9 that seemed more like a 5.7 or 5.8. I personally enjoyed their bouldering section more. The routes varied a lot and were really fun to climb. The only complaint I have is that it can get a little crowded and stuffy since it's on the second floor and with the curves of the wall - it leaves little room for multiple people to climb at once.  Other amenities in their facility includes:- cycling room- free weights, machines, squat racks and benching - very clean bathroom with lockers and showers Overall, I see myself coming here maybe once or two more time to try the routes I didn't climb the first time.
I'm here so much this is practically my second home. Now if only they would adopt the 24 hr fitness schedule, then I can finally stop paying the exorbitant amount for SF rent.

This is a really cool place to go with a group of friends, your ride or die partner, or just going there by yourself. Not only is it a cool place to go workout and have fun but it is located in the Mission, so you can probably grab some delicious food right after which makes it feel like a hidden gem. I was also able to rekindle my fire for climbing after so many years of no action. So, if anything I must thank this place and it's amazing facility for helping me. I would say that the price was 'good' considering that I only go for the early bird special because those are the times that I am free and want a good deal. Overall, I really like this place a lot just because I know I can get a good deal if I do the early bird special. But I am not a professional rock climber so I can't say "This is the best place to go to!" because I don't quite have the criteria but nonetheless check this place out!

Our team from the office took the afternoon off to go rock climbing here. Most of us had little to no experience, so we went to the belay class offered at 2:30. Henry did a great job teaching us everything we needed to know and was very thorough.The walls were massive, well designed and fun routes for all different skill levels. Very impressive.Also note, this place has no auto belays (that means you need a climbing partner.)Once 5:30 rolled around the place became very busy, so be prepared for that if you go immediately after work.

This is my happy place and light years better than a "regular gym." I love that I can cross train with cardio machines, weights, climb, yoga classes, and the icing on the cake is the relaxing sauna in the locker rooms. Thanks Mission Cliffs for creating a great place for climbing and community.

I'm so happy that I was introduce to rock climbing! This rock climbing/gym is huge! They offer variety of classes and intro to climbing.  I never attended an intro class and I really should and learn proper ways and techniques of rock climbing. The staff are very friendly and helpful.  When I first came here I had to do a belay test in order to climb and belay.  My fiancé's  cousin showed me the proper way to belaying and climbing.  When I tested and forgot a few things, the staff were very helpful and knowledgeable.  They made sure you know all your safety checks before giving you a belay card. There's a small area with basic gym equipment and can get your workout done.  They also have a cycle room and a yoga room.The climbing route are changed frequently so there's always something new to climb.  The bouldering area renovated and up.  It gets pretty crowded after work hours but if you come on weekends or early during week days you pretty much have the entire climbing gym to your self.  The bathrooms are renovated and pretty clean.  They have lockers for day use.  Just bring your own lock.  We pay $140/month as family.  We can bring in a guest (1 each) for free any time of them to and free guess on the last Friday of each month, so I think we get our money's worth.  I'm leaving mission cliff though to try another climbing gym, but I will always come back if I don't like my new gym (Planet Granite) I highly recommend this place to anybody!!

It is rare that I write a review, however, my experiences (plural) at Mission Cliffs have been some of the worst customer service experiences I've ever had. The staff has been rude, belittling, and extremely inattentive. My first gripe is with the complete lack of organization or consistency around belay testing. I climb frequently at a variety of gyms wherever my travels take me. Belay tests are expected and I've never had an issue at any other gym where I've taken the test. I went to Mission Cliffs several times and was never asked to take a belay test. One day my girlfriend was in town and joined me. Even though it was her first time at the gym, they still didn't mention any safety requirements or a belay test. We started climbing, and about 30 minutes in a staff member approached us with a very aggressive tone about our lack of "belay certified" tags. His tone was so aggressive and off-putting that we decided to stop climbing altogether to stymie our interaction with him.Our next visit, he was the person who checked us in and upon recognizing us stated he remembered our interaction and comp'd us our rental shoes and harness. The rental harness clip configuration was different than the one I own, so before the belay test started, I asked my examiner how to close the clip (make a "c" instead of an "o"). At the end of the test she said I "did extremely well" and asked where I typically climb - then proceeded to give me a partial pass because the clip wasn't closed before my inquisition. Ridiculous. I wasn't planning to climb before asking about the configuration of the rental harness. During the next visit's belay test I was asked how many pairs of 2's to check for. Having never been asked this before, I began to count aloud. After getting to three I started to count in my head and before I finished counting my examiner interjected the appropriate number and stated I was wrong that it was not in fact three. Then she asked if I was tied in to the wrong side of the rope, which I was not, but she led me to believe I was. At this point we decided to end our visit and don't expect to return unless an earthquake moves their facility to be the only cliff of refuge outside my apartment building during the apocalypse.There appears to be no protocol for the belay test or when/if it should even be performed at Mission Cliffs. A huge miss for a test that is supposed to improve safety.The rest of my gripes are about general rudeness and inattentiveness of the staff. Every time I need help with something (e.g. getting a different sized pair of shoes or asking a question about the harness configuration) they take an extremely long time to respond even though they aren't attending to other customers. I'll finish off by saying that I just raised an investment round and i found my experience at Mission Cliffs more demoralizing than getting rejected by VC's.

I have been here twice as a beginner with some time in between visits (enough to forget), so I took the beginner class both times. It is offered a few times a day but check the website and reserve a spot online as it can get filled. It's usually no more than 5-8 people and currently costs $35 if you are not a member (1-day pass is $25 for non-member) and includes shoes and harness. The class is a solid 45 min-1 hour, and a thorough demo of safety and how to put on your equipment. You end with a climb up the little training wall. The space is pretty large but I also have not been to any other climbing gym so I have no point of comparison. It's crowded but the easier climbs have not been super crowded on our visits. There's also plenty of things to see and people to watch so you can spend several hours here. The facility is decently clean. If I lived closer, I might consider a membership. Street parking nearby but the area is getting more crowded as housing and commercial development increases in the area.

This Touchstone gym is by far my favorite of the Touchstone Family.  We've been to Berkeley, Sacramento and Concord (our home gym), and Mission Cliffs offers a good variety of climbs (top rope and lead climb) as well as a good bouldering area.  The gym area is nice and spacious, and offers a good variety of different machines.  The popularity of this gym was evident by how busy this place was, although despite that, it was quite easy to jump in and get on the walls.  The tall routes provide a challenge, no matter how experienced you are, and make it quite fun (although a little intimidating on your first run).The only negative to this gym is the lack of parking, but you might get lucky (like we did) and find some a couple blocks away!

Oh how long it's been since I last climbed. 3 years. So happy to return!!I had ankle issues which resulted in surgery. And I really didn't want to undo that costly procedure. But my sister asked and she needed a new hobby. Updated everything. This place was renovated and I'm pretty ecstatic about the better use of space. New entrance and they moved the counter with much better use of merchandise area.  Exit is next to the entrance but not one and the same. Climbing walls and bouldering area, so much more of both since I was last here. Can't wait to work my way up to the tougher ones. Fitness and yoga classes available, and cardio and weightlifting areas, too.  Prices = moderate. Check out their site for pricing on day pass and membership levels. (If you do a membership, you will have access to the other Touchstone gyms.)  Currently, the 10-punch pass is $180 ($18/session), and it expires within one year from date of purchase.  Since it'd been a while, I joined my sister in the belay class, because it's always good to have a refresher. Only another living person's life is all. Henry was a good instructor and glad we took the class! Safety first, fun right after. $30/pp for one hour belay class, day pass use and equipment rental. Service = friendly staff. Restrooms = clean. Yes, shares the space with lockers and showers.I dig the new water fountains with filtered water bottle filling feature, and full sinks right outside the restrooms. Very helpful. They still have the cubes for storage but I love the shelving unit for water bottles. Clever use of space.Parking = street, and mostly without time limit. And, there's plenty of bicycle parking out front. (Beats the old system of having it inside by the old entrance.) It's a trek from public transit stops but feasible if you're not carrying multiple heavy items.

I have been going to this gym for a year. It's a very nice facility for rock climbers, they change their routes to keep you entertained. Stuff is always helpful and polite. They also have  dry sauna in the changing area which is very popular and plenty of towels for use. Besides that there are really plenty of yoga classes each day. Even some type of acro yoga which was fun too.

I've been to the Concord, Berkeley, and Sacramento Touchstone gyms, but this one is my favorite.  Despite being extremely busy on a weekday night, I still found a few routes to climb.  Things are a little tight, but since the routes are so long, doing a few is still a really good workout.  Didn't check out the bouldering area, maybe next time.  If I'm ever in the area again, I'll def. have to stop by.  It was also nice that there are a few food options within walking distance.  Tartine if you get out early enough.

It was my first time here with my friends. One of my friend was training me but when i went to check it before doing rock climbing but seems stuff disappointed about it and gave me not a good service. Just noticed that they need me to buy a class from them. However everything was ok and fun with my friends. Happy that i done with rock climbing again. Ill come back again soon.

First time for me in here. Service was not that good but I still had fun with rock climbing with my friends. Clean and neat. After done rock climbing I also do workout. Cool place to hang out and work out in the same time.

Rock climbing is an excellent combination of strength and cardio training. If you don't like lifting weights or running, I definitely recommend rock climbing. I like this place because there are many different walls to climb and the paths get changed frequently so there's always a new one to attempt. The paths are also very clear, with colored grips and colored tape specifically dedicated to individual paths. However, the difficulty levels tend to be inconsistent, and definitely over-inflated when compared to other rock climbing places. For example, I struggle climbing a 5.9 difficulty wall elsewhere, but have no problem climbing a 5.10c difficulty here. There are also a variety of bouldering options available, ranging from V0 difficulty to V11 difficulty. Generally, a V0 difficulty would be the equivalent of a 5.10a climbing difficulty. There's also some free weights, weight machines, and cardio equipment available for those people who choose not to climb. But I'd rather stick mostly to climbing if I were you. It's more fun!

On belay, y'all! I've been a guest at Mission Cliffs since I was a young lass. My old church's youth group used to head there every couple of months on Sunday afternoons and I always remember it being a grand old time. Now, in my attempts to stay active, I like to pop in with friends and make a day of it. I hadn't been in since they renovated and expanded, but his past Sunday my crew went in and all got certified to belay and to climb, your pal Crys bringing up the rear. I don't know what happened to my mind, but it was like all sense became nonsense, and I couldn't tie a climbing knot to save my life. The guy who tests people out was so effing gracious, I wish I got his name. He encouraged me, showed me the ropes (literally), and when he saw I was getting anxious, he would tap my hand and say "hey, why are you sad? You're guna get this!". Not my finest moment, but I finally pulled through and got to head up the walls.Everyone had a great time. The walls vary in difficulty and skill, the facilities are clean and spacious. I want to get a membership but sh*t is so pricey! I think it would be worth it now to get a membership though, because initiation is free January '15 and they have a lot of gym equipment so you don't really need a gym membership elsewhere. Plus rock climbing is super cool and exhilarating and you don't feel like you're even working out, you're just climbing around having all of the funs.

This is a very good home base for climbing and has been my regular gym for the past two years. The roped area is very large and varied, lots of different routes from very easy to spectacularly hard. The setters change routes frequently so you won't run out of new challenges even if you climb frequently. Some parts of the gym are reserved for lead climbing (rather than top roping) and those tend to be the harder and more overhung sections, so as you progress in your climbing they can provide some extra challenge for you.The bouldering area is relatively small, which is fine by me as I don't really enjoy that, but if bouldering is your main deal you will be much happier as Dogpatch Boulders (same family, membership in one gym gets you access to all of them!).Two small issues:- the staff takes a little while to warm up to. As a regular I've gotten to know most of them and they are friendly climbers who sometimes mistake taking their job and safety seriously with being hard asses with new climbers. If you keep a humble attitude and don't let your ego get you sore because you didn't pass a certain test when you thought you should, you'll have a better time.- Showers have been recently renovated and look really nice and have plenty of stalls, but sometimes the water is lukewarm at best... not ideal when all you're craving is a nice hot shower after a hard workout!

Mission Cliffs is pretty centrally located -- you can get there easily by bus, BART, bicycle, on foot and by motorcycle.  If you have a car and you're visiting the Mission - really, you should know better (we'll cut you some slack if this is your first few months in the Bay Area).  Parking is challenging but that's not the fault of Mission Cliffs, so deal with it like everyone else does and move on.Mission Cliffs was the first indoor climbing gym I ever visited -- and I am very happy with all the improvements over the past year or so.  The new walls are fantastic, and the route setters do a good job of rotating around the Touchstone gyms and changing routes pretty regularly.The advantage of joining Touchstone, IMO, is that there are several gyms relatively close together, so if you get bored with routes at one gym -- go to another. I regularly go to MC, GWPC & BIW, with a few visits to Diablo around the holidays (because they have the best holiday hours).MC renovations are still in progress -- and if you dislike crowds, I recommend you avoid visiting here in the "after work" hours -- it gets pretty packed.Music-wise, they have a better pulse on the Pandora station than other gyms, and even play their own play lists.  As with other Touchstone gyms -- things are a bit grungy and dirty all around:  holds are usually dirty, walls are usually dirty, bathrooms and inside lockers are usually not so great (on par with the other gyms; though Diablo seems to have the CLEANEST bathroom/locker room of all I have visited).Customer service is hit or miss -- there's an ethic to hospitality & customer service that is sorely lacking in the Bay Area.  It's beyond the response of "no problem" or "it's alright" to a "thank you" (seriously - why not say "you are welcome" or "my pleasure", folks?).  People really do pick and choose what parts of customer service they think are important and ignore the rest -- the customer is not always right here, and the folks who work in service roles prefer to think of themselves as "equals" to their customers from whom they are taking money (and giving what - exactly - in return?).    Of course all INDIVIDUALS are equals -- but when you voluntarily take a job (getting paid) to provide service to people -- it seems you would not be indifferent, snarky, sarcastic or apathetic about it.  When you are in an transactive relationship - there is no equality to the role.My point is - any complaints of customer service issues should be taken up at the gym, very close to the time of the incident and with specific details about what was inappropriate or offensive -- that's really the only way to change the culture of poor customer service.  It's not specific to Mission Cliffs (as many folks might claim in their Yelp reviews) -- but to individuals and their training or aptitude for *serving* others.

This is likely a great place to climb. Not that I would know. Here's why.Years ago, I had moved to San Francisco and would get tacos across the street at the El Tonayense truck.  Mission Cliffs always intrigued me so I decided to check it out and inquire about a starter program.  As soon as I walked in carrying a plastic bag of to go tacos from across the street, the gentleman at the counter said firmly and dismissively, 'WE DIDN'T ORDER ANYTHING' should the fact that I am non-white matter at all?  I understand one person does not represent an entire company, but unfortunately that's what happens sometimes when that person is the one that greets you at the door.  I'd encourage anyone to take a trip to Japan and experience what customer service means to them.

Recently got a Touchstone membership and am a big fan.Pros:*First and foremost, people here are actually really nice. You'll have the occasional douche here and there, but I'm serious. People are ridiculously nice. And it's awesome.*Convenient  - bike parking galore, car parking is doable, and it's close to the 16th street BART station*HUGE remodeled top-rope area*Saunas and pretty clean locker rooms*Yoga classes, lots of cardio equipment*That guava-butter lotion, ahhhhhNow the cons... The bouldering area is small and as of today still under a lot of construction. The gym also closes pretty early on the weekends too (around 7pm). So crowded with a sea of flesh that I thought I entered Dante's Inferno.  An ocean of people who talked loudly ad nauseum about boring topics like shuttle rides and commuting.The routes seemed ok, if they were not crawling with people stacked on people like that zombie hill from World War Z.

Although Dogpatch Boulders will always be my first gym love, lately I've been coming to Mission Cliffs a lot.Things MC has that DB doesn't:1) free wi-fi - you can sit upstairs on the top floor and get shit done 2) sauna!  i don't know what it does but it feels good.  you can turn on the light and read in there3) yoga! - sam, maria and jordan are all goodWays in which DB is superior to MC:1) DB has better music.  i don't know what pandora station they're using at DB ("chillwave?  chilled electro sounds?") but it's often a cool contemplative vibe.  nice change from the typical boom boom boom.  at MC I tend to not notice the music at best, and at worst it's some irritating classic rawk mix2) DB has a couch... Special thanks goes to the owner who private messaged me regarding my review and setting up new a session with a different instructor.The instructor was very informative and explained every step in detail to make sure we were being safe and most importantly had fun.I will definitely come back again
My husband and I went to this place for the first time and took a class for beginners. It was so much fun-! We will definitely come back to do more climbing-!

Released the cracken here who are my kids. Let's um kids scale cliff and I have a drink down below while thinking any stains on kids clothes. Gettin da exercise on and yoga for pretzel poses. Need to get out more, skin looks too whitey mighty.

I came in as a guest today. Was considering buying a membership, but was deterred by the complete lack of customer service. Was planning to sweat profusely into a towel during sauna use before taking a shower and drying off with one, and couldn't understand why I would have to use the SAME towel for both. I asked (shouldn't have asked) if they could please make an exception this once on their "one towel" rule since I was new and had forgotten to bring one.
