Great climbing gym! Lots of top roping/lead climbing. A decent bouldering section upstairs. Most every weight/machine you'd need too. At busier hours (after 5:30) it gets kind of crowded for sure - especially the weight section (only 2.5 squat racks and 1 bench press). I'm new to climbing so it's fine for me but some complain about route ratings. The only complaint I have is that the routes are seemingly inconsistently rated for easier climbs (V0-V3 has a lot of overlap) Day pass is 20 bucks + (5-7$ for shoes/harness) but with the membership you get in free to all the classes so if you live around and can afford it I recommend shelling out the $75 per month. It pays for itself in no time. Plus you get access to all other touchstone gyms like dogpatch bouldering.

I'm so grateful that my friend introduced me to climbing. I hadn't been top roping for at least 10 years, and this was the perfect place to get back into it. They have daily Intro to Climbing Classes with excellent and friendly instructors. That alone made me super excited to climb again! The bouldering area is fairly limited but still enough to get your fix. I would mostly come here for top roping.Their shop section is fun, because they have a wide variety of harnesses, chalk bags, and other climbing gear. As far as other amenities, their selection of gym equipment is plentiful. It can get pretty crowded, but everyone who comes here is super friendly. Great vibe. Wide variety of routes and difficulties that change every so often. Grab a friend and make a routine out of coming here to challenge yourself!

A friend really wanted to go rock climbing so I planned a little get together for us to take lessons here. I've only been rock climbing twice at Planet Granite. The only downside to Planet Granite is that it's really far. Mission Cliffs is much more easily accessible although they close an hour earlier than Planet Granite does.The price for belay lessons was $30. It was stated on the website that it was recommended to call in to reserve spots if a party of four or more wanted to take the lesson so I called in but they told me to just walk in and it was first come first serve. I think if we had one more person in the group it would have been different. It was stated that it would take about an hour but it lasted for an hour and a half. I think it's because our group was kind of big (four including myself plus two other people) and the instructor probably wanted to make sure we really knew what we were doing.The belay lessons here were more detailed and the instructor we had took the time to test us individually several times which is something I appreciate although I did get antsy really fast. She was very helpful though.By the time we were allowed to climb on our own, we got tired out kind of fast. Rock climbing takes a lot of forearm strength. I didn't expect it as much in the roped rock climbing because I"ve never felt that much strain on my forearms from belaying at Planet Granite...but I did work forreal. I can't even imagine bouldering!Anyway, Mission Cliffs is really fun. I appreciate that it's more easily accessible and that there are tons of places to eat around the area. Service is great too.

Mission Cliffs has some fun routes but I have to say there are better indoor rock climbing gyms overall (having hit quite a few in New York, Georgia, Texas and of course California). As for needing an indoor rock climbing gym in SF then it's my #2 of 2.Why I'm clipping in +'s:+ Friendly staff at check-in. The welcome mat means something to me.+ Great routes for those who climb 5.10++ Membership allows you to access other locations around the Bay Area.+ Inventive route names which makes me smile.+ Bike racks abound are a key alternative because street parking is a b-tch.+ Afterwards it's great to grab food or beer and a decent location.Why I'm not clipping in -'s:- Bouldering area is upstairs and limited. You will need to go to Dogpatch Boulders for some serious bouldering.- Place is popular and crowded on weekday evenings and weekends. Expect to wait for a route or get on something just because it's open.- Parking is insane!- Bring your own belay device.- Weight room is teeny. Tiny. Itsy. Bitty.

Mission Cliffs got me started on climbing, so I don't have many bad things to say about this place. I only climbed here for 8 months in 2011, but since then, a lot has changed (including where the entrance is, as well as the size of the gym, which has definitely gotten bigger). I do have to mention though, that the courses are rated pretty easily (although the rocks are pretty slippery, so maybe that compensates for it?). There is easily a 4-5 point differential between what my projects were in Queens, and what I climbed here with some difficulty. The people here are still really nice, and I passed my belay test with flying colors (even though I was trying to remember how to let my climber down using an ATC, since grigris are all the rage back in NYC). It was nice to go back to my roots, and see how far I've come :)
This gym has a lot of ropes but a nice sized bouldering area.  It's spread out so seems spacious, even in a busy day.

Great rock gym. You SFers have it really good up there.Mission Cliffs is well ventilated. Lots and lots of top rope, with long and high routes. No autobelay, so make friends! The bouldering section is somewhat wanting, felt a little cramped with a lot of overhung problems.If I lived in the area, I'd be a member. There's also plenty of new looking well-maintained gym equipment, fresh towels to use, and even a sauna! Lucky lucky SFers...

Of the 3 city climbing gym's mission cliffs is the most crowded.  It also has the worst parking (for cars, all 3 have sufficient bike parking).The bouldering area is small, crowded, and usually pretty musty, but it looks like they're expanding, so maybe that will help things.I still like this place a lot however, and the additions are/will be pretty nice.

I just recently got into rock climbing and decided to start a membership here. $75 a month is probably the most I've spent on any gym but luckily my company expenses a portion of it or else I'm not certain if I would have considered it.Intro to Climbing (belaying to be specific) classes are free for members which I highly recommend for anyone starting. I just took mine today and it was very helpful! Belaying involves 2 people for those who don't know what that is. One person climbing and the other being the "belayer" who feeds the rope to the climber. It's intimidating at first but so much fun when you start retaining everything! I actually made a friend in intro class who I will start belaying with which is pretty cool!Besides the option to belay, you can boulder (free climbing without a rope), take yoga classes, and there is even a small area for lifting weights. It's good to know I don't have to miss squat days anymore with this gym so close to my apartment.Though I do have to admit this space isn't that big and can get overly crowded during peak times. Or else I would have given this a sold 5 star.

Having been to a number of different gyms in the Bay Area as well as on the east coast, this gym is flat out the worst, in multiple aspects. A couple of things that are not meeting expectation:1. The route setting here is mediocre. There are interesting routes here too but lots of the 5.10 something are not really well thought of. Among all the gyms I've been to, the overall quality of this gyms' routes is the worst. 2. The 5.10s (and below) here are very very soft. I guess it's a "feel good" gym for beginner climbers. There are some interesting routes around 5.11 and 5.12, but the rating between different routes are very very inconsistent. I know ratings are subjective and it can't always be accurate, but some of the ratings here are so off. 3. There isn't a good climbing training area. This gym is so spacious yet they don't have a nice training area for finger boards and rungs, they have a huge yoga room and lots of treadmills, but c'mon, as a climbing gym it really should have a very nice area for climbing specific trainings. 4. They are very short staffed. They don't have staff member to give lead belay tests during weekday nights.5. They don't have the compensating weight for lead climbers, which makes it not safe for some climbers. All the other gyms I've been to either have the compensating weight, or have something for the belayer to tie into at the bottom of each lead route. As a very light weight climber, I always belay someone much heavier than me, and very often need the compensating weight. But once I was lead climbing in this gym, I was about to belay someone over 40 lbs heavier than me, I asked if they have the weight they just told me they don't and told me "you're fine"...it really irresponsible. I know perfectly how to catch a heavier climber, but the weight difference just means that they'll fall longer and there's nothing I can do. Stop giving excuses for not having enough safety equipments!6. Some of the staffs here are very rude. They are not just "not friendly", they are rude. They don't respect the members here, I don't want to talk about specific examples... In all the other gyms I've been to, the staffs were nice and helpful, they really help to build a great climbing community around their gyms. But that's not the case here, here it feels like the staffs are working against the members. To them this is purely a job, which is understandable but not good. 7. I've been climbing for a couple of years in multiple gyms, never had a hold fell off from the wall before. Yet it happened in this gym and I've only been there less than 10 times. Time to wear a helmet indoors..I got a membership before knowing all these nuances, now I'm very disappointed at this gym. It's just sad that they are in such a great location yet they are so bad.PS. I emailed the gym about one incident when a staff member was very rude to me, and did not get a response from the gym. That just tell me that they don't respect their customers, they stand behind the bad behavior of their employees. That being said, I didn't take it personal, cuz I think that staff member is just rude to people in general.I wish one day I can leave a review saying "they have the best routes I've tried in any gym, they have the best climbing training area and their staffs go out of their ways to help the climbers in the gym". With the current status, I don't see that happening anytime soon if at all, they just don't care enough.

This is my first ever yelp review and sadly it's negative. I came here today with my brother and sister for climbing and it was such a bad experience. It was my second time here and my sibling's first time. The customer service sucks here. We were on our own for one hour trying to figure out how to tie knots and how to wear the harness. We asked for help but they would answer with one word answers and will not repeat and just leave. Especially the female worker with short hair and blonde highlights. She was extremely rude! Left us tied up for more then 30 mins and rudely took are stuff back. I actually like climbing and the routes they had seemed interesting but was not able to enjoy them. Definitely will not be coming back here just because of the customer service !

Great facilities. Uneven and frequently poor staff.I've been climbing indoors and out for around 15 years. I've been at a lot of gyms in that time. MC definitely has a great set of facilities, and is vastly improved in this area from the previous setup of a few years ago.I choose not to climb at MC, however, because the staff is frequently rude and arrogant. The "Mission" part of Mission Cliffs is indeed present and accounted for, in the sense of dismissive and blasé service. There are a few gems, including the current cleaning staff (!), but it's far better to spend your time at Dogpatch Boulders - also part of Touchstone Climbing - if that's your thing, or Planet Granite for a more traditional climbing environment: chill people, friendly crowd, helpful staff.I got into climbing for the atmosphere and challenge, not the scene, and unfortunately there's always been a bit too much of the latter at MC for my taste.

Well, this is my gym so I obviously think it's amazing. While it's definitely smaller than the planet Granite Sunnyvale but it's quite rad! It has recently expanded its facility with a larger top rope section and is currently under renovation. They have a great cardio and weightlifting area  & locker rooms with showers & a sauna!The bouldering area is a little smaller than this boulder would love but adequate & they change the routes @ satisfactory intervals. A membership here gets you a membership at  several other guns including Dogpatch boulders!!!Conversely, there are many good restaurants in the close surround area & a regular food truck. You can have good food & then go burn off your calories or vise versa :)

I have been an on- and off- member of Mission Cliffs for the last few years; I moved away to Denver and Portland, before eventually returning to San Francisco. Mission Cliffs, compared to gyms in other cities, or hell, even within the city, is a joke. Here's why:- Routes are highly inflated by a grade or two, maybe even three; you'll be in for a shock if you do any outdoor climbing, or even visit another gym. Nearby Planet Granite is closer to grading elsewhere, and even PG is a little overrated. - Routes graded 5.10D and above are inconsistent and unpredictable. Their setters are all over the place. A 5.10d will be as hard as a 5.11c; a 5.11a will be incredibly easy one week, impossible the next, and so on. It's hard to track your progress with such variability. - Routes are set densely and incredibly close to each other, leading to a lot of congestion. In some cases, this congestion is dangerous -- in the rooms where there are overhangs with steep leanbacks, I've seen climbers fall back and literally smash into each other in the air. - The weight room portion of the gym is poorly laid out and incredibly crowded, almost to the point of being unsafe. For example: although there are a ton of pull-up bars in the area, they are often always on top of weight racks. A person can't do pull-ups if there's somebody there lifting weights -- and believe me, there's always somebody there lifting weights. The equipment is terrible; weights are rusted, metal. Good luck if you're trying to do anything other than a bicep curl -- there's no space for real weightlifting moves like deadlifts and cleans.- The "new" part of the gym, despite being new, is a hot mess. The carpet wasn't bolted down properly and bunches up all over the place, causing lots of people to trip. Although construction was only finished a few years ago, it was so poorly done that you can't actually tell that it's newer than the rest of the gym. It's already dirty as sin.- Everything is filthy. This is legitimately a breeding ground for MRSA.- People here are INCREDIBLY rude, staff and patrons alike. Because it's always insanely crowded, everybody just fends for themselves. The more advanced people will cut you in line for routes, or in some cases, even snake your route by tying on to the rope next door and climbing the route your rope is meant for. Tech noobs and amateurs will crowd around easy routes, spending 15-20 minutes tied in but NOT climbing, instead looking up and "analyzing" the climb, leading to even more congestion and crowding.So why do I still go? Unfortunately, I've been climbing for years now and this is the closest gym to me. Do I like it? No. Do I feel safe? No, not really.Hm. Maybe time to suck it up and just ride out to Planet Granite.

Came here for the first time this past weekend (after having climbed for many months at PG in both SF and Sunnyvale). It might be the marina in me, but I wasn't super impressed. The gym definitely has a mission feel... a bit on the dirty side, old ropes and no modern conveniences such as gri gris. Bring your own ATC or you won't be climbing. Also be prepared to spend 10 minutes waiting for and then filling out a digital waiver on outdated computer systems which slow the whole process.I was also surprised by how uptight the clientele seemed to be. Everyone was SUPER sensitive about even the slightest route overlap, even if the climber on the wall was already pretty far up the route. A bit hyper I think... we can all get along and share, especially in a small gym.That brings me to the size. I have to caveat this by saying they are under construction to double the size which should be great. But right now the climbing area if pretty small (though are are a good amount of ropes, just too many people who are too sensitive about overlap to be much good). The gym area is also pretty tiny. Planet Granite SF is only a bit better in this regard, but the Sunnyvale PG blows them both out of the water - a ton of climbing and gym space.The one highlight here was that the staff was very friendly and happy to help when I asked to take a belay test (another qualm... PG and Mission Cliffs should have some sort of reciprocal agreement - I'm lead qualified at PG and yet still had to take a test just to get top rope certified at MC). All in all, I'm glad I checked out MC and had a chance to climb something different and in a new setting... but I'll probably be sticking with PG for the most part.

My first time rock climbing and it was such an experience!! I came here to celebrate my cousin's birthday. What better way to celebrate than belay and climb!??!!?Most of us were first timers and I really believe that we got an awesome instructor!! (I forgot his name! Eeks!) He really knew how to interact with the group, make things fun and most importantly, he knew how to teach. Key points:When you walk in, you can kinda smell the "funk", but once you start, the smell kinda goes away. Nice and clean women's locker room. Each of the walls are marked, so you'll know the difficulty level. Going with a big group, especially those you trust made my first experience wonderful. More so, having my hubby as my belayer.

One downside is I parked my car along the street and in the building next door, there was a couple having really, really loud sex. It sounded like they were reciting lines from shakespeare as they were climaxing. The windows were wide open, so their intent on being heard was very clear. It only lasted a few minutes though.The bouldering here is pretty good. There is a good variety of routes and the crowd it attracts is very helpful and friendly.

Climbing/Space - the holds (slowly being replaced) are slimy and smoothed off.  The routes are set on the easy side and often involve more muscle than technique.  The old floor covering  (slowly being replaced) can engulf you.  The gym could be sterilized a bit more.Prices - January is free initiation fee month (same for PG), or buy a 10-pack and get a free init once the pack is used up.  The monthly and daily fees are still cheaper than Planet Granite, and Touchstone has more chains.  Food - When MC has celebrations, they have the best free hipster gym food ever.  Pulled pork sandwiches, baked beans, etc.  PG offers free food more often though, like free bbqs every summer.  MC sometimes gives away free samples of granola bars and bags of granola.  Crowd - MC is definitely crowded in the evenings, which can be a con for waiting but a pro for people watching.  Dog Patch has the true assortment of characters.Given the choice, I would choose PG gyms due to the nuances of the climbs, the cleanliness, and the spaciousness.  However, MC is still a fun place to climb, with an assortment of post-climbing hangouts nearby.

Mission Cliffs is awesome, and Dogpatch is even better. But the initiation fee is prohibitively expensive. If you live in San Francisco permanently and only climb, then you are set. Otherwise it costs $100 to start and $150 if you are a couple. Since I pursue several sports and can't afford to pay double/triple gym memberships, and I travel a lot. I am forced to either put my account on hold ($10/month  $20/month for couples), or cancel and pay a high price for initiation.I can't understand the purpose of the high initiation other than trying to force people to put their membership on 'hold', which is kind of a shady business practice. At least don't force people to pay the full initiation the second time (in my case I've had to pay it 5 times).  Planet Granite has a much more reasonable initiation fee

Mission Cliff ((( ROCKS )))!! I highly regard all the staff at the Cliffs. They are awesome, fun, welcoming, helpful, and they certainly know what it means to provide the highest form of customer service to the community. I love that their all about community buidling, awareness, encouragement and empowerment! All Love in this place!

Tip 1:  Parking is a B!  After driving around for 25 minutes, we finally found parking.  There's mostly 1 hour parking in the area so make sure you give yourself ample time to look for parking.  Get dropped off, ride your bike, or cross your fingers and pray for a spot.Tip 2:  Bring a bag to store your belongings.  We used the cubbies which were open to the public.  I didn't have a bag so I had to stuff my keys and wallet in my shoes.  I left with my keys and shoes so it seems pretty safe!  Another alternative is to use the lockers in their restroom- just bring your own lock.Tip 3:  Wear comfortable clothing.  I wore tights and a long sleeve shirt and although I was comfortable, all the reaching and grabbing caused me to perspire.  Don't be shy, show off some skin!Tip 4:  Bring a partner you trust.  Remember, your life is in their hands.  Whenever I reached the top, I would shout out "I'm ready are you ready?!  I'm coming down, are you ready?!  I'm ready, are you?!"  No mater how many times and different ways I said this to my partner, the only person I really need to ask is myself.  Tip 5:  Push yourself.  Encourage each other.  Great workout,  friendly staff, large facility.  I highly recommend trying it at least once.Belay on my friends.

The membership fee is a bit steep, but you get what you pay for in the quantity & quality of routes, as well as weights, yoga, and cardio equipment. Not to mention access to all touchstone gyms as well. Towel service is also included. The bouldering area is adequate -- nothing spectacular, but you wouldn't go here for solely bouldering anyways. I like the smooth texture of the wall. It's a tiny detail, but I've been to gyms with very rough walls that have scuffed up my knees and pants. Also really appreciate all of the bike racks set up at the front of the gym.One ask I'd have is to have a warm up wall for traversing. Other than that, awesome gym.

Member since 2012.Mission cliffs has seen some changes, but it is the best place to climb in the Bay AreaTop 3 reasons:* Largest top rope / lead in California* Weight room / cycle room / yoga room / classes* Great community / staffBottom 3 reasons:* Excellent bouldering area, but smaller than expected* Overall route-setting is not as good as PG* Really crowded now weekday nights 6-8 PM

This is not a great gym or rock climbing gym. You're much better off going to planet granite. Here are the reasons why- Poor Locker Rooms: Small and poorly organized. For example towels aren't stored in the locker room because there isn't enough room.- Climbing facilities: 1) Routes have heavy grade inflation, in no other gym am I doing 5.12's. Thanks for the ego boost but, no.2) Why is the carpet where people climb always bunched? It doesn't have to be this way.- Staff: Uninspired and brusque. - Rental gear: my friend visited and the shoes were horrible and the harnesses not user friendly.

Pros:-Very friendly staff-Members get access to the other touchstone gyms, including Dogwatch Boulders in SF-Location. Easy to access for many, and lost of options for apres-climb restaurants in the Mission.Cons:-It is almost always unbearably hot inside the gym.-Could use more crack climbs, but maybe that's just me. -Workout area is so small and crowded it is nearly impossible to access anything much of the time.

Love this place. Being a resident in the mission, this was my old afterschool playground (afterwork technically, but I felt like a kid here). Routes are nice, and I wouldn't knock on the rating system, but then again it's really whoever sets the route. I've done a 5.11A at Planet Granite Presidio, that totally felt like a 5.10C at MC, but it's always a grab bag. The updates are nice, more climbing area, I think they put in a lot of money on walls from Walltopia, kind of like what Dogpatch has (popular for bouldering competitions). Workers have always been friendly, I've really had a great time being a member here, yes, price is worth it.Updated gym is still a dash tiny, but I really come here to climb, use the locker, sauna, shower, and sometimes take a class. The only reason it is minus one star, is the cleanliness. I don't expect it to be super clean, but it does feel like it needs to be maintained more. Bathroom gets grody sometimes, glad they increased the lockers in the mens room for some more space.If they keep this place clean, get some new equipment in the gym area, create more lighting outside on all sides of the building (I know, broken car windows all the time, but that's SF for ya), and continuously worked at the bathrooms to be renovated, I think it would be close to 5 stars.

Man okay so this place is really awesome as a novice / casual top-roper. Fun and diverse routes with cool colored holds and the clientele is nice and interesting. Its location is convenient to me, and the expansion is a really interesting challenge to climb on.  As a whole, Touchstone is an awesome chain to belong to, with a bunch of very different and good gyms around the Bay area, and if you join one you join them all.  But man there are some problems. The customer service is mostly appalling. With some exceptions, the desk people are uninterested in helping out, don't greet you or look you in the eye, and are often away from the desk. Case in point, one day, me: "Do you offer personal training?" Desk person: "We have a personal trainer associated with us, but they're shockingly expensive." And then turned to walk away. That's government bureaucracy quality ofcustomer service there. Or tonight, I asked for a towel at close: "Aw too bad! You missed towel service," and threw me a towel after I insisted.  That sort of thing: a mix of pretentious, cold, and weirdly buddy-buddy.  I really hate it and it's by far the thing that bothers me most. I pay 73 bucks a month in membership fees. I'd like to be treated with professional courtesy.The weight room was really small when I joined, and since construction has started, it's become even smaller, and now it's moved to a part of the gym that's real awkward. Too open to foot traffic, benches are positioned near protruding wall parts, no mirrors. It's bad and probably dangerous, and there's no indication if it will change. The bouldering area is small too and the problems frustratingly hard for a beginner like me. I guess the difficulty goes with the territory but Dogpatch and Ironworks seem to hit the sweet spot more consistently. Gym closes super early on the weekends. 7pm doesn't really cut it.Many frayed ropes on the top rope routes, and semi-frequent loose holds. Is this dangerous or just annoying?  Well that's it. I've been coming here since December 2013 and getting more and more frustrated. So okay in sum: a large, beautiful top-rope climbing gym in the Mission that has somesmall but significant flaws not apparent at first glance. I really hope something changes.

I was really disappointed. I am on a vacation to San Fran right now and I had heard about the awesome rock gyms in San Fran. I have a membership in LA and the walls are much shorter so I was really excited about climbing some huge walls. The staff was so rude I could not even believe it. They used a different belay device than I'm used to and they refused to show me how to use it. They told me to find another gym patron to show me or try to figure it out on the smaller walls. So of course I went out and bought the belay device I usually use because I had already paid my 20$ and no one was going to give it back. (Utter determination). So, I pass the test. Now my friend comes who is unfamiliar with climbing, not that I'm anywhere near an expert, and they won't show him how to put the harness on. Mind you, at this point, the front desk is not busy and the testing guy is just standing around. I have my own harness and had never see this type of rental harness before. I mean really? You could not take a few seconds to show him how to put the harness on? In the gym I climb in at home, the staff are happy to help. They care about safety and they will show people how to use the equipment because they want to ensure people are safe. They care and they are polite where I come from. Just a quick comment about the quality of the gym itself. Not impressed. The routes for the top route climbing are not very well thought out. It's basically like climbing a latter up a wall. I guess I'm used to more of a puzzle and more wall shape variation. The routes are just really boring. The bouldering routes are more fun. The place was pretty crowded but we were able to find open ropes. The etiquette of the other climbers leaves something to be desired. My guess is that this is because the staff refuses to do any teaching and also perhaps because if the staff does teach I would imagine that if their ettiequte matches their attitude then of course we have poor etiquette.I would not return here. My friend who lives in San Fran does not plan to return here. It's really too bad, I was very excited to get in there and climb.Side note: it took 2 full hours to pass the belay test and the person testing allowed my friend who had never belayed before to belay me without ever actually belaying a person before.

I stopped by this morning to ask info about joining the gym. The guy at the desk should look for another job- technically if I'm walking in there you should jump in the occasion and show me what you got so I can be excited and sign up . No, the guy was not motivated at all to answer my questions, he was very eager to get his stack of towels folded though!All the info I got from him I could have got from the website. I don't think I'm going to join this place due to the initial lack of service .Sorry guys, into the next one!

I had a super fun time here yesterday, first time rock climbing and it was pretty fantastic. I was a little leery of everything at first, although apparently it was my idea to do this... I diverge different story. Anyways, the instructor that helped us out in the necessary first instructional class was awesome. Eden was really patience with me, when I couldn't tell my left from my right hand if it killed me. She really helped out, really sweet and made me comfortable to go rock climbing after the hour tutorial.Besides her, and the great staff the facility was amazing the walls and set up were fantastic. The lockers rooms were all pretty decent as well. I'd totally rec this place for anyone up for an adventure.

This is a review for a kids birthday party we hosted at Mission Cliffs. I am sure it's a great climbing facility otherwise. But parents - beware: our entire experience with the party was a disaster. Instructors were not communicating to each other or the parents, in the process we actually thought we 'lost' a couple of kids which created a small panic. The 'party room' (as they call it, but its really a closet storage with mismatched tables and chairs) was absolutely disgusting when we arrived. It had trash cans full of fruit flies, mess on a floor  - and my demands for cleaning we finally answered after I had to go to the reception twice.  Take your kids party elsewhere...yuk!

Not the best, better than average.  Pretty good climbing gym, lots of top roping and lead routes that are set well.  It's a fun gym, but tends to be overly crowded during the weekdays, obviously not really their fault but worth mentioning.  Staff is friendly, place is pretty clean.  Only thing I'd say is that the bouldering area is pretty tiny and so is the weight room. Worth the monthly fee.

Mission Cliffs is a great climbing facility. One of my favorites I have been to in the US. The route-setting at Mission Cliffs is very good! The routes flow well, there are feet where they are needed, and it is apparent that short people are taken into consideration when the routes are set. I was recommended by a former setter for Touchstone Climbing (route-setters for Mission Cliffs) to visit the gym, and he did not stray me the wrong way. The only thing I could note, and this is petty, is that the grades were pretty soft, but that seems to be the trend with most new gyms. Despite the grade levels, the climbing itself was incredibly fun.Within 20 minutes of being in the gym, I had sent the hardest boulder problem they had to offer, which was a slight bummer, as I was training for a bouldering trip. When I went to the desk to ask for a belay test, so that I could continue climbing, I had mentioned that they needed more hard boulder problems (V10+), and the staff member informed me of their strictly bouldering gym (Dogpatch) a few blocks away. Instead of packing up and heading there, I took my belay test. The gym has a great feature, if you do not have a partner, they will make an announcement over the loudspeaker if anyone else was looking for a partner. I thought this was such a great concept. Within 5 minutes, I had a partner and began climbing every route that gym had to offer.I did not witness a belay lesson, but heard from some patrons that I climbed with that Mission Cliffs is very good about giving thorough belay lessons. In this new day and age of fast-paced mega gyms, it is good to hear that there are still places that understand the importance of a good safety and belay lesson.All in all, a great place to climb!

Let me preface this by saying that this was my first time rock climbing, so I can't really compare this to any other climbing gym. But it's true -- the place was pretty crowded, and I did see many people climbing very closely to one another. My friend even got knocked into a few times.Not sure how they might implement this, but it might be a good idea to share some "rock climbing" etiquette with the less experienced climbers such as myself. Lucky for me, I went with a friend who was pretty knowledgeable, so I was well-informed. That said, I also didn't have to spend much time interacting with the staff. However, when I did, I thought they were helpful and friendly.Overall, it seemed like a pretty chill/safe environment, as I was able to leave my belongings untouched in the outside cubbies (and I'm usually pretty paranoid about that sort of thing). They also have lockers in the respective bathrooms, and other cardio/weight training equipment inside the gym... not sure if that requires a separate type of membership or if it's for the hardcore climbers who want to amp up their heart rate?I don't know if rock climbing is in the future fitness repertoire for me, but I'd definitely be open to trying it out again (and at this location). Also, finding street parking was not an issue and bathrooms/rental shoes were pretty clean.
FUNtastic! My group was full of first timers and our instructor, Eric, was entertaining and helpful.

The rock climbing experience was awesome. So many levels that you have options to choose from and there is plenty of room. Can be a bit packed but it's worth it. Only thing I disliked is that the staff who test the people to get their pass are extremely rude. It's as if they really hate their job. Felt bad for one of my friend cause she felt extremely intimidated by them. Other than that, heck fun!!

love love love mission cliffs!I have climbed here for over 10 years and I LOVE it !if you have not rock climbed then I highly suggest you try itit is the best sport I have done, In a lifetime of doing sportsgo to mission cliffs - the member fee is worth the sauna let alone the gym and rock climbing =)

SUMMARY: I was definitely spoiled by Earth Treks when I lived in DC. Having moved out to SF recently, I have visited this Mission Cliffs + the Planet Granite in Sunnyvale and look forward to visiting the others. --------------MORE DETAILS--------------ROUTES: This Mission Cliffs has much more lenient ratings than any other climbing gym I've been to (10+). At other gyms, I can't touch a 5.10c, but here I've been able to complete a 5.10C without stopping (and I'm more out of shape than ever). This is great for my ego, but something to keep in mind. The bouldering route ratings seem to be on par with other gyms. There also seems to be less slopers and crimps in routes. Having said that, there are very few routes under 5.10a - a trickle of 5.6 - 5.9s but not much. There's a good array of tall and shorter climbs. I've been here on what seems like their busiest times and you may have to wait for a few minutes, but if you aren't too picky you never seem to have to wait a lot. Good set of bouldering routes as well. STAFF: NEUTRAL: Staff seems ok - have had some meh experiences and some good ones. They seem to pay more attention than some other gyms to if you have your belay card or not.CLEANLINESS: GREAT: Bathrooms + main areas are all clean - no complaints. Free towels + lotion are available for use.
Fantastic community climbing center, decent free weights, yoga classes and plenty of cardio equipment. Staff is friendly. Women's locker room was recently remodeled!!!

I first got a membership when I moved back the bay 6 years ago. Then, MC was way too crowded for me and I usually avoided it. Even after the remodel, it's even more crowded and that's not even what gets me. What gets me is the members who seem to have a total disregard for any climbing etiquette--people climbing on top of other people, not taking turns in the boulder area, etc. It felt like a complete mess. I somewhat blame MC for not pushing better behavior as there are a lot of new climbers who are behaving poorly. It's ironic that as the gym has become more unusable because of crowds, membership rates of increased... I don't live in the area, so I plan to avoid this place at all cost, it just bums me out.

You like to get your hands dirty?! You like to sweat?! You're not afraid of heights or at least trust your buddy not to drop you?! Then this is the place to be! HUGE climbing gym, nice bouldering area AND a gym plus classes you can take! What else can you possibly want?!

Why have I not reviewed after four check-ins? Well because there is not much to say. I come for bouldering, and it is a nice local gym but not perfect. It gets very crowded and super hot at times, but it is a convenient spot. I am not sure the admission price really reflects the facilities - it is tough to stay stimulated after an hour as it is a pretty small area. However, it is really a great place to come at a slow time of the day, with friends. Make a morning or afternoon of it and have a good climb before lunch or dinner.

I really like MishCliffs. It was the first climbing gym I ever visited, and it holds a special place in my heart. The intro to toproping class is great, and the instructors are friendly and patient. Additionally, the locker rooms here are the nicest of the three Touchstone gyms I've been to.The staff here are all pretty friendly, and most of the clientele also seem pretty chill and laid back. That said, this place gets craaazy packed after work on weekdays. It's almost unbearable. On weekends, expect smaller crowds. (I'm sure the same can be said for weekdays during the day, but I've never tested this out.)They seem to change up the routes pretty frequently here, but not too frequently so you can still conquer your projects. There's something for every difficulty level here, but the lead climbing seems to be a bit packed into tight quarters, which makes for some scary incidents every now and then.Parking is very very very rarely an issue here. Usually street parking is pretty easy to find on weekday evenings or on weekends, plus it's free! :)NB: One of the things I really like about the Touchstone gyms in general is that they double the rope at the top anchor, so there is additional friction that prevents the belayer from being lifted up from the floor. It makes for a nice gym experience, even if it isn't super reminiscent of an outdoor experience.

What's not to like?!?! Tips:- If you drive, there's usually parking in the street right behind the building- They have lockers, but you have to bring your own lock, or buy one there for $5- For beginners that need to learn how to tie in as a climber and how to belay, plan to attend one of their intro to climbing classes (touchstoneclimbing.com/m…)- They usually waive their member registration fee in January - so go sign up now!- There's also yoga classes and other stuff like cardio boxing offered in the studio space

Mission Cliffs has a lot to offer. A great selection of ever-changing climbing paths through bouldering, belay or lead. It also has classes, a nice, but small gym area, treadmills and ellipticals. My least favorite part is how many tech-dudes come here and talk business extremely loud. I don't wanna hear it! Also parking can definitely be a pain around this area.

I'm fairly new to rock climbing, so we took the class that shows you all the ropes (bad pun intended). Our instructor was absolutely friendly and helpful. Even though I'm sure they do this all day long, he was very energetic and attentive.Then it was time to climb! My belay parter and I felt very safe the whole time, and it's fun to try out the different routes. Super welcoming atmosphere, great staff, and a wonderful experience overall. Will be back!

If I had to rank Mission Cliffs solely on their available climbs and workout equipment, I'd give 'em a 4.So why do they get a 2?The Staff: No one there smiles. Ever. I can't tell if it's pretentiousness or boredom. Actually, considering the few exchanges I've had with one of the testers there, it's probably pretentiousness.The Aroma: Ladies, I dunno how your locker room fares... but the men's locker room smells of perma-dump. All the time. The moist shower air only locks it in. This is a sentient stink, as it somehow knows and understands that it is not allowed past the locker room doorway (probably because it doesn't want to pay the entry/membership fees).The Lockers: Speaking of the locker room,... if you wish to lock your belongings safely away while out on the wall, you gotta bring your own lock. That's fair; lots of places do it that way. Perhaps you can understand, then, why it burns my bristles to never have access to a locker because everyone else is cramming their crap into the units and NOT using a lock, when we all know there are only so many lockers available. Honestly, if you have a lock then just start moving the unlocked stuff out.The Hipster Ratio: These spoiled brats are claiming this place as their own, complete with the usual level of flippant privilege they expect. Standing on a belayer's rope? Check. Flying down a wall haphazardly? Check. Telling climbers to wait while they continue their climb? Check. Stupid beards? Check.Truth be told, I'm going to use up the last of the visits on my pass and then go someplace else.

I'm not generally keen on gyms. They tend to encourage surliness, cocky machismo, and smell bad to boot.This place is great. Climbing routes and bouldering problems are always pretty darn fresh.Multiple daily yoga classes (and workshops!) are included in membership.The humans - staff and members - are pretty much unanimously friendly.Only thing I would change:  Cleaner facilities. The floors are not the cleanest and the changing areas can often smell like pungent feet :P.

I come to Mission Cliffs during the week on my way home from work.   It is one of the Touchstone gyms so if you have their regular membership, you can use it here and at any of their other gyms. For me that would be Berkeley Ironworks and sometimes Oakland Great Western Power Co.  Their website is pretty comprehensive in terms of the information they provide about the specs, events, rates, class schedules, etc.  I give Mission Cliffs five stars for their high climbing walls and the varied and interesting routes.  My favorites are the fun overhang problems, and the high walls definitely  give you an opportunity to build up your endurance.  The variations in the route setting also means you can practice different climbing techniques and it's really awesome.It can get pretty crowded during the week, but I have never had to wait long to get on the rope.  Their bouldering area is upstairs and it's a little cramped but still decent.  The workout area is a little small (compared to Berkeley Ironworks) and the cardio machines are scattered (some upstairs and some by the shop) but it's no big deal.  And it's only a block away from Southern Pacific Brewing company, so you know...if you get thirsty after the climb you know where to quench your thirst.

This place is sick.  First time I went here was way back in 98 or something, when I first came to SF to hang with friends.  At that time, it was the biggest indoor rock climbing wall I'd ever seen.  That was before us East Coasters were graced with Chelsea Piers and more recently Brooklyn Boulders.Interestingly, on a recent trip here in the summer, I was meeting up with my friends.  They asked me to come by and I arrived about fifteen minutes before they finished.  Upon entering, the woman at the counter asked for my membership card.  Since I didn't have one, I explained that I wasn't going to climb, but simply wanted to wait for my friends.  She proceeded to explain that under no circumstances could I come into the place without either taking a balay test or presenting my membership card.  I ended up going outside and waiting by the curb.  LOL  Shortly thereafter one of my friends came to the door and escorted me in.  The crazy wacky woman was no longer at the counter, so I guess we got lucky.  They told me she is known for being kinda clipboard-nazi style, and I said she reminded me of the chicks who work the velvet ropes in NY!  Anyway, i wouldn't let that one bad experience blind you to the obvious awesomeness that is Mission Cliffs.  Get your six-pack on people!

I really like coming to this place. i think the staff is really friendly and helpful. A great place to learn. One of the guys spent a good amount of time teaching us...and gave up helpful tips to remember the method (e.g. "choke and punch the guy" to make a figure 8 knot)It's gets pretty busy on week day nights and on Saturdays. I came here on a Saturday and it seemed like almost every rope was taken. It also stunk from everyone's feet and sweat.

Prices went up without any added amenities. Not only that, the bouldering wall actually got smaller. There were so many parts of it left empty today. Not sure what's going on, but I'm not liking the trend here.

This place is always, always super crowded, especially on week days. The climbs are long and varies often, but people are usually waiting for routes or climbing around each other. I dunno about you, but I get anxiety whenever someone starts climbing too close to me. The gym and weight area are also kinda small, but they have decent equipment.I come here since it's close, but definitely prefer PG.

Sweet way to spend an afternoon, even if it turned out to be the longest climbing session o' my life. Brother and I each grabbed day passes, which are $12 if you can pop into the place before 3 pm (o doing stuff working stiffs can't...). $2 or 3 bucks if you need shoes and harness. We very clearly put on the harnesses ass backwards since we weren't used to the kind they use, so thank god some climber did a "pssh, you look retarded PSA" for us (he was nicer than that). We got ourselves belay tested and then started hauling up the walls. Staff were really nice and patient!Loved the toproping here since the difficulty grades seem well-thought through, and it's awesome being able to do routes probably three times the length that I'm used to at the Stanford climbing wall.Bouldering seems awesome too upstairs, but my forearms were already calling in death threats by the time we ambled upstairs. All in all, we were there for a tad more than two hours of climbing time, so not so bad. Definitely getting a month-to-month membership in the summer!

As a fairly regular climber (3-4/week), and fairly new San Francisco mission-ish resident- MC is the closest and most convenient climbing gym for me. That being said- I spend most of my time bouldering while there. The Good: Lots of variety (though the problems I can actually do wear out quickly). Clean lockers (for me, at least) and showers)Convenient LocationThe Bad: It seems as if MC is the place to go if you're...       a) Like to talk about yourself      b) Like to talk about yourself in the tech industry.       c) like to talk about how big of a shot you are at your job in the tech industry (I'm looking at you shirtless, pudgy, curly haired, beardo and friend).  Oh- and don't even think about missing a hold lest you incur the passive agressive banter of your fellow climbers (see list above for description). "You HAVE to use all the holds. They put them there for a reason." If all that sounds bitter- it's because I am. I'm a teacher. The last thing I want to do after work is hear overgrown children moan and complain about their overpaid jobs. Just shut up and climb.If you can- avoid it. GWPC in Oakland, and Ironworks in Berkeley win hands down with a blindfold on. If not- grin and bear it...or write a Yelp review.

Been bouldering for a couple months and this place is wonderful. They have endless top-rope and a small but well-rounded bouldering section. They also have plenty of treadmills, ellipticals and a solid weights section. Free-wifi and a nice work area in the Boulder top out area is a plus. Haven't tried any of their classes but they also offer cycle, yoga, and more. My only complaint would be that it has quite a corporate feel (as opposed to the family feel of great western power company in Oakland). Also, if you come after work it will be super crowded.

My boyfriend took me here for our Anniversary and we were definitely tired afterwards. The staff is very friendly here and is good at teaching beginners how to rock climb. It was our first time, so we had no idea what we were doing. Our instructor taught us how to tie the rope (which is the VERY complicated) but with a few practices, we got it down. After the class, we got to explore the whole place and climb whichever wall we wanted to. They range from very easy to difficult.. and we stayed on the easy side, of course. If you're really into this, you can bring your own rope and equipment.. and even sign up for a membership. One time was enough for me.. I think I'll stick to other sports.. but it was a good time.
My favorite place to climb!! Great top roping areas! I highly recommend coming during the day time because it gets packed during the evenings.

This place is so dirty that I actually, sadly, stopped climbing here. I was a four day a week climber. The same abandoned hair tie (full of someones gross hair) was in the ladies bathroom for about four months before it was cleaned up. Just a signal that the place was not being properly cleaned.Only climbing outside or traveling to another climbing gym from now on. And I am a fairly gross person, but this took the cake. The foot smell every time I have walked in here for the past few years will not be missed. It is about 3 times stinkier than any other climbing gym.

I came here for the first time not exactly knowing what to expect. For the price of a movie theater ticket we were able to embark on an indoor climbing adventure. I have to say that heights are not really my thing. I felt safe and I control throughout the entire activity. You need to have upper body strength and good dexterity to be able to make it to the more difficult areas. The instructor was patient and friendly. If it were not for my aversion to heights I would give this place a five star review.

I am a newbie and have been climbing for just about 5 months. I was hesitant to join or even check out MC because it looked very SF sceney with lot's of shirtless posturing dudes covered in tape and chalk. Well, many of the dudes are exactly that and there is an excessive amount of "look at me" hollering and grunting from them--kinda like the monkey cages at the zoo. BUT, thankfully, I am an adult woman and can laugh at them and go on with my climb. There are a lot of older women climbers which I appreciate and a lot of women in general. Most of the other climbers are sweet, helpful and encouraging and I am really enjoying it.  I climb Saturday's around 10 and Sunday's around 12 and haven't had very long wait times. I am also lucky to be able to climb in middle of the day on weekdays sometimes... I also joined when they waived the $100 joining fee. That was helpful.The staff has always been very nice and welcoming to me, the yoga is pretty darn good except that I think the teachers could all get a little more creative with their classes--too much time in downward dog and warrior. The cycling is meh ( don't like biking anyway) and the weights area, I haven't tried.Yes, it smells. DUH!  It's a dusty warehouse converted into a climbing and fitness gym that has stacks of smelly shoes and walls full of SWEATY snail trailers with stinky feet. Bathrooms are decently clean, but I only use the lockers because I live three blocks away ( YAY!). They are upgrading the entire place however and much of these issues will probably go away.  I would very much like to see the matting under the ropes area to be re-done. I don't know how many times I have almost ripped my toes off tripping on the metal pieces, especially the ones along the edge.The ONE thing that annoys me more than anything are the weekend children's parties. There HAS GOT to be some change here. I would pay more to have the place party free. Kids end up unsupervised, running amok, tangling ropes,  running under descending climbers and screaming. Good times.  Awesome instructor.  Super informative.  Took a belay class as a refresher, and learned to tie a figure 8 like a boss.

I came in the other day and took the safety class with the instructor Daniel and he was absolutely amazing .he was very friendly and bothered her and explain everything very simple way .Mission eclipse is a great place for indoor rockclimbing and you should definitely ask for Daniel if you want to take the safety class.

My upper body strength is nil.Seriously. Nil.Back in elementary school when those President's Physical Fitness tests were all the rage in schools -  I always failed miserably - when it came to the push-up and pull-up part. My body just wouldn't cooperate. And so those coveted President's Physical Fitness blue badges were perpetually out of reach. I always had to settle for red (which when you think about it - red is a much cooler color than blue anyways).Nowadays I've pretty much sworn off exercising - outside of walking and dancing (though I've found that messy rooms can conveniently double up as agility obstacle courses - and sharpie scribbling makes for prime arm work-out) So when I learned that we were having a small work offsite at Mission Cliffs Climbing & Fitness - I was both a little nervous and excited. Excited because climbing sounds fun. Looks fun. And because my arms could definitely benefit from some quality strength challenges. Nervous - because the idea of someone's life being in my hands - on some rope does not sound like fun. Nervous because like I said before - I have absolutely no upper body strength.Despite any initial reservations - Mission Cliffs surpassed my expectations. Mission Cliffs was not only impressive -  facility wise - but their staff rocked it. From the moment we arrived - their staff were helpful, patient, and efficient.They let us leave our stuff in the party room - and didn't object when we hungrily devoured  huge cupcakes before making our way to the ropes (sooooooooooo not a good idea)We were split into two groups. My group's instructor was amazing. She walked us through everything with extreme diligence. If we didn't understand something - she would smile and then take her time in really making sure that we were comfortable with a concept - before moving on.It was apparent from the moment she began talking - that she truly enjoyed climbing and seemed to genuinely enjoy teaching people about how to better appreciate it, as well as making sure that we were doing it as safely as possible.When it came to the actual climbing part - I  - was...well not good. My  climbing - form  - pretty much mirrored the way I dance - butt out. But I had such a great experience with the process of learning how to climb - that I'd love to come back sometime and try to conquer the climbing wall again....And maybe even try some yoga here..The great thing about Mission Cliffs is that it is not only an exceptional climbing center, but it's also a fitness center. They offer yoga classes and even host some basic exercise equipment as well.My favorite take-away from Mission Cliffs, outside of that slightly sore feeling in the arms,  is that despite the popular misconception that climbing is all about upper body strength - it isn't. It's about problem solving and keeping your body in balance to find the best angle and position possible - to allow you to work your way up a wall or incline as comfortably and confidently as possible...(at least that's what I took away from it...)Which means - there's hope for me  :)

I never in a million years thought that I would enjoy rock climbing. What's to like? Climbing up a steep, treacherous wall with only tiny pegs standing in the way from me a sloppy floor plunge...needless to say with that attitude I wasn't exxaaaactly selling it to myself. That is until the BF suggested we go and then of course, I was more open minded. I'm really glad. It was SO much fun; hard as hell but SO much fun. My expectations were this: I walk up to the wall, I lift my foot on to the first peg and then collapse on the ground in to a Mr. Burns from the Simpsons-like heap. I guess I don't give myself enough credit, though, because I made it up to the top! Granted it took me a while and it wasn't a very big wall but still! Me! I can't wait to come back.

My brother and I came here today, his first time climbing and me, out of shape. We took the climbing class to learn the ropes (ahhaaaa get it?), the lesson was well-taught and within 40 minutes we were ravaging and conquering 5.8's and up. We went during the daytime so it wasn't crowded, but word around the street is that it gets stupid crowded after 6pm on weekdays.Pros: Kinda cheap, $15/day, $30 including the tutorial. This includes harness, ATC, shoes (optional and I don't recommend unless your shoes are weighty), and carabiner.Cons: IT SMELLS LIKE FEET and GENITALS. And you get a big whiff of it right when you walk through the door. It wafts around and does not go away. {shrug}

I booked a team building climbing experience at this gym with my co workers and we had an amazing time - it's also probably because I work with fitness maniacs - thank god.  They are in the midst of a huge remodel and the place is still awesome.  I have been climbing on and off for years now and that experience just reminded me that I need to climb more.  If you haven't tried climbing - you are missing out and you really should!  The staff was attentive and the facility is nice and clean.  If I lived near this place, there would be more sighting of me in it.

Great experience. If you want to do something different, bring a date, just workout, or have fun I would recommend it. I booked 2 intro to climbing class. It's affordable and a great value. The staff member that taught us was really nice and professional. After the class you can practice by yourself which is really nice. I would go early because it gets packed in there. For sure a place to check out.

Great, definitely a work out for a first timer. Remember to do your stretches! You won't be able to feel your arms the rest of the day & the next. The belayers we had for our group were nice and patient, which was great for someone like me who is afraid of heights :) Don't look down...! Some walls were super difficult and my tiredness didn't allow me to make it all the way to the top. I think next time I will rent shoes and see if that makes a difference in climbing. The only downside is probably the stinky feet smell & parking.

I will admit that certain ex-San Francisco expats in London hyped up Mission Cliffs to be a whole lot more impressive than it actually was, however as far as climbing gyms go, this one ticks all the boxes.Annie L and I arrived about fifteen minutes prior to opening on a Tuesday morning (read: stupid o'clock a.m.) and were pretty much the first two people in the door. The automated computerised sign-up process was painless and easy (for me... less so for her) and took no more than five minutes. Then it was off to the races!I will note that even at crazy early hours, Missions Cliffs is busy. From the moment the doors opened, there were hardcore gym-goers on the stationary bikes warming up, some far more proficient climbers than I on the walls, and it got progressively more hectic as the morning wore on. I could see this place being jam packed during normal hours or on the weekends, but there was a pleasant hum of activity during the early morning.Coming back to the bouldering, you'll not want for options or challenge. I struggled with a couple of V0s and V1s over by the bikes until we realised that there was a whole section of wall strewn with easier bouldering problems tucked away in a back corner upstairs. I did witness some more experienced climbers working on some awe-inspiring climbs around the corner, and I always love ogling -- errr... I mean... admiring... -- the grace and athleticism of hardcore enthusiasts.If I lived in SF, I could totally see making this a local morning routine, especially if I lived nearby. While it doesn't have the jaw-dropping qualities of size or aesthetic awe that London's Castle Climbing Centre does, Mission Cliffs is utterly respectable for what it is.

I started here with a month membership from Groupon and I couldnt be happier! I've been renewing my membership for the past 2 months*The staff is really friendly and helpful. *If you're a newbie, the intro to climbing course is $29 for non members, free for members. *there's a sauna in the locker rooms! Close to the 16th Street Bart and buses (33, 22, 27, and all mission buses)Apparently they are expanding their space soon, which will make it even better!

Just got a membership to this over planet granite due to the location and their expansion coming up. The staff here is wayyyy nicer and the music is better. I will say that if you are a student (like me) Planet Granite is $25 bucks cheaper a month... but you need to weight the pros and cons.

I haven't been climbing in years and so trying it again was... well... scary. I'm scared of heights but having an oh so awesome person to belay me calmed my nerves... slightly.Anyways, Mission Cliffs is a pretty fun place to climb. Just be prepared to pay $$ for the weekends.PS. It smells like feet in here.PSS. All climbing gyms do. Well maybe except dogpatch, but that one is new...

It took a visit to a smaller SoCal climbing gym to understand the great things that Mission Cliffs provides. Sure the membership's a bit expensive, but what you get is a huge variety of well balanced courses with consistent difficulties and friendly staff who are courteous and ready to help with anything. Guest passes and comprehensive facilities are icing on the cake.I'd give 5 stars if there was a separate, cheaper membership option for climbing only! I don't really dig fitness machines.

Pluses:Locker RoomsGym AreaRock Climbing!!!Bouldering!!!Friendly, likable staff,Group classesMinuses:Kind of expensive membershipneed to bring your own padlock for lockersgets PACKED anytime after work on a weekdayBouldering and climbing is tough when there are soo many peopleIt's also a long check-in for non-members and those renting equipment when they're that busyDespite the minuses, I LOVE this place! One of the best rock-climbing places I've ever been. Went yesterday with some friends, had tons of rock climbing walls, and also bouldering walls. Staff was helpful and amiable. Walls had difficulty all the way from 5.4-5.13 and practice walls. Also, they're open until 10pm! So I have enough time to leave work and climb for a few hours.This place rocks. Forgive the bad pun.
:) I like this place.Yoga Class yay. And other fitness classes avails.Other gym stuff like treadmills, sauna, showers.. SERVICE:workers here are nice

If any venue deserves an a-okay rating, it is Mission Cliffs.  Location, convenient hours, and general consistency are winners.  It's a gym full of sweaty people, so there are occasionally weird smells and always chalk dust on everything.  It does seem to be getting consistently busier and busier everywhere - from climbs to the locker room.  And sometimes, when I'm lead climbing I feel like an extra from Thunderdome (you know - Tina Turner, Mel Gibson: Two enter, One leave...) because questionable safety choices happen often.  I don't want to blame people who are new to the activity, but the general approach to safety here makes me a little nervous.  And FYI: the outside bike parking provides A LOT of parts to the local bike thieves.  I lost a pretty nice seat that was locked to the frame of my beater bike and two other friends have lost entire bicycles (also locked) in the last 3 months.  I guess once your neighborhood bike grabber invests in bolt cutters they feel obligated to use them?  So - maybe don't park you $$$ custom frame outside.

Mission cliffs is a mixed bag....I've been climbing at Mission Cliffs on and off for years, but never had the time (or a regular belayer) to follow my climbing enthusiasm through.  Well now I finally know some peeps who get me there on a periodic basis. So here's what I love about Mission Cliffs:**Total low-key staff.  Really helpful, really friendly.**It's a full-on gym!  Cardio equipment (although not the best), a circuit    area (pretty cramped though), and weights.**Classes too!  Yep.  Yoga, pilates, boxing, cycling, climbing.  **Dedicated people.  Don't expect to find anyone reading magazines here.  It's ALL   BUSINESS. No-frills, no fuss.  Just how I like it.   **A no-commitment membership.  That's right, month-to-month.  Although I've yet to sign up, I may consider it...As I ponder the membership, here's what I could do without:**The skanky smells and dirtiness.  I'm sorry, I don't want to make it       sound like a rat hole, but it's a little rough.  It just looks like they don't    clean inside very much.  **The old tapes that need replacing on MANY of the older routes.     There are some routes that are borderline impossible to climb    because you can't see where you're going!**It's a freaking MAD HOUSE on weeknights.  TOO Crowded, too    much chalk-dust flying around, too long to wait.  Also on weeknights,    I noticed that some climbers are a little territorial.  Seriously.  Why?Overall, a cool place.  Throw in the fact that EVERYONE there is in shape!  They offer enough to keep my mind and body (and eyes) active ;)

So much FUN! However, the place get a bit crowded on week nights and people are practically stepping over each other to get ropes...Still need to adjust to the humid/sweaty funk but definitely excited to go back and climb some more!

Having a one on one with your boss bouldering at 6:30am is definitely something to tick of the list of things I've done before I die."Look at how I glide effortlessly up the wall, understand the symbolism boss man."Sadly I did not glide up the walls but rather cussed as I dangled from one arm like a frustrated monkey that believed inside she really was a collie but lived in a village that would ostracise her for coming out.... Lost? That's OK it's one of my talents.For bouldering I found this disappointing. There wasn't the mix of climbs and walls to satisfy me. Also the basic matting had me a bit nervous. The gym itself is a great space -- high, airy, and light.  The staff is friendly and helpful and the overall mood of the place is pretty good.  All that said, I have to agree with other reviewers that when this place gets crowded (after work on weekdays) it becomes hard to enjoy the experience -- people  are climbing on top of each other as the routes are pretty close together.  Most folks are pretty polite about it and work things out among themselves.  The bouldering area is well laid out and pretty extensive and therefore easier to climb at when the routes get crowded.

Mission Cliffs. Founded 1995. Hasn't been cleaned since...1995. Hasn't had ropes swapped since...1995.This place is a lawsuit waiting to happen. I guess that's why you sign a waiver. Pads that come up to trip you to...ropes that barely fit through an ATC b/c of all the chalk caked in them...blood smeared on the wall...people taking pictures with one hand while belaying with the other...holds that spin the day after the route was set.Oh, but that's okay you think, I can just focus on my route. Mission Cliffs, my oasis in this concrete jungle. Harrison and 19th. I've said it a million times. That's because I've told so many people about my climbing gym, and they all want to know where it is (The Mission not being specific enough).Why do I talk about it so much? 1. It's a great place to learn to climb. A year ago I had only ever rock climbed once (and that was almost 20 years ago in Tahoe). MC has lots of classes and the testing doesn't take that long. The staff is quick to get you hooked up for the day.2. Community! I see the same faces year-round, and there are some serious athletes that frequent this place (lots of pull-ups). If I see them every time I'm here, one can almost guarantee they come more often. The staff is nice too. They're very patient with the n00bs.3. Routes! There are so many routes, varying in degree. A few 5.4-5.6s and lots of 5.10s. A year into it, my climbing partner and I have reached the moderate level that allows us to climb 5.10As and 5.10Bs without climbing the same routes each week. The staff does a pretty good job of creating new routes. 4. Space to breathe. The height of this building is so tall that the bouldering walls are on the second floor.  5. Locker room. It has all the things you need: showers, saunas, open air, lockers etc. Best part, it's kept really clean! I guess that goes back to my second reason for loving this place, the community...There are a few things that could make this place better - more space to do ab workouts/stretching and the cardio machines are out-dated and often broken. I hear they're expanding, so perhaps I'll be adjusting my review soon!

Decent indoor climbing gym, a bit far from my home but always nice to have options. It did have a sweaty gym odor and was very full/busy. Gym itself was just average, not a big fan :-(

I don't even want to know about the spin room.

Terrible experience. I went for the first time and non of the employees are motivated to work. Even when I asked for help they were busy flirting with customers. I felt bad with a couple that was also bring ignored, but I asked for my money back and left. Stay away, there are better places out there

'bout time I update my review...So I love the laid back vibe and friendly staff. Steve and company took good care of me. Mission Cliffs keeps getting better.  They have recently remodeled and added yoga, better weight facilities, and a great little spin bike room.  The spin classes (with Chris) are awesome.  MC has evolved from a good climbing gym to a boss climbing gym and your one-stop fitness club.

I learned to climb at Mission Cliffs, tried out Planet Granite and decided to stay with MC. It's so much more convenient and the staff is really nice.Also, if you're thinking about joining and are on the fence, the 10 pass is great. Two words: Dog Patch!Anyway, I went here recently with a few of my friends and had a blast. We primarily top roped and it was great. The routes were well set and the walls had some nice angles. The bouldering section was a little disappointing. I was hoping it to be similar in size to Planet Granite or a smaller version of Bridges Rock Gym. Though the routes were great, it was waaaaay too crowded/dangerous to jam so many people in such a little space. Then again, that's why we have DOG PATCH!

I have a lot of friends who rock climb, and so my boyfriend and I got ourselves a Groupon for an introductory rock climbing class at Mission Cliffs.  We then proceeded to procrastinate using it because we thought we would be absolutely terrible.  My boyfriend doesn't know what he's talking about.  He's a fit, robust guy and he knows what he's doing.  Me, on the other hand...I come from a long, proud line of pear-shaped, T-rex-armed women.  I have been diligently working on my upper body strength, but it's really quite slow going.  And so, not wanting to lose out on a Groupon and wanting to take part in this activity my friends promised me was fun, I hauled myself out to Mission Cliffs full of fear and trepidation.I was a little surprised to find that Mission Cliffs has gym equipment as well as rock walls, but I was also surprised to see what an incredibly warm community there was around me.  Rock climbing, as I learned, is pretty impossible to do on your own - you always need someone to hang onto your rope while you're climbing.  And so the climbers formed a really cozy community.  At first I felt a little like I was peeking in on something that wasn't mine, but eventually I realized that everyone was probably even happier to have me around than I was to be there.And then the class started.  My boyfriend and I got there for the early class and so had the instructor all to ourselves.  He was friendly and knowledgeable, and in a short period of time I went from having no idea what was going on to having enough knowhow to get myself up and down a wall, and to ensure that I didn't drop my boyfriend like a sack of potatoes onto the bouncy, spongey floor.  By the time we ventured out to an actual climb, my clumsy fingers found their way around the knots with relative ease and I felt that I knew what to do for almost any situation in which our inexperienced bodies would find themselves.  And then we climbed.  And climbed.  And climbed.  I think I made it up the wall two-and-a-half times before my body all but gave out.  Not just my upper body, mind you - no, climbing is as much about pushing yourself as it is about pulling, and as much about strategy as it is about brute force (at least it is when you're tiny like me).  My whole body just said, "You know what, Becca?  I don't think I have anything left to give you."  I was completely utterly spent, and it actually felt really good.  While my body asked me to please stay away from Mission Cliffs for a few days, my heart and mind are ready for more.  And I shall return.  And then I get to be part of the smiling camaraderie on a Saturday morning where friendly, happy people cavalierly hoist themselves up giant walls using tiny footholds.  Thanks, Mission Cliffs - for helping me see that I'm ready to live the dream.

Some people have called me a gym-rat. I disagree. Regardless, I'm at Mission Cliffs a lot. The routes are changed often enough to keep me interested, as are the problems in the bouldering area. And there are plenty of lead routes too. The place can get super crowded sometimes (particularly Tuesday and Thursday nights), and you might have to wait for a rope (ugh). But you can use that time to chat with the friendly folks who visit the gym regularly. The staff is also very nice, but strict when it comes to giving out belay cards. And once you already have one, it doesn't mean they won't pull it later if you're caught doing something dangerous. The yoga there is also pretty good. Some of the instructors are better than others (go to Kate's class if you can!), but they offer so many classes each week that you can pick and choose which ones you like best. And they have mats and props if you don't bring your own.The locker room has plenty of lockers to store your stuff, decent showers, and also a sauna (great for after a workout).I've been going here for about two years, and don't see myself stopping in the near future.

I come here to butch up my hands.My first visit to mission cliffs was an attempt to get me to trust more and bond instead of being skidish like a cat and mawling hands that touch my belly.It didn't work but my shoulders are way buffer now.Once you get past the odor of straining to crawl up walls you're good.

I never thought much about rock climbing. Not that I thought it was stupid or anything like that, I guess I just had no interest in it. It wasn't until stepping into IronWorks for the first time (the one in Berkeley) that my eyes have finally opened. Initially I was more overwhelmed by the immensity of this place. Colorful rocks that filled wall after wall, boulder after boulder. Courses that seem endless and possibly high enough to reach the sky (i'm 5'4" okay?) I ended up just watching people climb that time. And I was truly amazed.Mission Cliffs is smaller compared to IronWorks. But it was still big! Finally it was my turn. Learning the basics like tying knots and safety rules wasn't bad. In fact, it was reassuring. Because I was terrified. lol.My first climb: first couple steps...not bad. Almost half way...struggling a bit. Then up a bit more. Oh man...hahaha. Even with the AC blasting, I was sweating like an infant peeing in his diaper. To make matters worse, I looked down at my anchor person for help. And of course, I'm afraid of heights. hahaha. I started losing grip because my palms were so sweaty. But I was so afraid to let go to get some chalk. All that was going through my head was "OMG OMG, I can't do this anymore!" Actually I think I eventually said that outloud. ahaha. So the outcome of my first climb: FAIL! =[But I did manage to complete 2 climbs after that. YAY! It feels really rewarding to finish a climb. I understand why people do it now. And of course it's a really good workout. Climbing is definitely hardwork! My arms were sooooore! hahaha.The sport of rock climbing has earned my respect. And props to every climber out there! =]

PG is nicer, but this is more convenient and closer.Workout area is small, ellipticals are super cramped, but you come here to climb anyway, right?Yeah basically it could use a renovation, but it's a great climbing gym right in the middle of SF, 'nuff said.

Absolutely LOVE THIS PLACE! It has yoga, a gym AND the climbing and bouldering walls. I spent most of my time bouldering - I absolutely love it there. It is not far off mission street either so is very easy to get too!

This is my most favorite gym I have ever belonged to! They have a belay area, so if you can't find a partner or you want to climb solo, they've got you covered. Another benefit of this gym is it's a part of Touchstone, which means you get to climb at all their gyms.
