Sf, Concord, Oakland, Berkeley, San Jose and if you're in Sacramento or Fresno, they've still got you covered!I've belonged to this gym for almost 3 years... Quick tip. Wait till they have their "No initiation fee" when enrolling... you'll save yourself $100. These happen around 3 times a year!Now get out there!

I came here for the introductory lesson.  All three students in our intro class were law students.  I'm not surprised - law students need to de-stress somehow!  Apparently it is either through alcohol, BDSM, or rock climbing.  No joke!1) The introductory lesson is around $25 - $28.2) Make sure you make a reservation.  They have a morning class, 2:30 PM class, and a 6:00 PM class. (Don't be like me and show up at 3:30!)3) Class usually lasts about an hour but can take longer.4) You get a day pass for the same day with the purchase of the intro lesson.5) Bring a lock for the provided lockers.Our instructor was friendly and helped me see the rock climbing light at the end of tunnel.  Because we were late to a concert, he even issued us vouchers to continue our climbing another day.  Maybe it's because he got to make fun of me so much?  It's not a secret I'm not too coordinated.Did you know there is even a sauna in the changing room?  It's a great room for drying off from the rain or a shower(blow drying is inefficient in my opinion)!  You can even use it for traditional sauna purposes!  The possibilities are endless.

Was here over the weekend for the first time in a few years. It was really great to see how much they had expanded the climbing space & were plenty of routes to climb without a ton of people crowding the walls in the morning. The thing that really took me off guard was the very unfriendly staff at the front desk. I usually climb @ the Oakland and Berkeley gyms & love the desk staff at both places. Here, not so much. Both people working the desk were extremely unfriendly and it was noted by the person I was with that this is normal. Who has time for bad attitudes?

This place is fantastic!!!!!!!!!I recently held a birthday party for my kids.  Remy was very accommodating with our date changes, answered every/any questions that I had and was able to showed the event space a week prior to our event. Day of event, sadly, Remy was off. However, the front desk staff were friendly and provided the assistance that we needed to ease the flow of checking in our guests.  The 3 belay staff for our group were awesome!!! Eric, one of our belay staff, was FANTASTIC!!!!  Eric was supportive, silly, and provided encouragement to the kids, and myself, to climb higher and conquer fears. We truly appreciate him for making our experience so memorable.

The best in the bay. I love the friendly staff and the friendly members.  quality of routs are so much better than other places I've climbed before. I wish boulder section was bigger, but then you get to know everyone who climbs there in a month.  They are so helpful, too. Hands down. THE BEST.

I love this gym, it is friendly and great, it has pretty much everything i could ask for from my gym except for two things;1-the hours suck! i really wish they stayed open much more often,and 2-they allow kids in there.

I'm always looking for a great excuse to get off my ass. My buddy (who was a member) invited me and I had a blast. I don't recall how much I a paid but it was somewhere between $15-$25. It was much more of a workout than I thought it would be. The few people we interacted with were very friendly. The only thing that kind of sucks is that you have to go with a partner in order to climb (which makes sense). If you're a first timer you have to pass a test to make sure that you can tie knows and know how to belay. A great spot.

I began living when I started coming here.I never used some of those muscles in my back, arms, shoulders, and legs! (haha ok so most of my body) I loved the way this place was good for learning teamwork AND being a hot place to take your date! There are a lot of different levels and climbs you can do with the routes that they lay out for you. For $15, you can stay for the whole day and use their gym facilities (weights, cardio machines, showers, etc)Good for all ages.

Enjoyed a short climbing session at Mission Cliffs today. I had to redeem my Groupon before it expired. After 5-6 block walk from 16th St. Mission BART, I signed in and got my waiver filled out quickly and conveniently. Staff was cool and polite. My friend and I were a bit bummed to find out we came in between the first-time belayer class, so we just hung around for an hour. Mission Cliffs is a huge space also with exercise equipment. The treadmills and ellipticals looked fine, but the weight room area had pretty old free weights and machines. The rock walls themselves are awesome with many degrees of difficulty. I wouldn't call the gym immaculately clean, but I wouldn't call it dirty either. They had protein bars, drinks, and other snacks for sale. The shoes and harness I was loaned (in exchange for an ID) were in pretty good condition, but I found my shoes to be a tight 9, so may want to get a size up. When it was time for the first-time class, we were led upstairs to the beginner walls by a really patient staff member who taught us how to prep for climbing, belaying, and tying all the necessary knots. We all got a lot of individual attention, and we were taught 5 safety checks, which made us all feel secure. After, my friend and I had a great time climbing. Bouldering was too hard, but the walls were awesome. Some critiques:-more cubby holes would have been appreciated. I would suggest leaving purses at home. -$30 for a day pass is a bit expensive. Without my 3 day pass Groupon, would probably not want to go too often.

This place is a part of the Touchstone climbing gyms, so deciding to come here wasn't really a choice. I already pay for membership at Ironworks, I might as well use it at every place I have access to.Anyways, this place definitely gets busy after work and sadly doesn't offer the same perks as Ironworks. For example:-Ironworks has loaner chalkbags, Mission Cliffs does not.-Ironworks doesn't charge to rent a ATC, Mission Cliffs does if you didn't rent shoes or a harness.Also, it definitely more difficult to test for your belay certification at Mission Cliffs, as in they are very nitpicky.However though, I much prefer the routes and layout at Mission Cliffs. It isn't as lead climb focused as Ironworks is set up to be, which is nice when you're a beginner like me.

Let me begin by saying this was my very first time climbing... but I already know that it will not be my last. The people who work here and climb here are all very friendly, helpful and did I say friendly. We were only bouldering (which is when you climb a short distance without a rope), and it was pretty crowded. I was told that before 5pm during the week is the best (least crowded) time to climb and at night it get's super crazy. Well as crazy as a rock climbing gym can get, which i also have no frame of reference for. Anyways, LOVED IT, will totally go again and think everyone should try this once. It's an amazing workout, my arms are still burning 24 hours later.

First-time rock climber here. Took the bf with my Groupon and it turned out to be one of our favorite dates (no chocolate, flowers or fancy dinners required, just baggy gym clothes and plentiful wedgies!). The extent of MC's climbing walls and boulders are both intimidating and impressive. John was our funny/patient/all-around awesome instructor and did a great job teaching us everything we needed to know to climb and belay safely and effectively. Once you've taken the class, you never have to again, although there is a safety checks quiz that you have to pass on every subsequent visit to ensure you're not going to fall and crack your head open.Day passes and equipment rental prices are all very reasonable, and there are some traditional exercise machines available on the second floor (eliptical, cycling, etc., though the emphasis here is definitely on climbing). Locker rooms are spacious and there are tons of lockers in which to store your things (bring your own lock). I wish I lived closer because this would be my gym of choice (plusss, great music!).CLIMB ON, my friends!**A word of caution: PARKING IS A NIGHTMARE. It took us half an hour to find a spot 5 blocks away. Unless you have a residential parking permit, street parking is limited to either 1-2 hours, which honestly is crap if you're planning to workout/rock climb. Thursdays must be the absolute worst because it's street cleaning day on half the streets in the area, further compounding the problem. I just wish MC had their own private parking lot.**

Must be because of the new year that this place is so crowded even on a weekday.  I also wish more people would use deodrant.  Still the climbs are pretty cool and it's a good workout climbing up 3 stories after a hard day at work.  The staff is friendly as are the other climbers.  Too bad you can't bring your dogs in anymore though ....Dangerous.

Touchstone Climbing made it very easy for me to fulfill a long-time ambition of learning rock climbing.  It's massive size, in an old warehouse in the Mission, permits a dazzling array of route complexity.  The bouldering area is somewhat smaller than other Touchstone locations, but offers a good range of problem complexity and overhang challenges.The weight training area is geared toward free-weights.  The locker rooms are clean with excellent saunas.

JACKPOT if you can climb before 3pm, it's 12 dollars to climb for as long as you want.the top roping routes ratings are kinda inflated, so I FELT LIKE KING OF THE WORLD climbing some real hard routes. the bouldering routes are very challenging, so i wouldn't recommend a novice trying out the bouldering second level. they do have a pretty good number of 5.5 and 5.6 routes, for people who are just getting startedi rented a harness and brought my own shoes here. the harnesses are kind of gross. i never thought i'd say this, but i missed my dainty primrose harness. everyone here is VERY nice and helpful. this was my first time here, and people were very helpful helping me choose lots of routes and help me get less sweaty on the way up. aside from the rock climbing stuff, they have weight and cardio equipment! that's so great! i really wish this was in chicago, because i'd be super beefy and stronger than hulk hogan (probably tanner than him, too). THEY ALSO SELL JERKY HERE. JUST SAYIN'. if anything makes a me reach near nirvana levels of peace and happiness, it's a triple whammy of climbing, cardio and caca food. THEY EVEN SELL SNICKER BARS. if you aren't into fructose/glucose/gluten/everything i like, they have cliff bars and other protein bars that you can eat!don't forget to bring a lock, if you want to lock your stuff up, but there are plenty of cubbies within eye shod of the wall that you can just leave your stuff laying around. seems like a pretty safe environment.

I enjoy coming here on a Thursday or Friday, climbing for a bit then hitting the city strips. This is a full  Climbing gym, with a small free weight area and an even smaller cardio area. They offer classes as well, such as cross fit, and kick boxing among others. There is also a small shop next to the front desk where you can purchase gear, supplies and snacks. The Gym is quite large, comparable to the Berkeley touchstone location, Iron works. The walls are very high, and set on a fairly consistent basis. I especially enjoy the back corner where the highest walls are, and problems that deal with a lot of stemming and mantling. Anything with features on are great problems in my book. With a wide array of toprope and lead problems, many unique wall structures and features, its really tough to get bored climbing this gym. Their bouldering however lacks a bit. Its too cramped and tucked away upstairs. The quality of the problems presented are top notch, however, the congestion of them tends to detour us die hards. This can be a bit annoying, especially on packed nights where you have to wait in line to attempt a problem, and the constant risk of landing on someone or being landed on poses an unwelcome distraction. Hailing from the east bay, I often climb as much as I can with friends in the city locations, and I like a make a night out of it when I do. Often grabbing lunch or dinner while I'm out there. Mission cliffs is somewhat conveniently located near a lot good eateries and hang outs, mainly mission street, and surrounding areas. But its only a hop, skip and a dyno away from the SOMA and lots of other entertaining locations. Getting to the gym is super easy when taking Bart, and not to far a walk from the 16th st station. Being the most popular climbing gym in the city, it fills up pretty regularly, mainly during the evening, often making parking a hassle. This includes bike parking, as all the railings and outside posts tend to be jam packed with fixed and speeds of all sorts. The staff are great, and very helpful. But don't mistake their kindness with leniency concerning time, as they clear the walls 5 minutes before closing and expect everyone out by the tick of the closing clock hand.

Unfortunately, just because of  one bad service I have to rate this place one star. This guy name Sean who assisted at the front called us "IDIOTS".. Yes idiots!! I don't recall anybody who call me an idiot since I was fifth grade. I confronted him before we left there, his excuse was "Because you guys were slow" He didn't even apologize!! I was very excited to try rock climbing for the first time, but this guy had to ruin our day. A lot of my friends go there, so I really didn't want to say anything bad about this place, but a consequence has to follow for his bad judgement. I would still give some credits for a good instructor name Heather.

So it seems like if you want to take an intro class to climbing in San Francisco, you have only 2 options. So you can't be picky.But even then, my trip to Mission Cliffs was pretty awesome.Went there with a buddy of mine for the 12.30 class. Neither one of us had ever done this.First good surprise, it was only $22 each even though the website says $28. Cool.The guy explaining the basics was pretty cool and did a good job at teaching us basic safety procedures.The place was nice and big enough with enough routes (if that's how they call it) for beginners.It's also cool that they have a weight room and cardio machine if you want to come in for a complete workout.I will definitely be back although I think I won't get a membership but use the day pass option for $12 (plus $5 for the equipment).The only thing is that I would recommend coming in early, as it started getting crowded when we left at 5.30pm.Also I see some reviews complaining about the place being not so clean... isn't climbing supposed to be an outdoor activity? I believe that would be much dirtier... if you want immaculate, just go do pilates at the Sportsclub LA.But then again, I've practiced MMA ground work in tiny, badly ventilated gyms with 10 other sweaty guys, so there is not much that can indispose me anymore :)

First time rock climbing and I had a blast at Mission Cliffs. My $28 went to an hour-long tutorial of how to become Spiderwoman and an all-day pass to climb the walls. Shawn, our instructor, was patient with a person who can't follow spoken directions very well (aka me).After he gave his blessing on me, we were permitted to climb on our own. Wow, those walls are freakin tall. There was a fair amount of climbs for beginners, but there were many for those in the 5.10 and up range. I was a scaredy cat and could only make it half way up before I wanted to come down, but man, every time I'd go up, it'd be a workout! Mission Cliffs is cool because it also serves as a gym, but doesn't smell funky like one. The place is clean and spacious. I had a great time and would be very interested in coming again with my friends.

Hello! This is such a great fitness facility. Free yoga classes, fitness center, and UNREAL climbing walls. I had to put on my stunner stages to take in all of the different climbs. Great variety of moderate to difficult. The staff and members were extremely helpful and experienced. I'm just about ready to tie the knot and sign up for a membership.

I hesitated to rate this place because I hate to admit that I only made it 1/3 of the way up.  Great place.  They were doing a special during Carnaval Street Festival where I got to try 3 climbs with the instructor as my partner for $5 (no equipment rental fee).  Of course there was no need for 3 climbs as my  arms were going to fall off after 2 climbs.
any gym that plays the Juan Maclean on a regular basis is one I will have with my presence

Mission Cliffs is a great gym. The people who work there are really nice and I enjoy climbing there. The membership is a great deal when you factor in the yoga classes.  But if having workout equipment that actually works, having the space to move around without bumping into someone at every turn, or having a place to stretch before or after you work out are things that you value in a gym experience, then I would not join - or even go there - at this particular juncture if I were you.

I've quit... after years of climbing, I'm frustrated by the filth of MC and lack of simple repairs. Example: There has been a mini human-size hole in the back room for over a year. Their solution? Put tape over it instead of replacing the mat.Example: I sliced open my elbow on a wall two summers ago. The blood is still there... yes folks, the climbing walls aren't cleaned.Example: Go to the short routes upstairs, climb to the top and look down at the dust bunnies of chalk and dust that have never been touched. There is one bunny that a partner and I named last year that is still there... he's just gotten fatter!Good bye MC and hope you clean up your act... it's really pretty gross.

Went rock climbing for the first time here a couple weeks ago. My first reaction as soon as I stepped into the gym:Holy fkin shit, these patrons are RIPPED. Their upper body muscles are crazy. Some strong ass bitches here for sure.Okay I always underestimate things until I try them. I tried the boulder area to start off, and damn, it is HARD. Which means.. I'm in dire need of a workout.  Tried the ballay area (with the ropes and stuff) and wow.. Died after doing a few of those sessions.What a workout. I was sore for 3 days.Loads of women (especially lesbians)... Average age groups about 20-30, however I've seen some kids here too.Individual session = $18, but students are about $11, and memberships... If I remember correctly is like $50+, but don't quote me on that part.The surrounding areas are pretty much in a bad neighborhood, from what I saw, but whatever, I'm not the one who's driving...and perhaps getting my radio snatched out of my car...Anyway it's an awesome gym. Definitely recommended.
Great gym with a ton of climbing for everyone. Beginners have a lot of easy top rope and boulder problems and the more experienced climbers have tons of top rope and lead climbing to do

I love MC and work out here everyday! My only complaint is that they are closed an excessive amount during the holidays. For those of us who work out in the mornings before work, they were closed the days before AND after Thanksgiving, plus Xmas Eve and NY Eve -- with no discount or compensation to those of us who pay $70/month for membership. Also, on weekends, kids can be a problem, and staff doesn't do much to discipline parents who let them run around or play in the bouldering area. Otherwise, great gym, good selection of cardio equipment (although the weight area is very small), and nice variety of routes and difficulty levels.

I used to be quite neat indoor climbing aficionado. My ex girlfriend was really into climbing and so that kinda meant that i was too.  I went to Mission cliffs multiple times and I usually enjoyed myself. They have a series of climbing walls of different levels like all indoor climbing facilities.  they start at about 5.2 which is pretty much like climbing a ladder and they go up to about 5.12 which is like climbing the Empire State building (or something very difficult). The key thing about climbing is that you're not supposed to use your hands that much.  using too much arm strength will wear you out well before you get half way up. This is why women sometimes can be very good at indoor climbing. Because they instinctively don't try to pull themselves up with their arms whereas men try to continually do pull-ups and basically end up exhausting themselves immediatelyyou get in a pretty good workout and it's interesting.  not repetitive like riding a bike or swimming and there's a sense of accomplishment involved.  it's not boring.  there is some strategy, as well as you need to plan most of your ascents.  technique is, of course, important if you don't want to wear yourself out.  plus it's kinda social since you have to do it in pairs and you better trust that other person so they won't drop you!

I used to come here around twice a week in high school! Wow i was buff then hah. The walls are amazing and the place is so big. The second floor consists of all the bouldering walls and some gym machines. You can park your bike inside the first floor, the restrooms/locker rooms kept neat, and all the amazing walls.  They have a long rope you can climb for those who want to re-live their high school gym experiences and make it to the top.If you're a first timer...-You can buy your chalk, clothes, and etc here.-You may rent your shoes, harness, and what not-They'll teach you how to belay and lock yourself in if you have no clue what you're doing.-If you come in often and you pass the test enough times that they recognize you, you can get a laminated card allowing you to climb walls without supervision (oOoooOo)-Bring your own water and food and snacks. They sell the typical gatorade and power bars but it's easier and cheaper to just bring in your own trail mix if you're feeling weak and in need of some energy*I had my 5th grade birthday party here! I got to bring in about 5 or so friends and an instructor helped us the whole time :) It was pre-arranged and really fun. This is a great idea for a small birthday party activity, i'll never forget it and i'm sure another little kid would enjoy it and remember it just as much as i do!

So much fun!The four of us went to Mission Cliffs for the first time after purchasing a Groupon for intro to climbing. $25 for two people (normally $28/person) includes all necessary rental equipment,  an hour class and climbing for as long as you want afterwards. Our class was at 7:30pm and instructions ended about an our later. We went on our own afterwards and tried different cliffs to climb. I wish we had more time because they closed at 10pm, giving us only an hour and a half to play.I will definitely go back with my friends some other day. I believe it's $12 to climb for the weekdays. Check out their website for their schedule for classes and their open hours. If it's your first time, pick an earlier intro class so you have more time to climb afterwards. The only cons were that right when you go inside, you smell sweat. And there's plenty of people walking around barefooted. Yuck.

I've been here many times for Spin (Indoor biking) classes.  I really like this place because they don't make you join, you can just pay $15 when you want to take a class.  On another note a lot of time this place smells like BO.  I just wish they would spray something at the end of the day or something.  Also the Spin classes are just OK compared with others I've been to.  Sometimes the bikes don't work and have issues but I do get a good workout there.  One time an instructor didn't show and we still worked out but they refunded my money.  They do have good customer service.  There are a few things they could work on but I'm not there to climb and the spin classes aren't their main source of income.  Happy that it's only a block from my house as well :)

Scaling a 40 foot vertical wall is an adrenaline pump and great mental exercise.  There's a cool group of climbers that meet on Wednedsays 7pm by the Foosball table. the name of the group is Bay Area Rock Climbing, for more information, logon to meetup.com and search for this meetup group in San Francisco.  I like climbing here: low key vibe, friendly people, small weight room, uncrowded cardio area, boxing aerobics and spinning is available. Easy parking.

I was just on a stroll in the neighborhood one day with my boyfriend, showing off the area, when we stumbled upon this place. I had driven by it many times before, but never had time to go in. My boyfriend is an avid climber and wanted to check out the digs. This place ROCKS. (no pun intended). Everyone was so nice in there! The employees were more than happy to talk to us about the history of the building, the company, and why they loved working there. One of people who were climbing even let my boyfriend put on their harness and try out the wall. How cool is that?! Bottom line: If I still lived in the area I would for sure have a membership here.

I'll be editing my review after I've been a few more times, but upon my first visit to Mission Cliffs, I have to say, I'm pretty impressed. The top rope and lead walls are super tall--much higher than anywhere I've climbed indoors on the East Coast, and the route setting is excellent. These guys are no amateurs. The gym also has standard fitness equipment, yoga and cycling classes, saunas, showers, and (YES!) towel service. And to top off the awesome, their membership rates are super reasonable. As of right now, Mission Cliffs loses a star because the bouldering area is very small in comparison to the rest of the gym. On a Sunday afternoon, it was almost dangerously crowded.

I've been a member here since June and for the most part I'm really happy with it.  I'm not going to compare it to any other climbing gyms in the area (because I haven't been to any of them), but I will say:In addition to the dedicated climbing wall and bouldering areas, they have some really solid classes. The cardio boxing class is great, and the yoga seems really legit. These are classes geared towards climbers/people already in shape, so it's a better work-out than you would get at a standard gym.They place new bouldering routes pretty often. BUT top-roping leaves a little bit to be desired if you go pretty regularly. Showers + sauna etc. are clean and well maintained. Central location AND easy to find parking nearby.It gets really crowded weeknights. If you go during non-peak times, it's a lot better, but then you run the risk of them placing new routes and having entire bouldering or top roping sections closed off. I was charged a late fee once because my credit card had been cancelled and I didn't get a chance to update the info with MC before the auto-payment attempt. They didn't really inform me of this until the next time I showed up to MC, which seemed odd to me. I will say that the membership fee is a little steep if you don't plan on going at least 1-2 times/week. If you take advantage of the day pass (weekdays before 3pm), it's $12 ... and 5 visits a month ($60) comes out cheaper than the monthly membership fee ($67). Something to consider, and then you're not tied to a particular gym either.Also for climbing newbs, remember to bring socks if renting shoes! And if you don't have a top-roping partner, you can always go to the front desk and they'll make an announcement on your behalf. There are also plenty of beginner routes.

I have been climbing here for too long to remember when I began, but it was soon after they opened in '95.  I have also climbed at Berkeley Iron Works in the same Touchstone system.  IW is a larger space and has a larger variety of work out equipment and options.  IW walls are predominately overhanging.MC and IW both have some impressive, interesting walls.  MC's back room is better for smearing.MC does have a lot of techies and hipsters, but there are also a lot of die hard climbers just doing their thing.  They are clearly trying to provide a service that works for a variety of users.I am  not sure why some people say they are not clean, as there is a very sweet guy cleaning all the time every time I go.  I believe he works at least 40 hrs. a week cleaning and polishing non-stop.  I have never seen anything that looked remotely dirty and I am a clean nut according to some people (who are slobs).  Most facilities just have janitorial staff come in for a few hours every day, and not a full time dedicated cleaning person.Probably near closing it does get messed up, as he is not cleaning every minute of every hour they are open.  I am sure he is very bugged that anyone would think his gym is not clean, as no one could be more dedicated to their job.  The staff is overall very nice and helpful.  The fees are more than I like, but that includes all the regular classes like yoga and kick boxing. There is a simple weight area, cardo areas, bouldering area and sauna.  The fees also allow you to go to any of the Touchstone gyms and there are a lot of them in N.Cal.  I consider the fees part of my health care costs.  Climbing is addictive, in a good way.In my dream climbing gym there would be a hot tub...  ;-)  Hint, hintIf you have a teen and want them to be able to have some adventure (without having to bail them out) and build self esteem that will stay with them, I would suggest trying climbing.
Nice family gym great vibes

So I went back and finally got a belay card. Too little too late - I still can't in good conscience recommend Mission Cliffs to anyone on Yelp. The waits are insane, the lifting facilities are hyper limited and people tend to get up in your grill, and for a drop-in I don't think folks would have a good experience. On the other hand if you're willing to go at off hours and go through their bull, and you live nearby so the time investment will be worth it, and you're willing to go during off-hours when it's not jammed, though even during those hours the gym is jammed, so let's also suppose you don't care about lifting, then Mission Cliffs is a fun place to be.

This place is scary if one comes here for the first time without people with experience. The first time I came here it was with a couple friends and it was pretty fun. My arms were burning from the climb and I even had trouble picking up a cup or anything heavy afterward. The second time I came was more of a rush since I was only here for maybe a couple hours. This time I was smart enough to use my legs to push myself towards the next peg. Overall experience is fun. Just need to go here with friends that are willing to take a challenge.

Adam, at Mission Cliffs, is SUPER nice! Extremely helpful and friendly.My friend forced us to come here and I'm so glad he did. This place is super spacious and the people are friendly. You get some of those snooty "I'm so good, I should be climbing on REAL cliffs" types -  yea? well why don't you.On the other hand, some people are really nice. If you happen to get stuck on a route, some people will yell out where to go and suggestions.I haven't been in awhile but I'd like to go regularly and this place is perfect. Close, lots of parking and helpful staff. I think the routes change too!I can only get in 3 climbs so the prices are pretty expensive (I have to get shoes) but I'd like to own my own stuff some day.My biggest, biggest gripe is that I see a lot of people walk around barefoot - straight up nasty. I feel so dirty after I climb here and it's not just the sweat!

I've been told I climb walls like a monkey so it was inevitable I try Mission Cliffs at some point in my life. My sister was the bestest and hooked it up with an Intro to Climbing class with Adam. He was patient, kind, friendly, and extremely knowledgeable. Then again, I would hope a certified instructor would teach us well since my entire body is hanging in a harness and a long rope! The class was small (only 4 of us on a Friday afternoon). We learned the basics of climbing and all the safety checks involved. We learned about tying figure 8 knots, being a belayer (basically, the individual on the ground that creates tension for the climber), and how the climber and belayer communicate with each other. The experience reinforced how communication is key. I found myself making indoor rock climbing/outdoor rock climbing analogous to life. It's definitely a new found love, for sure. If you don't feel like scaling walls, you can also work out on the cardio machines, take classes (if you become a member), and/or bouldering which is learning how to climb laterally. I wouldn't go suggesting this as a first time date or group activity though. It's a fantastic activity if you're needing some bonding time with people really close to you. It was such a great experience with my sister and reminded us that constant and clear communication is important! Most importantly, climbing is pretty meditative, believe it or not. It's just you and the wall and problem solving with your body. Come on, now! What more can you ask for...also, if you keep climbing, imagine how flexible and in shape you would be. Ummm, I'm pretty sure nobody would complain. :)

I can't believe I never wrote a review for Mission Cliffs.  Its like my second home now, well not really, but I'm here quite a few days a week. Started climbing last summer and have loved it ever since..  my strength, endurance and confidence has definitely improve since I started, and I like how there's always a new challenge since they change the walls every 2-3 months. The yoga classes are also great, as I've been going about 3x a week now and feel SO much more flexible now.  it definitely helps with the climbing, as it helps open up places that are tight, especially the hips and shoulders. The instructors' classes I really enjoy are Jody & Kate (vinyasa flow) and Elyse (ashtanga), Tania might not teach here anymore but I use to enjoy her classes as well. sometimes certain classes at popular times/teachers gets a little crowded, but still worth going and always still gets me working up a sweat.  The crowd here is mainly young, probably mid/late 20's-early 30's, especially on weeknights from 5-8pm. and it could get a little crowded.. but makes it interesting and inspiring when you can see what some people are capable of doing! during the day its a little more random and kids have field trips here, which can be cute. if you are new/ don't have a membership, I'd recommend coming during the day time as its cheaper AND less crowded and stressful -you can take all the time you want and have most walls free to yourself.

It's a climbing gym, clear and simple. If you want to be surround by hipsters bouldering in jeans and no shirts, then this is probably the place for you.Major complaints: it always smells like old dirty man sweat, and there are way too many routes set on a wall, and still way too many people trying to climb those routes.Why go here: Well there are only two options in the city and this one is closer to where I live.

Pros- Gym has plans to expand, They use ATC devices, Variety of routesCons- Staff Belay Testers, Routes over rated +1, ParkingI've been a climber for over a decade. I love Indoor, outdoor, bouldering, lead, trad, ice or any other type of climbing. The majority of my experience is indoor and I try to climb at least 3 times a week. So you can image my joy in finding a gym right next to my new job in San Fran. On the Pro side signing up for / into the gym was easy. They have a few self service computers where new comers can quickly enter their info and sign the waver. Once in, the routes are creative and with the difficulty variety there is plenty for everyone no matter what the skill level. I am also a proponent of the ATC friction device over the Grigri and its the choice of mission cliffs as well. While you cant take your hands off the rope to high-five anyone and still catch your buddy falling off the wall (like you can with a Grigri) it does offer more control and less friction taking out the slack while belaying an ascending climber. Now to the Cons. Parking, yeah its the city but still it should be said that if you drive, you may have issues. Veteran climbers may find the route difficulties slightly sandbagged. Great for making you feel like superwo/man but you'll constantly second guess your choices until you adjust to the new norm. The biggest con of all is the belay test. As a veteran climber who's been to gyms all over the country I've had to take my share of belay tests. I've even administered them but I always feel self conscious when I'm and never want to take them. However, I've never have I felt like the person giving the test felt the same way. The test started with one person who asked me to tie in. Typical 'show me your knots' stuff. Once done he asked me to tie into belay and promptly walked off. About 5 minutes go by before another staff person walks over and tests me on my belay technique. She tells me I failed but get a day pass. When I ask why she says "I dont know, I'm just difficult". When I ask her to tell me where I went wrong because I want to be a safe belayer she tells me "You did everything right and your confident, dont worry about it. Here is your day pass. You can retest the next time you come in." I was with a group of people so I didnt want to argue.  When I shared my experience with my friends they all told me that it wasn't unique. Climbing should be fun and safe. This test was neither.
Excellent instructor; great staff.A good mix of climbs with enough challenge for different skill levels.$18 day pass + $5 shoes and gear

I run a youth group, and today I took 4 of my teenagers here for an event. 3 of them had taken belaying classes before, and were kind enough to take some time and teach the 4th person, so they paired off. When I came in, I was magically struck by the inability to speak in complete sentences, but the person behind the desk was really patient with me and not in any way phased (despite the fact that I appeared to be mentally challenged). I was able to just sit down on some (very uncomfortable) metal bleachers to keep an eye on my teens. The place is gigantic but designed in a way that is parent-friendly, because you can see almost everything going on with the rock walls from one place. There are people there of all ages.This places seems like it would be Hipster Mecca. Not only does it have a belaying area and a bouldering area, but it comes complete with a gym and yoga classes. You'd think you could feel the pretentious energy zipping through the air. But you'd think wrong! Everyone here had a really positive, laid-back vibe. I didn't smell one single iota of hipster condescension. My kids and I both had a great time here. It's affordable and you feel good while you're here. The atmosphere breeds a sense of companionship and teamwork. I can't wait to bring my kids again. :)

I'm happy to be a member at mission cliffs and climb here 2-3 times a week but there's some things they could improve.First, the good. The routes are terrific and there's a frequent rotation of new stuff, to the tune of 50-150 routes no older than 2 weeks at any given time. As a member, the free monthly guest pass is a great way to introduce the unsure to climbing. The other climbers also are friendly and helpful, and patient with those who are new to climbing and might not have a handle on gym etiquette. Ok, so what could be better? For one, they need to be more judicious about changing out ropes that are beginning to wear. I never felt unsafe, but it's hard to ignore the psychological effects of tying into fuzzy ropes that look like they've been chewed on, especially when you're just starting out. Second, when they raise their rates, they need to broadcast it as loudly as when they change their safety policies. It's not cool to find this out by checking a credit card statement; it just feels sneaky.It gets crowded weekday nights too, but if you go in the morning you have the place all to yourself.

It was my first time.  And I freakin' loved it.I had only heard good things about Mission Cliffs for climbing, but when my friend, who was experienced in bouldering, was in town, he suggested we try that.  Not knowing the difference, but always up for a new sport (i.e. a new way to destroy my body), I was eager to give it a try.The routes, or "problems" as they're called, were pretty challenging, but they had a variety of good ones for beginners.  The cool thing is, there is a weights and a cardio section, so if you need to take a rest or a break for a bit, you can always go back to the wall.  I found this extremely helpful since I wasn't used to using my forearms or hand muscles so much--especially to pull my whole body weight up a wall!What really stood out in my mind was that the people there were super friendly and helpful.  Even though it was my first time, I totally felt at ease and not self conscious (well, as much as you could for doing anything physically challenging and new).  Also, I didn't feel intimidated or weak for being a woman--I saw a lot of women kicking ass up on those walls!Make sure you spend the extra few bucks to get chalk and tape for your hands--WELL worth it to prevent blisters!I was "rocking" a good soreness for 2 days after, but it was well worth it.  Hurts so good!  Can't wait to check it out again!

I've only been rock climbing once down in SoCal, and this was my second try.  Valentine's Day.  The introductory lesson is $28 for non-members, but my boyfriend and I had gotten a Groupon for $25 that included the intro lesson for two people. What a great deal!REMEMBER, make a reservation otherwise you'll end up arriving in between lessons and having to come back a different day.  There are three lessons each day. The instructor John was very informative and extremely patient.  He was able to clearly explain exactly what we had to do to both climb and belay.  His instructions left nothing to question.The intro lesson was about 1 hour, it might be longer depending on how many students there are.  There were 4 students in my lesson.The gym itself is relatively clean.  The facility boasts a 5-story wall with double overhangs and numerous climbing routes for both the beginner and advanced climber.  If you choose to boulder, that is also an option.  I left feeling like I could definitely pass the belay test the next time I visit (you have to prove each time that you still remember how to belay and how to keep a climber from falling off the wall.)Shoe and harness rentals total $5.  You are not allowed to wear your regular gym shoes.  Climbing shoes seem to be required.
I'm a member here and love coming. I've been coming since 2009.  Everyone is awesome...helpful...nice...knowledgeable...and i just love the gym.  Glad Michael is back.
by far the best climbing gym in the bay area i enjoyed every minute that i spent therehighly recommend this place to all that is interested in this kind of sport its fun.

Awesome gym! I still don't really get the numbering system but can figure which climbs I can and can't do. It's an awesome facility with friendly staff. I even liked the locker room and restroom. It also doesn't smell as bad as some say. I've visited planet granite before and it is closer to where I live but mission cliffs is worth the trip. They offer bouldering, weights, regular gym and yoga classes. Only bad side is parking, totally sucks. Still, would definately go back to get my climb on!

I never rock climbed indoor or outdoor before so I was kind of nervous going into this. They have a class for those, like myself, that have never done this before. They explain the basics of belaying and get yourself prepared when it's your turn to climb. The instructor we had, Adam, was friendly and thorough on explaining the basics of how to set up the harness and climbing equipment. I was surprised how patient he was even when he had to explain some stuff to me because I didn't understand it at first. Once that class was through I powered up the short climbs like I was Spiderman. Then I wanted to try out the more vertical climbs. That was quite an experience. The first time I did it wrong because I was using all the colored grips. You're only supposed to grip on the yellow grips if that's path you chose, for example.

I start this review with one disclaimer: 1. This is my first review...so be gentle I have memberships at both PG and Touchstone and I have to say in terms of climbing Touchstone (Mission Cliffs) is far superior than PG. The main reason? The routes. Going to M/C will make you a better, stronger climber. The routes not only require you to work on your technique but the routes will improve your overall strength and endurance. Most of the Mission Cliffs' Community are climbers, serious about the sport. I find that PG attracts more the of causal "hey climbing is the new hip in thing to do " crowd. Don't get me wrong PG a great place to learn how to climb but if you are serious about the sport and want to be around the climbing community then M/C is the place to be. The Good: Membership rates: $67.00 (this includes access to the other Touchstone gyms in Concord, Berkeley, Oakland and Sacto), climbing: routes are challenging, great lead climbs and I wouldn't know about bouldering.The Bad: Gets packed at nights, I recommend the weekends or early mornings. The ugly: The Lead climbing and belay certification test is significantly harder than PG. At PG you can test on any route that allows for lead. At M/C they test you on a 10b or higher.

I've seen my share of climbing gyms and this place has it all: top roping, lead climbing, huge walls and big windows with natural light make it feel (close ;) ) to being outside, a great bouldering area, and weights and machines so you can use this like a regular gym.  There's a sauna, and a great vietnamese restaurant across the street.  The only downside is it's a bit busy in the evenings and on the weekends, and it can be a bit fast-paced.  So if you want to go a gym to hang out and have a few laughs, relax climb and meet some climbing road trip buddies, go there during the day :)

This place completely doesn't suck.I was lucky enough to learn the basics of rock climbing and belaying here with my friend BJ.The staff was super helpful and mostly friendly.  I really like how they test your knowledge about being safe - you have to get it right, but they're not mean about it if you don't.  It's all being done for the "right" reasons.I am totally considering ditching my gym membership and joining the climbing wall place in my 'hood (similar to Mission Cliffs) thanks to my great experience here.  Thanks MC - you guys rule!

New to climbing and Mission Cliffs welcomed me with open arms. I took the one hour beginner class and the instructor was really cool-patient, funny and kind. The bouldering area is great and I can't wait to try out the classes and everything else this place has to offer, which I will do because now I am an official member-boo-yah!

I've climbed at every major gym California, and Mission Cliffs hands down has the worst staff of any climbing gym I've been to. Most of the staff members give off extremely negative energy and act inconvenienced when you ask for help.  Worse - last time I was there, I witnessed a staff member bully a new climber with advice that was actually unsafe for the belay device she was using! Where do they find these people?I haven't experienced this problem at other Touchstone gyms. Seems to me like a change of management is needed at this particular gym, because supervisors are overlooking very poor behavior.
Came with a friend to climb and check out the gym. I had a good time but there was  ALOT Of people.  If it had less people, I would join the gym.

This is my regular climbing gym and I don't think I could have found a better fit. I live a quick 25 minute bus ride away (very convenient route actually) and have completely worked it into my weekly routine, going a few times a week before work -- which is doable because of how accessible the gym is!The staff is helpful and friendly; I'm pretty sure they started recognizing me after only a few weeks. I have to give a lot of credit to the climbers who set their routes too. I started at Mission Cliffs as an absolute beginner, and working up from the easiest routes has forced me to learn good technique. A route will sometimes frustrate me (I often use the excuse that I'm too short), but it seems like that's when the route is trying to teach me a new technique.They have some weights and treadmills too. I've never used the treadmills, but have used the weights on occasion. They're nothing fancy, but that's generally what I'm looking for.If you're looking for a climbing gym to go to regularly in San Francisco, this is easily my top choice.

I'm a huuuge rock climbing fan now, and perhaps my review is a bit harsher just because I'm not just a 1-timer wowed by rock climbing in general.MC is awesome.  The vibe here is perfectly mission -esque with friendly people and a great atmosphere. The pluses:First timers will love it... hey cause everybody loves to climb rockThey have some really high walls to test your endurance and your ability to consistently do difficult movesThe the difficulty range here is nice, with plenty for everyone from 5.9 up to 5.12d.  I notice that there's a bit of sparcity in the 13's on, but more htan i've seen at other gymsBouldering is fun (though a bit limited).Cons:crowded... man there's alot of people here.  It's always tough to get the climb you really want.  Definately don't be shy and always ask "hey you guys switching off on that rope?"The climbs are graded pretty friendly here.  Over at PG I can climb 10a strong and dabble in the 10b/c range.  Here I'm hitting all the 10B most Cs and got a 10d under my belt!the leadclimbers here tend to be really uppity about how good they are... get over it and let me learn!All in all i love the place, and if it were only a little less crowded I'd probably be a member (instead of a 10-pass holder)

Great way to spend an afternoon!If you get in before 3pm it's $12 to climb ($17 if you need a harness and shoes). You have to pass a test to say you know what you're doing with the ropes (my friend gave me a quick refresher before I took mine!) and then you're off and away! I love the way they have it organized by routes, which is totally different to the wall I used to go to at home - here they use different colours to denote the difficulty, cramming a ton of different routes into the space. There's overhangs and whatnot too if you fancy a challenge! Climbing is a great activity to do with people of different levels of skill/fitness - you can choose the level of difficulty you want and everyone has a great time! There's also a sauna to relax those post-climbing muscles in.....

Mission Cliffs is a smallish rock climbing location, with a fair number of climbs but significantly less large than Planet Granite Belmont and Sunnyvale.  Routes are extremely inflated, a 5.9 at Mission Cliffs is more like a 5.8. The gym is has the equipment needed for the Olympic lifts, but can't handle a significant flow of people.  Overall, the staff is unbelievably rude.  Like the stereotype of how French waiters treat Americans.

It's all right for the money and there are many different levels of walls/climbs. I went on a weekday evening, and it felt like I was in a cage with hundreds of chimpanzees. Caution: with that many chimps in one spot, it tends to smell like a zoo as well. I did, however, surprise myself because I made it all the way to the top and then back down and then back up and then back down and then back up again without falling or needing to have myself hoisted down by my more experienced belay partner.I like heights, I like hot men; and this gym has plenty of both. I wish my gym had walls like the ones at MC. They're super fun, and brings out the primate in me.

First off, I love the folks behind the desk, they're all fabulous, a special shout out to Daniel and Steve my boys. I've been going here for about 3 years now. Things I like:1. They change the boulder routes routinely, love that.2. The staff is very helpful and friendly3. They're open till 11pm Tuesdays and Thursdays4. Other climbers here are friends and cool5. They have great yoga, spinning, and boxing classes during the week.Now for the not so good... Since Mission Cliffs has a pretty much monopoly on climbing gyms in San Francisco they really have let themselves go. This is why competition is so important! Here's a list of gripes, all solvable I might add:1. Workout equipment is from circa 1995. Especially the cardio machines.2. If you boulder on a weekday 5-9pm someone will fall on you or come very close to falling on you. 3. The crash mattresses are mega old and nasty4. The locker room looks like it's from right from my old high school roman showers and all.5. When I would workout in the morning the cleaning dude would always mop right when I got there, I love bleach fumes in the morning, must say it's hard to resist.Seriously, if MC weren't 3 blocks from my house I would go somewhere else. MC having janky equipment isn't cool.

I've only been here to boulder on a few of the too-far-in-between occasions that I've gone up to San Francisco in the last year, but even on those experiences, I must say MC is a great climbing gym with plenty of character...Coming in off the street, you'll either first notice one of the following: 1) the monumental main wall (with the notably steeped base) that stands high, extending beyond the i-beams that constitute the ceiling of the warehouse, or 2) the multi-floored layout with the bouldering section and some top-rope routes elevated on an indoor mezzanine.(OR you might notice the huge crossbeam and crane overhead, hearkening to when the building was probably part of SF's industrial history. I'm kind of a geek, I know.)One of the impressive features of the gym's offerings is the multitude of contours and architecture (man-made rock formations: is that still architecture?!).  Many top-rope climbs/routes look like they involve some traversal of buttresses, cracks, or transitions from slabs to steeps; few strictly vertical climbs.  Also, for the hardcore, there is an ominous archway for lead climbers...For my taste, the bouldering area here is excellent, in both the variety and challenge, as well as the friendly attitude and encouragement from other climbers/enthusiasts/strangers.  The lower overall height of the bouldering area here, IMO, is more than compensated for with intense, dynamic and fun climbs, testing technique and strength in tandem to a high degree...  Satifying when completed, frustrating when failed, but all the while, its not uncommon to be cheerlead'd by friendly looker-ons.On yet another positive note for safety sticklers (and you should be, shouldn't you?), getting the [permanent] belay card here is a task, as the staff closely critiques everything from technique to tie-ins.  If any part is shy of perfect, you only get a temporary/day belay card; I've YET to get my [permanent] card after three attmempts.  That level of mindfulness is awesome!!All in all, an awesome facility, staff, and patronage...(and goodness, there are pretty PRETTY people here! YAY!)_________________________________________Best part of tweeting that I'd been here?Darling Jaye C. replying exuberantly "Kevin Rose climbs there!"

DO NOT GO TO MISSION CLIFFS AND RENT THEIR EQUIPMENT. YOU MAY BE RISKING YOUR LIFE.Everyone who climbs or wants to climb at Mission Cliffs should read this. I went with my boyfriend, who climbs there, on Monday, 1/19, and rented one of their harnesses. When I got to the top of one of the routes the strap on my right leg came apart. I was freaking out and didn't know what to do. My boyfriend was on belay and in that timeframe, there was no one at Mission Cliffs to help. Luckily (I was very lucky then), there was an experienced climber who got to the top and strapped me in again. I came down, shaken. I can't believe this happened. My bf and I check our harnesses and configuration before every climb. I had also gone through the climb and belay test just 20 minutes earlier and knew the drill. When we took the harness to the front desk, the guy there examined it and saw that the clasp on the right leg was broken and separated from the belt. And that was it. He took it in, no apologies, no calls to the manager, nothing. If this is the kind of gym you want to go, you better think twice. If they don't even check the equipment they rent out (which is extremely old), what other safety measures do you think they exclude on a daily basis?This was by far one of the scariest experiences I have ever gone through. You can be sure that I will never go to Mission Cliffs again.

Mission Cliffs has done some very recent updating and beautifying.  Very nice, MC!  And the staff is still fabulous and friendly, for the most part.My only complaint is the crowded condition, of late.  Though the gym has been crowded in the past, it seemed to be full of people who knew the unspoken rules of climbing etiquette.  In my opinion, Mission Cliffs needs to put up a sign of Climbing Etiquette 101.  If you don't tell the newbies, how will they know?Bert M's suggestions for that list:1) Don't start climbing something directly under or next to someone else. This not only messes up his/her concentration, but also can be very dangerous if the person falls off, kicking you in the head in the process. Give that person a little head start if he/she was there first.(Climbing "through" someone is the equivalent of seeing people waiting in line at the bank and just butting in at the beginning of the line while stepping on everyone's feet on the way past.)2) Don't constantly yell "helpful" instructions at the person you're belaying.  It annoys your partner, as well as everyone else within earshot.(Yelling instruction is the equivalent of picking your nose in an office meeting, then announcing to everyone that you got it and wiping it on your sock.)3) Don't let your children run rampant and unsupervised.  This is dangerous for them and the other climbers.  It's also very loud.  Inside voices please.(Letting your children run around willy-nilly as though they're in an amusement park is the equivalent of... well, letting your children run around willy-nilly anywhere else in the world that isn't an amusement park.)I love that so many new people want to check out climbing!  And, I think people are willing to follow social rules if they know what they are.  Hey MC, how about filling people in when they arrive for their first try at climbing?

This place rocks, no pun intended. Rock climbing virgin no more thanks to mission cliffs. Took the required beginner intro class my first time around then stuck around with my friends. We were also able to have lunch at a nearby mexican dive and come back. In and out privileges are pretty awesome. Yay for...the variety of courses, the boulders, friendliness and helpfulness of staff, clean lockers, the vast number of restaurants in the areaNay for...the crowdedness it gets on the evenings and the weekends, the scary walk from the BART station (how many crackheads did I pass? Dunno..lost count), the run-down workout room (often times the treadmill is broken and the equipment needs to get updated.)3 and a half stars.

For years I've wanted to join a rock climbing gym but kept putting it off since I was already going to the boxing gym. However, I finally decided to give it a go when my co-worker told me he had a free pass I could use. So I went, took the little belayers test thing, and off I went. Awesomeness on a cliff.It was harder than I thought it would be, and strange enough, easier than I thought it would be. I don't have much trouble doing pullups so I figured I'd climb these walls like it was no thang. I was wrong. Started on a 5.9 and it kicked my ass about 3/4 of the way up. After completing it and moving to a 5.10a I figured it would be much harder. But after applying some of the techniques I learned from climbing the 5.9 I found I made it up the 5.10a no problem. Then I tried a 5.10b and got my ass kicked again, hah. Regardless of the ass kicking I was always having fun and felt like I was learning something each time I went up. Bonus for it being back-friendly. I hurt my lower-back earlier this year so was concerned that the climbing might aggravate it but found it actually helped. After each climbing session my back is worked but relaxed.Aside from the main walls, there is also a bouldering area where you don't need a partner. Cool thing about the bouldering is that everyone is ready to help each other. People who don't know each other are often asking or giving advice or discussing how to tackle one of the routes. So while you don't have a partner in the bouldering area it's actually a lot more social and friendly (though the belaying area is also friendly).Next to the bouldering you have treadmills and other cardio equipment. Downstairs is a small free weight and machine area. There is a studio for Yoga and other classes. The bathroom has lockers, showers, and a sauna. The front area has a spot where you can lock your bikes or leash your pet. They also carry all the climbing gear you need and if you buy a certain amount (I THINK over $70.00) you get a 10% discount. If I remember correctly, renting the gear is about $5. Oh yeah, there's a foosball table, PC for general net access, and free wifi. With all that, the monthly membership ($60) is well worth it imo. So much so that I signed up on the spot after I used my co-workers guest pass and have been going ever since. Now a bunch of my friends are clamoring for use of my free guest passes.

Wahwahweewah.  I have never in my life seen such a gigantic climbing gym.  My boyfriend's brother Javi is an avid climber, climbing at the very least once a week.   So upon his visit  to San Francisco we felt compelled to take him to the promised land.  As soon as we stepped into Mission Cliffs he was speechless and he couldn't wait to get climbing.  Unfortunately my two friends and I are rookies. So Javi was kind enough to show us the ropes (pun intended) before we got started.  The gym is great for beginners and experts alike.  I was scared shitless going up the "bunny" wall, while I watched the pros jumping around on the more advance walls with ease.  Even if you aren't into climbing it is really incredible just to go watch.  And you can do that for free. yaya, my favo.

It was my first time here, i was really excited, but somewhat ending to be disappointed b/c my instructor was not very patience with me...  Yes Yes, as in all people, there are some who are not as brillant, yes, that is describing me... I'm a slow learner...  (SO WHAT!!) It just takes more to practice... chellow!! So somewhat disapointed, just cuz your a pro, doesn't mean you can look down on ppl, and be impatient.But, I eventually got it, and ha, I climbed, and HA! I can beLAY! THank you, to my good friend who helped me out, NOT the instructor, don't deserve my $5, in which I can't hear you half the time! BOOAlso, I don't think they regulate how many people come in, and there can be long lines at times... too crowded..

I'm addicted to climbing... been going to MC several times a week since 2005. I've also been to Ironworks in Berkeley, TS in SJ, the new GWPC downtown 510 and other climbing gyms in the BA, on the West Coast and Europe... so plenty of perspectives. MC rocks! but...I did not select 5 stars because MC is plainly exploiting their monopoly in the city and this has become just painful.  I'm surprised that only 5 people have rated this place 3 stars & under. Some reviews actually only depict poor personal experiences and do not constitute objective criticism but most reviews, even those with high ratings, already report what I'm about to say but still, MC gets 4 or 5 stars, thus my previous statement: MC gets a great average simply because Yelpers love climbing in the city, not because of the gym itself.The amount of people on Tue, Wed and Thur nights goes beyond my mind: it's impossible to find a route, people literally climb and even fall on each others.An outdoor terrace on a warm sunny day with free beer wouldn't be any more crowded!The air quality is terrible; look at all the floating chalk in a ray of light or at the amount of dust on beams and furniture!  The air temperature is always off, way too cold or hot, fans are ridiculous and loud, thank god the poor staff members have an overhead heater.  The painting and lighting is so depressing and dark that I forbid myself to get inside on nice and sunny days.And it's funny how people line up for yoga classes, ending up exercising face-first in their neighbor's sweaty ass.Half the basic plywood hand-made lockers are damaged and boy! does that room smell like decaying sweaty old socks! Floors are simply bare concrete... I mean, I can appreciate the overall natural touch, but it should really not be complicated to upkeep the place.Why did TS feel the need to build a new tiny-ass gym in the EB where it already has so much to do to improve its flagship?Please! for the love of the sport, install air purifiers and reversible air conditioning, remodel these locker rooms and demolish some walls to let the sunlight come in!!I'm not sure what can be done about the crowd but Planet Granite is about to open an impressive spanking new climbing gym, with massive glass walls, just off of gorgeous Crissy Field and I'm pretty sure people aren't gonna stay faithful to TS very long.MC's patrons are just too much in love with climbing and surprisingly way too complacent to pressure management. I hope this review and the introduction of PG's new gym will change the deal.5/1/09 UPDATE:  I went back to MC a couple of weeks ago and it was awesome!   They clearly have listened to our remarks on Yelp and improved the facilities:  new lockers and remodeled locker room, new refreshing painting, an entirely new window-panel-wall in the back... Great, yyiiiieeahhh!

Mission Cliffs may have more climbing walls and the bouldering area upstairs might be a little bigger but the cardio, weight machine and free weights areas are significantly smaller and more cramped than Ironworks in Berkeley.  Since I use the facilities mostly for the gym, I wish there were more cardio machines that weren't so close together but the view more than makes up for it.  They also have later cardio kickboxing and yoga classes which works well for me.  I saw a taco truck parked out front.  There's usually one parked in front of Ironworks during the week too.  That's just mean.

My girl has been sayin to me "Hey let's go rock climbin, it'll help me get into shape yadayadayada"... my usual response is "Hell yea let's go" mainly because i thought i would be good at it being that i consider myself to be in pretty good shape.  So we went before 3pm because that's when it's cheaper, and less crowded. And apparently we had to go through a crash course on how to climb, belay, safety issues and all that dumb shit. kidding. But the guy who taught us did a really good job, cuz i wasn't paying much attention but still figured it out.So when we start climbin i start to feel confident because we started off on the rock with no actual color-coded routes. I was thinkin "this aint so hard" so we move on to a rock where there are many routes which are labeled by its difficulty. So i take the medium/hard one and i start climbin. So im feelin real good and still thinkin "this aint so bad".. all of a sudden I hit the part where the rock slopes against you.. now im sweatin bullets and my palms feel like they're on fire, and im stressin out because i cant find a hold thats the color of the route im on. So without lookin at my girl, i tell her i need to go down because im tired as shit, and while im doing so, theres people passin me up the rock left and right with ease. So when i look down at her i notice that i am barely 10 feet off the floor, which isn't very high... and a kick to the balls of my self-esteem.It was here at Mission Cliffs where i came to the realization that my upper body strength can be laughed at by my girlfriend and many others. Im still havin trouble trusting whoever is belaying me but i guess that disappears over time. nonetheless me and the misses had an incredible time making fools of ourselves in front of people who seem to be regulars there. Such a good time that imma be back doing the same exact thing.

I must say, this is a wonderful work out.  A lot of it deals with muscle control, trusting on your partner, and mapping out your course.  With that said, I've become a fan of rock climbing.I like the facility, the courses range from beginner, to pro as well as bouldering, so with that said, its going to take you some time before you reach "Ceiling" (pun intended) of conquering the courses.  The staff is friendly, and knowledgeable of their craft.  the only let down is the lack of parking.  It seems that any time of the day, parking will always be an issue.  I recommend you to check this out, the price is reasonable and the experience is great to have.

No I don't climb rocks. Stephanie don't play that. But my friend recently threw a birthday party for his young daughter here and I have to say it was pretty damn cool. The kids ranged in ages from 5 to 14 and they seemed to have a great time. The staff was attentive and the gent who was coaching the kids, mostly girls, on how to climb etc.. seemed very patient and encouraging.The most amazing thing was to watch these little kids scale the wall all the way to the top (30ft straight up?) like an anxious monkey and then repell down like it "twernt no thang." I guess the young are truly fearless. And now I am inspired.There was a small, modest room in the back where the kiddies had lunch and cake after it was all over. I am guessing it's for rent. The party was on a Saturday afternoon. It was pretty crowded in there but all the other adults who were there to practice their skills seemed fine with sharing the walls. I saw a few people climbing and conquering what looked to be impossible overhangs. Amazing.

What a place! Indoor rock climbing can't get better than this place. Its huge! Gotta be at least a 70 foot high ceiling. The climbing courses change often so you'll have something new to master every couple of months! Difficulty ranges from 5's to 13s. 5 to 8s are pretty much beginner courses, 9s to 10s are intermediate, and 11 to 13s are pretty high up there, literally. Height of course has nothing to do with it. Its the course that defines the difficulty. The tougher courses challenge your flexibility, strength, stamina and require you to "solve puzzles with your body". The most difficult course I've seen was a 13C. That had those insane upside-down overhangs, and was lead climbing only.  They've got a nice area for bouldering (rock climbing without a safety rope but only going up about 8 feet) too. Safety is crucial here and they're totally on top of it. Regardless if you're experienced or not, unless you have a tag from them showing you can properly belay & wear and tie your harness/ropes, they will not let you climb. Luckily for beginners, they provide a class that shows how to tie your ropes so you don't fall to your doom. They also show you how to properly belay so your partner doesn't fall to their doom. Not that anyone has so far. For pricing,  a day pass can be about $22+ with all the gear (shoes, harness, carabiner, and belay device. Extra for the chalk bag and chalk. Membership starts about $60+ monthly. Definitely pays off if you go frequently like all gym memberships.They've also got a small weight room and some cardio devices. Heck they even got a room with kick bags to increase stamina and strength. All in all a great gym. And if you're a member, you can go to all the Touchstone Gyms in the US as far as I know. Only downside is the place kinda smells funny but what gym doesn't?

Where to start...Things I love:1)  Bouldering peeps - they are so great, friendly and helpful to anyone trying to improve as a climber2)  The locker room is 10 x better since the remodel.  That alone gave you a star.3)  The class schedule - having class on Sundays is awesome and yoga early AM and late PM is key for my schedule.  4) Close to my house and close to Tonayense taco truck5)  Real people that are not annoying to work out with or next to.  I don't have to worry about anyone throwing pick up lines at me.  6)  The routes are awesome and changed routinely.  Things that make me wonder if I should commute to Planet Granite: 1)  Cleanliness - the dust is out of control here.  Clean the overhead beams more often and wipe down the cardio/weight machines more often.2)  The weight room is prehistoric - how fitting you added Kettle balls to the collection.  I must admit, it has improved some in terms of adding new yoga mats and foam rollers.  Seriously, get rid of the leg machines and half the benches, open things up a bit, and replace it with a Free Motion cable system. 3)  In comparison to Planet Granite, this place should be a steal.  Lower the prices or make the equipment / services better.  4)  Small bouldering area.I will always be a loyal member.

MC...has to be my favorite gym, then again I've been climbing there since 04. Through the years the routes (rope & bouldering) have steadily been fun, technical and awesome! I do miss hawk and tol's routes though. A definite 5 stars for indoor climbing. The staff are awesome too! Very knowledgable and puts safety first in everyway.

Rock Climbing is my favorite hobby, and Mission Cliffs is my favorite climbing gym. They have an amazing facility and employees, and all of the members are really nice too. They also offer classes, but climbing is the main draw. Everywhere you look there's hot shredded guys. Sounds like a good workout experience to me. Plus, at the end of the night, you can even take a shower with them!

Service: Friendly if you know what you're doing; can be a daunting social interaction for newbies- but they're all really helpful!Cost: Pricey compared to places like Planet Granite (65/month vs. 53/month).  The initiation fee is 100, but every now and then they do a month where they waive the initiation fee.Classes:  I've never been to Spin or the Cardio Boxing classes, but I live by their yoga classes.  They even do workshops throughout the month (e.g. Inversions, Hip-Openers, Arm-Balances, Beginner's Workshops, etc).Climbing: I boulder more than I top rope.  They have plenty of routes that they change in sections every 3-4 weeks and unlike Planet Granite, the bouldering routes are more complex and require you to use a lot of different climbing techniques.  PG has more routes, but they require more stretch and muscling your way through- and it seems like they change less often.  The bouldering cave at MC may be a little small, but the front desk person told me that they will be expanding the bouldering area soon (they bought out an office next door).Cleanliness:  Layers of dust/ chalk in the lockers are pretty much unavoidable.  The machines could use a good wiping down.  Equipment: Not much- this gym is not a fancy facility and is all about no-frills climbing.Overall, PG may seem like the better deal: they have more machines, more frequent classes, a lot of routes to choose from, are cleaner, and cost less, but I can't stand the pretentious vibe I get from the other granola patrons form the Marina and the kids running around the place- it's disgusting.  MC may have it's share of snooty hipsters, be a little more expensive, and have less to offer in terms of equipment, but the climbing experience and the classes are top-notch and the routes require just as much mental skill as it does physical.But be sure you get there in the wee hours of the morning- this place gets packed in the evenings.

Common fears.  Fear of close places.  Fear of heights.  Fear of intimacy.  Apple?  Check.  Check.  Check.  Ok, well one of those fears can be conquered here.I used to be afraid of heights.  I started rock climbing and that really helped me.  Nothing like being suspended from a fifty foot wall, entrusting your life in the hands of one person and some friction on a rope.  Climbing is an exhilarating experience.  You can set goals for yourself, reach that rock, reach the top.  Finishing a climb is satisfying, especially if it was a challenging one.  The more you climb, the more you see improvement.  It helps you build confidence, focus, decompress, and have a good time.A good date activity.  Nothing like showing off your bootay to your partner while you are on the wall.  Mission Cliffs is a great place to practice.

I love it here. Its always a great time, I'm not the best climber in the world and you know what there are no judgments here. Only calm level headed advice and great staff who help you get up there.  Variety of walls and levels of difficulty. Bouldering upstairs and a steam room for your tired arms and legs when your done. The gym is also nice when you want some cardio or weights.  They have yoga, and core training classes as well. In case you are like me and need to get yourself together before climbing again after a year.  Overall this place rocks!

Tonight was my first night checking out my local climbing gym (just moved here). The male staff was kind but the one female staff member was very unfriendly. I felt as though I was bothering her just by talking. I'm still deciding if it's MC or PG for me but the experience at MC today makes PG look more appealing.

Dearest MC,First thing you should know is that I love you. That will never ever change.We've been through a lot together, huh? Remember when I first gathered the courage to meet you face to face? Timid and naive, I took you on and only lasted three routes, the hardest being a 5.6. Unperturbed and confident, I came back around and slowly worked my way up your ratings as you worked your way into my heart. I was completely okay with the idea of you seeing other people (97.5% of the climbing populous of San Francisco), but I'm a pretty open and understanding fellow, I had a girlfriend as well, so who am I to talk? Yes, we were both happy and content.But over the past year, though I'm still thrilled to see you, I will have to admit that that flame deep inside me does burn a little less strongly for you. Yes, it's true, I have strayed a few times, but in all honesty, I don't think I can be blamed for that. To my dismay, your popularity has been increasing, so much so that I struggle for your attention most evenings. I know, there isn't much you can do about that: you're the only one in the city. And we've worked through that issue by agreeing to meet in the mornings and early afternoons. It's worked well for both of us so far, tho parking has been a pain during the day. But yeah, I know you're in the Mission, so that's kind of expected...But also, for being fitness oriented, you've let yourself go quite a bit. I know, I'm being very superficial--but I have to be honest here. I find irony in the fact that as you've helped me get more fit, you've pretty much stayed the same, and in some cases have let yourself go. Your weigh and cardio equipment is quite small and limited, your locker rooms aren't as nice as your contemporaries, and air filtration isn't so great.
