And would it be too much to ask to improve your lighting and just put on a little bit more paint and deco every now and again? I mean, yes, you are a natural beauty in that industrial, alternative sort of way, but even you'll probably feel better and more confident yourself if you'd spiffy up a bit more.MC, I truly do love you. You've opened my eyes to a whole new world and have given me so much. But I think it's time for me to see others again. Don't worry, I won't walk away from this relationship that we've built. You're somewhat close by, but please don't think that I'm just keeping you around for convenience. You're still dynamic and crazy in ways that the others aren't. I don't want to make any promises or lead you on, but there may once again be a future for us. Only time will tell. And though I may not always be around as often, you are always in my thoughts. Always.Truly yours,MPS -- How about brunch a month from now?

Love U Superbowl Sunday. You gave me an empty climbing gym so boulder wall and I could have our way with each other for hours. It was rough, it was tumble, and some blood was involved .... Just the way I like it. Just me, the 2nd floor boulder wall, and hours of solitary sweating. My shoulders and back are trembling.... and my arms are numb. - "Was it good for you Boulder-Wall .... ?"- "Shit, Mark, just wake me up when you wanna go again"-...... (Hmmm,  I'm gonna need more practice)

So much fun!  We took a belay class where we learned to rope ourselves in and belay our partners.  Once I was stationed on the ground and realized that I had somebody's potential fall in my hands, I gripped on tightly.  I thought that we'd clock in a few climbs just to say "yeah, we're really adventurous, we went climbing today."  We stayed for three hours!  There were a whole variety of climbers and people bouldering.  You know that when a seven year old climbs past you that you need to work on your climbing game.It was $28 for the belay class and a day of climbing- well worth the feeling of superiority that washed over me as I left.

I came back recently to try their bouldering.  MC was my first exposure to indoor climbing, and, as such, I think my initial review was a bit wide-eyed and overstimulated.  On a second visit, I didn't like how cramped the bouldering space was - the caves gave a claustrophobic feel and the corners made it harder to share the space.  It was very crowded (7:30 weeknight).  I got tired of everyone milling around watching me fail at bouldering (and so did my forearms, since obviously my form leaves something to be desired) so I thought I'd at least go to the cardio section and sweat for a while.Two pieces of the very sparse cardio equipment (maybe 12 machines all together?) were not working.  I settled on the only vacant functioning machine, a stair-climber that squeaked with each step.  I squeaked on it for 20 minutes, much to not only my own annoyance, but that of climbers nearby.  So first I was clueless boulder newbie with bad form, then I was crazy squeaky stair girl.  I know people don't probably come here for the cardio equipment, but I would think these Mission kids aren't shelling out extra money for a separate gym membership.  Service and rope routes are still good.  Also, I don't mind the social atmosphere and unsolicited tips so much.  I might come back, but wouldn't consider membership.Bottom line, I think they could clean this place up significantly and re-think the floor plan - right now it is not competitive with Planite Granite.

I came here a month and half ago. It was my first time doing indoor rock climbing. You can rent equipment there, the harness and shoes. My friend had to teach me how to tie the knots and I had to take some test before I could have started climbing. I believe we arrived around 7.30 or close to 8pm on a Tuesday. I did the "easy" ones. They were pretty hard but my friend pushed me to continue and I was able to complete them. It was extremely fun and I would definitely like to come back. Your arms will definitely get a work out although you're suppose to use more of your legs. O yea your hands get really sweaty and I would suggest washing your hands after you are done climbing.

I love this place.  I used to live a few blocks away and this place is one of the things I miss about my old neighborhood.  That and the nachos a few blocks away.Everyone's really helpful and friendly, the setups are good, and there's a steamroom in the changing area.  There's also a gym but I forget that every time I'm there because I get caught up in the climbing part.It's not cheap cheap but it's fairly affordable, so I feel I can justify going every chance I get.

My friend and I came here at 11am on a weekday. It wasn't crowded at all. The staff is very friendly and the regulars who come are very welcoming and helpful (especially because it was my first time). The belaying intro class was not only very helpful, it was actually fun.I always wanted to try this place and now, I'm really glad I did. I even ended up getting membership. =]

Great for beginners and fairly forgiving for slow learners.  If you can get a partner to come with you that's your size and wants to do all the things you want to do, so you have a spotter or if you both want to boulder you'll have a good time well worth the price of admission.  I believe they have like a ladies night only every third Tuesday or something like that and me likes discounts.Personally I like trying the medium to difficult faces because they present good challenges while still giving you room for creativity though you still have that nice little rope safety.

I get reciprocal membership here through my Pipeworks membership, so I decided to check it out while in SF this weekend.  I found the bouldering area to be more difficult than most, due to a large number of the walls being inverted.  Difficult in a fun, challenging, way though.They don't have much cardio/weight equipment.  While Pipeworks has plenty of that, I couldn't use Mission Cliffs as a primary gym.

An Indoor Climbing Paradise!In San Francisco? Need a workout? Need a first date idea? Like climbing? Mission Cliffs is where it all happens. Was out in SF for a vacation a little while ago and wanted to get my climbing fix so I took my buddy and went to MC. This place has it all! Monstrous 5.15 routes for the advanced to simple 5.6's for the average Joe Schmo! On top of that, they have a really nice bouldering area, gym and a sauna to boot! If you never climbed before, I highly recommend you take the class, it is a great help and you will get familiar with what is what there. The staff is super friendly and I was able to rock out once I got in.  Did I mention that this place is HUGE?! There is definitely something for everyone from beginners to advanced. For those who are locals, you have one hell of a gym,and if you are a visitor like me, you will make sure you find this place and grab on to the wall.

I heart Mission Cliffs. This is one of those gems in the city where there's something for everyone: you can bring the kids, hang out with friends, get a good workout, clear your mind.... etc. The bouldering problems and top-rope routes change fairly frequently -- the route setters do a pretty good job ensuring variety and complexity for all skill sets.Some things to consider, which are reasons why I docked a star: (1) The weight room is outdated with old equipment. If you're a cross-training/cross-fit athlete, you're not going to have all of the equipment you need for a full work out.(2) The place gets CRAZY packed on weeknights. So, you can expect to wait a few minutes to do a problem/route.(3) So you know when you go into a rock climbing gym and the smell of foot and body odor  permeate in the air? Well, you still sort of get that here.... but it's NOT THAT BAD, promise. In fact, I'd say you probably think the odor added a bit of character to the place.
I can't say I'm impartial-- starting climbing at MC in 3rd grade, took a good 10 year hiatus and have been back to stay :)

Such an empowering experience.  Sure, I work out all the time, and can hold my own in a weight room full of dudes just fine.  But there is nothing like conquering a towering wall with your own strength, perserverance and maneuvering.  The staff is super friendly and accessible.  The rentals are reasonable and they have a beginners class that will certify you specifically for this facility if you just want to drop in (check when they have the class though).  One of the best features are the patrons.  I'm pretty much a novice, but everytime I've gone here, I've met some amazing people who are more than willing to share insight, a new technique or their own escapades.  I tried bouldering for the first time during my most recent visit and one of the guys there stayed with me til I mastered the climb--took 3 tries but dammit I slapped that ceiling but good!

How have I not reviewed my favorite gym?? Climbing takes the monotony out of exercise. Plus, it feeds on itself - get more fit, climb better, repeat.There is climbing for all skill levels, bouldering, top rope, and lead climbing. They also have yoga, cardio boxing, and spin classes, plus enough weights and cardio equipment so that you rarely have to wait to get on a station or machine.It can get crowded during peak hours, and especially during the cold season. But everyone is great about climbing etiquette and observing the right of way.One last thing -- they're expanding in the next year or so. Which is awesome.

An absolutely wonderful indoor climbing gym. They have weights, exercise machines, showers and sauna... but I only go for top-rope climbing with my friends. If you ever go alone you can let the front desk know and they'll announce that someone is looking for a climbing partner. If you have friends who are members, ask them if they'll bestow upon you their monthly free guest pass.What gets me most excited about this gym is the number and quality of the routes they have (which are changed on a regular basis and rarely have missing tape like I've found at other gyms). Not only is there TONS of wall space, but they have a variety of types of routes: stemming (ie in the corner between two walls so you rely on balance even more than strength), straight vertical and overhung routes abound, each with a wide range of difficulty ratings.

Okay, I love climbing at this place but not really necessarily for the facility itself.  I love the people that I meet while bouldering upstairs, but I don't love the fact that I've had to wait in lines to get on a warm-up, and I feel like my technique has gone to the crapper (as opposed to the first gym I climbed at and worked at (Rocknasium, in Davis)) because so many of the problems are strength oriented.  I love the height of the rope climbing...its pretty amazing, and when I bring new people to the gym they are super impressed by that...complaint: the problems under 5.10 are ladders.  There's little in developing technique for new climbers when thats all they do.  Also, the ratings are ridiculously sandbagged.  I've never climbed 5.12 outdoors (let alone 5.11b) and I can flash here.  Same with boulder problems, although my complaint with the boulder setters is the consistency of ratings...some are fairly accurate, whereas others are way easier. I don't know if it's just me, but that's my gripe and I'm sticking to it. I will continue frequenting this gym, solely for the people I've met and climb with on a regular basis...This is my home away from home.  Some of the problems/routes are really good (so don't think I hate all the setting! I'm just short and hate reachy/strengthy climbs...give me crimpy/balancy/technique-y climbs anyday!) And most of the staff is okay, not really stand-out service or anything but they do their job and are definitely corporate climbing staff, not your small-town dirty rock-climber-owned-type of place.So, in the end, come and hang out...So many regulars; you'll make tons of new climbing friends!

What can I say?  I love Mission Cliffs gym.  Very fun, healthy, and a great crowd!anyone who wants to try rock-climbing, or yoga, or get in shape doing something other than walking the treadmill, give it a try.

I began my climbing life at Planet Granite in Belmont. Then I changed jobs and when I began to work in SF dirving down to Belmont every day to dangle from a rope became impossible. Sooooooo I made the switch to Mission Cliffs and I knew right away, this here ain't no PG scoob.Mission cliffs has become too big for its britches, the routes are more than crowded, the bouldering cave has become a "scene" and a place to show off ink as much as it is a space to boulder. The cave is small in comparison to say Planet Granite's expansive bouldering ramp and other varied walls. Oh you like cleanliness ???? Well forget about it... I find the whole thing to be filthy... seriously... broken lockers in the men's changing room, not sure how the ladies is, not enough lockers to go around, a space that is small cramped and smells of warm pabst, stale cigs and that general hipster funk that permeates every corner of psuedo intellectual fashion cliques... man I sound old, but really I'm not, I just really don't like mission cliffs.But its not all bad... in addition to the first come first serve yoga they have spin classes, something PG is missing, but to me isn't the main draw of a gym... there's the El tonayense taco truck perma parked across the street to reward a day of being hit with hipster shvitz and waiting forever for a route, but other than that I think its on par with my favorite climbing chain... so yeah... there you have it... enjoy...

I love Mission Cliffs. I moved to SF from Berkeley and now Mission Cliffs is my preferred climbing gym. The fitness area is definitely smaller than Ironworks but the climbing at Mission Cliffs is just as good if not superior. The climbs are definitely longer (the highest climb is 50ft) and the terrain ranges from very challenging (5.14) to beginner (5.4, 5.5).

This place is soooo over-priced, it's actually a crime. The $100 initiation fee is too much, their daily rate of $20 is too much, their 10 punch pass of $160 is too much... If you put your pass on hold, you have to pay a monthly fee... And, I wouldn't be surprised if they raise their prices after the renovation! I've never seen prices like this at a climbing gym. And I've been to many. And, for what? Their customer service sucks, it's always packed after 6pm, the ropes are literally disintegrating and I've never seen so many macho, skin-monkeys in my life. Why do people pay these prices for such shit? Maybe because of the promise of a newly renovated gym soon to come - and they want to feel like they're contributing? Or, maybe because no matter how much it is, Bay Area yuppies with tons of extra cash laying around will pay it (and contribute to the ongoing family evictions in the Bay Area at that). Maybe it's all our own faults that these prices are high or maybe it's not. Regardless, if you go here, you are contributing to it all and you suck too.

Ok, so I maybe developing a new addiciton. I went climbing for the second time on Sunday. This time it was extra cool 'cause it was for my good friend's 30th birthday partay! Anywho, I'm really new to climbing so I've only got first impressions to work with...so bear with me ;-)Mission Cliffs is not as clean as Planet Granite in Belmont, however, they seem to have more variety as far as climbs go. They also have spin bikes, a weight room and yoga classes. All good stuff that I need to stay shape during winter time, especially as riding my bike in the rain all the time gets old quickly! Yea to finding a new sport!So new experiences, I learned to belay and I did a couple 5.9 and one 5.10a climbs! Oh yea, being a cyclist means I have no upper body strength...so I'll have to do as 50 cent says, "do all them push ups to pump up your chest I got a 12 gauge mossbert to pump up your chesthave you gasping for breath after that shell hit your vestfear me like you fear god cause I bring death"...word!I'll be back, probably to take a basic class to up my skill level!

What a great place! If you like trying something new, like adventure, or want to conquer your fears this is the place for you! Through groupon, my sister and I were able to come here and spend some quality time and try something new! Before you hit the ropes, you meet with your instructor plus other beginners for a cram session on the do's and don'ts of climbing and safety measures. Adam was our instructor and he was very nice and also very patient (with me) when I fumbled on some things. (hey, being put on the spot is a lot of pressure, ok?!!) Once I got the hang of things, I started climbing. It was scary and I tried not to look down but I managed to get half-way up...Hopefully, the next time I come back I'll muster up the courage to go all the way up!!! It was fun but it is also a good workout...you don't realize how much upper body strength you need till you're hanging there trying to figure out which ever way to go. We also tried bouldering for a quick minute and that was even harder....time to hit the gym hard. Btw, they do have a little gym area with weights and cardio machines. Staff was friendly and helpful. Clean facility. Definitely will go back for more! :)

It's not going up that's scary...A few months ago my mom asked me when we were going rock climbing. "Whaaaaa?" I had thought about going before but to have my then-49 yo mother ask me about it...Cool. So today as a birthday present, we went (avec mari) to Mission Cliffs. Happy 50th Mom!We took the Intro to Climbing Class with Michael who was a highly effective teacher. I really enjoyed his teaching style. He gave us a thorough lesson in all the safety basics, made sure we knew what to do and left us to climb with confidence. So many thanks to Michael! The class was about 1.5 hours long which does seem like a long time. There were 6 of us in the class but really that amount of focused teaching on something potentially dangerous is welcomed by me. We still had plenty of time afterward to climb on our own.Can I say that my mom (et mon mari) put me to shame? My fear of heights prevented me from making it to the top of the wall. My mom? No problemo. Go Mom!I liked the wide open facility. I had no problem with snotty attitudes from more experienced climbers. The facility was clean. Not smelly. Good times really. $28 for the intro class, equip rental and day pass is a bit too steep for a monthly thing but they have cheap equip rentals and day passes without the lesson if you know what you're doing. We will be back! Maybe next time I'll make it to the top.

For $22, I was able to boulder several of the many courses they have set-up upstairs, take a yoga class, shower, and relax in the sauna...what's not to love about that?  For a beginner like me (I didn't do the full climbing experience) this was a great way to put my toe in the water without having to dive in head first.  Be sure to check the schedule on the website to see when the classes, special events, etc. are.  Oh, and as a bonus, VERY attractive members...most of whom are topless.  Definitely no complaints from my end.

I've been looking for a good gym in the Mission for a while. Even though I've never been especially drawn to climbing, I had heard it's fun and a good workout. When I learned this place also has basic weight and aerobic equipment, I thought it'd be worth checking out.Ultimately I did decide to go with them for these reasons: 1) NO CONTRACT.2) Friendly staff who gave very direct answers to my questions and didn't try to deliver a sleazy sales pitch or force me into giving a bunch of contact information.3) No sign-up fee throughout January (normally $100).Also, bonus points for not getting uncomfortable, overly-lustful, "I'm gonna make you squeal boy" looks when checking out the locker room.

Mission Cliffs is a COMPLETELY different vibe than Touchstone in Concord, my first climbing-gym-love.  Don't get me wrong, though.  Different doesn't mean bad.  I mean that it's a different gym with a much different clientele.  When I moved to the city, I had already canceled my membership at the Concord gym, so I had to re-sign up at MC.  Everything about the gym was fine except that I never really got to know many of the people there.  I felt like everyone just kind of went along doing their own thing and didn't get to know their fellow climbers.So I went alone to the gym, made a few friends, but mostly hit up the bouldering pit or the elliptical machine.My biggest gripe about Mission Cliffs?  THERE IS NO SLACKLINE.  Gasp!  My true love is not a part of this gym, unfortunately.  And it's understandable, considering the small space and the set up.  They even expanded around that far corner and added a room for fitness classes, but alas, no slackline (mind you, it's been some time since I've been to MC, so if there is a slackline there now, PLEASE let me know!!).All this yelping about the climbing gyms had me really nostalgic and now miss climbing a lot!  If anyone needs a temporary (day-use-only) climbing partner, let me know, I still have all my gear!!!

This is where I learned to climb back in the day.  It seems like a lot of people have defected to PG now but I'll always love Mission Cliffs even though I'm always either freezing or sweltering there.My girlfriends love sitting on the bleachers watching fit men who don't seem to own shirts climb.  My preschool/first grader friends love the dinosaur holds.  I've taken a few yoga classes, not really impressed but not bad for being free with gym membership.

Great walls, Lots of super friendly staff, clean and has good hours. Mission cliffs is a great rock-climbing gym to start with. On top of that it offers some pretty fantastic yoga classes and a well maintained weight-room / set of exercise equipment. More than anything though I'm a fan of the casual and friendly atmosphere.

I couldn't be more pleased with my introduction and ongoing experiences at Mission Cliffs.The staff is friendly and very informative.  The community is full of knowledge and comraderie.I joined to climb primarily -- not realizing that Mission Cliffs also offers a series of group exercise classes, steam/sauna/shower amentities -- in conjunction with their cardio/weight equipment.  It has a lot to offer besides tons and tons of climbs!Mission Cliffs = one, big family.  Sincerely,Newbie climbing nerd

Seriously, every single person that has even known me might not believe it is actually me writing this review, despite the clear photo depicting Laura G (the first).I love going to the gym.  NOT every gym, just THIS gym.  Climbing is one of the few workouts I can participate in without checking my watch every 4 minutes and asking whoever I'm exercising with "Are we DONE yet??"And friends are always surprised and impressed this climbing gym also has machines and free weights, yoga and spinning classes.Who knew Laura G could enjoy a gym!PS It is really easy to crush on most of the men here - have you SEEN climbers arms???  Anyone who appreciated a good crew member in school, check out the climbers.  You won't regret it.

First thing I noticed was that this place is just really cool-looking; used to be a steel mill and now it's got a nice appealing warehouse-y look to it.  It's a very relaxed atmosphere. The staff are friendly and helpful (one guy spent literally twenty minutes helping my friend figure out how to wear the odd harness he brought from home).My friend and I wandered around, top-roped and bouldered, did yoga, and munched blueberries on the bleachers without ever feeling out of place in any of these activities.  It's got some really high walls and a lot of high-rated climbs, but they also have a few shorter walls full of 5.7s and 5.8s for beginners. I was amused by the rows of very fit men in crew cuts running on the exercise machines.

I like this place. I have a membership here, and climb here on a regular basis. The walls are interesting, and the routes are kept fresh. They sell and rent equipment. The rental prices are cheap. The one thing that may irritate folks who only climb indoors: rather then using biners to clip into the top rope, they have you tie in. This slows down swapping between climbers.The have a decent bouldering area, but not amazing. A good mix of difficulties.They have yoga classes (haven't tried), weights (haven't tried) and a small selection of cardio machines. The cardio machine mix is a bit off: treadmills are usually full, while less popular cardio machines are free.When in doubt, meet at the bleachers.

First off, I love Mission Cliffs.Secondly, it's far from perfect.  I'm sorry, but it's true.Pros:* Great staff.  This didn't used to be true.  They had a few awful ones.  Now, everyone is pretty cool.  One of them will try to hit on your girlfriend, though, so watch out.  (you know who I'm talkin' about!)* Great climbs.  The climbs tend to be tougher than Ironworks.* Great cardio.  The machines are mostly new and in good shape.* People.  In general, you will always find something to befriend, chat up, or just watch in awe.  I've made numerous great friends, and even a few (bad) girlfriends here.Cons:* The locker rooms are smelly (well, okay, the MEN's locker room is, I'm just *assuming* that  the women's is, too).* The weight area is pretty bad.  It's way too closely packed, lacking in machines, and not a great weight selection.  I go to Ironworks to get a weight workout.* Tuesday and Thursday nights, in particular, are getting ridiculous.  I love the 11pm closing time on those days, but the crowds of newbies falling on my head in the bouldering area is annoying.  (no hate for the newbies, I was there too, but I never fell on anyone)These days, I prefer Ironworks for the smaller crowds and vastly better workout area.  For fun, interactive bouldering, though, Mission Cliffs wins hands-down.

It's were the IT techs, musicians, SOMA scenesters and old Dungeons and Dragons guys go to get in shape.I need to go more. A buddy of mine actually got me some climbing shoes for X-mas...really cool. I work in a normal gym setting and it's a refreshing change. It is a bit of a learning curve though and the gym culture is a bit of a change from the gym bunny/meathead scene. You can tell the members know that too. If you're new, they like to point out how your gym physique might hinder you but at the same time will tell you a decent route for a climb.And....It's a good place to x-train since they have a half decent weight room and cardio equipment.

I like to climb walls but I'm not great at it. In fact, my short stature limits my ability to do well or so I think it does. As a beginner, I signed up for a membership at Mission Cliffs during their January promotion when initiation fees were waived. Membership fees per month are reasonable; however, I should take advantage of the gym and classes offered to members more frequently. My only gripe is the smell.. I wish more people invested in deodorant or would air out their funk outside.

Of the two climbing gyms in S.F., Mission Cliffs has a more hardcore attitude and is less frilly/posh. Never will you see the SF Gate suggesting this as a place to take your kid on a rainy day, like they did for Planet Granite. Mission Cliffs is older, dingier but has awesome climbing (the bouldering there is definitely harder than at PG); I must say, for top roping, I like how PG uses colored hand holds rather than tape since it's easier to see what is on, but that is personal preference above all. Be sure to bring your own belay device because they don't have gri gris on all the ropes, like at PG. The locker rooms are nicer at PG but the sauna at Mission Cliffs smells more like a sauna should - the wood is more aromatic and it's darker and more secluded than PGs. Once, I had a guy walk into the ladies room at PG on accident and the first thing you see is the glass sauna door upon entering...ack...not going to happen at Mission Cliffs. It is so well hidden, I went 5 times before I noticed it was there.I personally belong to PG, mostly because it's closer to me. If I was halfway between, it'd be hard to decide. PG is newer, brighter and much more posh...Mission Cliffs is edgy and gets more of the Mission crowd. Pick the one that fits your geography/personality best since pricing is pretty comparable.

I just like the overall relaxed, yet focused, vibe of this place.  I was supposed to meet my friend for the introductory Belay safety class but unfortunately I arrived 8 minutes late (as opposed to 15 minutes early) and they didn't let me in.  While I was dissapointed, I admired their committment to safety and people completing the entire class.  They could have just took my money and threw me on the wall, but they didn't.  The good news for me is that my friend took the class and ended up teaching me what she learned and so I didn't have to take the introductory class in order to pass the Belay test.  Sweet!The staff seem to really enjoy working there but also come across as taking their jobs seriously.  The sign in and gear rental process was simple and quick.  And there seems to be enough space for everyone to climb with some additional workout facilities if you're so inclined.And did I mention the guys that come here?  They're pretty damn hot.  Firm upper torsos with tight shirts to show them off.  Just another incentive to come back....

I surprised myself by accepting a classmate's inivitation to Mission Cliff tonight.  Mostly because I'm weak and have no upper body strength and am not really interested in showcasing my undefinedness.  This was exemplified during my pitiful attempt at bouldering.  Pitiful.  Let's just say if I was being chased by bears and got cornered up against a giant rock, those bears would be sucking the fat off my bones in no time.  Just fat though, since I apparently have no muscles to speak of.  On the plus side, I was able to claw and grunt myself up the easiest of the wall climbs, but only with a lot of encouragment and help from my friend who was amazingly patient and sweet with me the entire time. (Thanks, Chris!).By the time I got home and hobbled into the shower my arms and hands were aching.  I had to wash my hair with breaks inbetween because I couldn't them hold up and my towel felt 5 lbs heavier than usual.  My hands are raw and blotchy with a bit of skin hanging off one and a blister on the other. I am horrible at this climbing business, but I still had fun.  I'm totally showing my hands to everyone at work tomorrow so I can pretend that I'm hardcore like that.OH.  I almost forgot!  Serious revelation: Climbers are hot.

I am scared of heights, but love new challenges and testing myself. This was the place to kick my fears in the nuts. After plopping down $28 for lessons and rentals (the shoes were not gross), we were taught techiniques for climbers and belayers. With an overdose of coffee surging through my veins, I managed to stay focused and absorbed the information from our instructor.Ignoring my ounce of anxiety, I was up on the wall. Turns out that I am an agile little monkey. Surprising my friends who did not expect me to climb up the wall at the speed of an energizer bunny. It was AWESOME! When I got to the top, I looked down and smiled! Then I wanted to do it again and again. You get the point.Exhuberence is a bitch. My arms and legs were shaking. We plan to come back bi-weekly. People who are scared or have their souls killed by stress should try this. It's not cheap, but how you can put a price on your sanity and nailing down your fears? End of it all, I took a nap and ended up snoring (I never snore so you can imagine how tired I was!) Just make sure you don't wear jeans cause you might end up with crotch burn if the  belayer takes his/her time letting you down. For my first time, everyone heard me grumble "Ouch, my crotch! It burns!!! OUCHHHH!!!"

Booyah for climbing!!I've recently decided to become more of a dedicated climber and finally decided to join MC.  Pretty easy to get to if you don't have a car.  Just get off of the 16th Street Bart exit and walk to Harrison.I have my own gear, but you can rent it if you don't and want to see if this is your thing.   They also have a cardio room, yoga and bouldering.They change up the climbs regularly so you don't get bored. I already have a gym membership and go to a yoga studio so unfortunately I can not yelp about those extras.  But if you don't well then this is a BONUS!  I like this place a bit better than Class 5 in San Rafael.  Still need to check out Bezerkley's joint.Definitely recommend coming here, the staff is super cool and the all around vibe is chill.

Whoa, you definitely need to check this place out. So many runs your head'll spin. Although, watch out for when you venture there, for you'll encounter lines especially when everyone streams out of work. Walking up and down the climbing fingerboard kicked my butt as it should. For a quick workout and a fun time with friends it was a treasure to find this facility so close to where I was staying while in the Mission.
Almost always crowded, unfriendly staff, but fun walls.

Nerves were a little jittery on the way over to Mission Cliffs... I was going, after all, with my boyfriend who's an experienced climber.  The most I'd ever climbed was out my 2nd story window at home to hang Christmas lights for my mom.  Would I fall?  Would I be schooled by ten year old kids climbing 35-foot walls like monkeys?  Would I be able to belay my heavier-than-me-boyfriend?  Luckily, the answers to those questions were no, yes (there were some damn good little kids there, you'd be impressed, too), and yes.  What a fun way to spend a Saturday afternoon.  It wasn't too crowded, I learned how to tie knots and belay with the best of 'em, and I did about 4-5 climbs, increasing difficulties (and heights!) each time.  It was inbetween cheap and expensive - $18 to climb and $5 to rent shoes and a harness  - which I was fine with.  I left feeling accomplished and proud of myself for learning something new and working my muscles so hard it's difficult to type up Yelp reviews today.  =)  Bring your friends here, you'll have  a blast.

I love, love, love this placemember for 7 months now, couldn't be happier, but i wish there were more classes offered, especially on the weekends and early morning...just sayinghowever the classes that are offered are awesome....jodie's yoga classes are the best, the wednesday morning pilates/core class is really good All that said i really can't get enough climbing in and the hours could be slightly longer especially on the weekends.

I have great memories of Mission Cliffs as a kid where I would come here almost weekly to go climbing with friends. But after being away for 6 years and coming back to it, it just doesn't have that homey feel to it anymore. It's almost always crowded, leaving you to spend the majority of your time waiting to climb than actually climbing. But on the other side, they have added a sauna, and that's pretty cool.I still come here because it's more convenient than Granite Planet (or Planet Granite?) but try to avoid it on days when I know it will be at it's worst (i.e. rainy days)

Rock climbing is a total California thing. One trip to Mission Cliffs and you can see why. Mountain Hardware, North Face, and Timbuk2 stuff is everywhere. People carry around cartons of soy milk and huge Nalgene containers full of water. If you feel at ease with this group, this is the place for you. People here are friendly and available to offer advise if a you are stuck particular point in your climb. Everyone seems health-conscious and there to have a good time. The staff changes the climbs monthly so climbers are never stuck doing the same routes often.With all these great things, why do I only give it 4 starts? I subtracted a star because there are too many half-naked dudes walking around. Seriously, it never gets hot enough in San Fransisco or inside the facility to warrant that. The gym is built inside a old warehouse so the ceilings are freaking high up. Hot air rises!!! I realize you are climbing up but I've been to the top, it is not that hot up there either. If you are a person with overactive sweat glands, buy a Dri-Fit shirt. That material wicks away moisture. Otherwise, show off what you have on Flickr something.I joined a traditional gym a while ago. People there lift a lot of weight and run a lot of miles fully clothed. I do not know why this place should be any different.

I belonged to this gym a couple years ago and quit after my climbing partners and I became too busy to meet up. At the time it was just a good excuse to hang out with my friends and I belonged to another gym so I didn't miss it much when left. I rejoined a month ago because it's near my new shop, I've gotten chubby and I needed something convenient so I couldn't make excuses. I love it. I love that even though it's a climbing gym there's still all the equipment you need to get healthy and strong, I love the classes they offer, I love that I can go into the yoga room when no one's in there, plug in my ipod and jump rope all by myself but what I really love are the people who work there. They are friendly and helpful. I'm glad I chose to rejoin.

My girlfriend dragged me here a few months ago. Rock climbing was never something I thought about but since then I have been hooked. This is the only indoor climbing facility that I have been to, however the staff are friendly, helpful and knowledgeable. The walls are always changing which is sometimes cool but last week I found one of my favorite warm-up climbs was replaced. However this means you never get too comfortable and you are constantly being challenged. I have a great time here and highly recommend Mission Cliffs for a great workout and a new experience.

This place has character.  Although I live closer to the new PG, I just can't seem to let go of my Mission Cliffs.  Four stars simply because i am addicted to climbing and MC has an old timer climbing feel to it.  Great walls, helpful staff and a generally dedicated and interesting group of people!  The newly updated locker rooms are definitely a plus.That said, it definitely need a bit of updating in the gym department and bouldering areas.  New pads for bouldering would make a HUGE difference, and they seriously need to reorganize the gym area and get some new equipment.  Obviously there isn't much room, and I would rather have more walls than more equipment, but MC, you need a new hairdo!So minus one star for the gym equipment (and im sure there's more pressure now than ever since PG has opened), but the other 4 for just ...being MC...

Watz ^ Mission Cliffs!?!I started climbing here nine months ago and it's been a blast ever since. I went once with my roommate and bought a membership the next time I went in. I still have yet to top rope since I am a bouldering rat and always kick it upstairs. Bouldering is way more social and I've met loads of people in the bouldering area over time.Tuesdays and Thursdays they are open until 11 PM, which is perfect. It gets crowded during the week which is why I go at 9 PM on those days after the rush. The mornings and early afternoons on the weekend don't seem to be too bad when I go in to climb as well. I guess it can be quite expensive if you don't have a membership to visit. That's why you just have to find people with memberships and ask them to tag along!And as an added bonus, the taco truck outside the gym is totally awesome. The pollo asada is where it is at. This is the perfect place to hit up for lunch on Sunday after climbing in the morning. MMMMM......delicious!BATHROOM REVIEW------------------------------Showers in the bathrooms! This is like 6th grade PE class all over again. Lockers, showers, toilets and paper towels all over the floor. I think there is even a sauna but I only tinkle in this joint.

This rock climbing gym tries to accommodate children and adults. I go to Mission Cliffs every opportunity I get with my uncle and younger cousins now ages 6 and 10. They love the fun climbs on the second level. When they get tired my uncle and I go to the bottom level and climb our own routes. We always have a good time here.

Clmbing is like crack, nothing beats the taste sweat and blood after a long day of climb.  Mission Cliff is the oasis for urban climbers.Mission cliff has awesome walls and great bouldering problems, sometime I wish it's a bit bigger, especially in the evenings. Great place for beginners as well, free seminar on how to belay.  It does get very crowded after work, I'd recommend going during the day or early in the morning.

I really like this place, although I am not a member, paying that day pass gets you to do anything and everything that the gym offers. I like how they close late too. I mainly go there to go rock climbing but when I found out I can use all of the perks that it came with i tried cardio boxing and oh boy was that a work out. They really have good customer service, even after the staff is done serving you they walk around once in a while and check up on you. This is a good place to go indoor rock climbing and there is always a taco truck outside the building so it's a plus if your hungry afterwards. Although it has street parking I never had a hard time looking for parking. A good place just to work out, I can stay there all day and I'm not a gym person either. Check this place out has a lot of activities to offer.

I received a rock climbing gift certificate here as a X-Mas present and am psyched that I finally got the chance to use it a few weeks ago.We weren't able to make it in time for the belaying crash course, so we instead decided to do some bouldering and had a great time! I've been to City Beach's indoor rock climbing center and wasn't a big fan of their bouldering selection. From what I remember, there were just a few small boulders to practice on. Borrrrrring. At Mission Cliffs, they have a good section of walls to climb that are definitely challenging, but a good place to start. The padding below was adequate too, seeing as how I came flying down like a bird outta the sky at one point & walked away just fine. =]  Be aware though, that the beginner formations are pretty challenging but still a good place to start, so just be ready to push yourself when you're there. Shoe rentals were in pretty good condition, parking was easy, and the staff was cool. They've got weights and treadmills so you can tone up for climbing and the locker room/shower facilities seemed clean to me. My only gripe is that the facility is a bit on the musty side. They could probably use better ventilation.As far as the other climbing walls go (that require belaying), they seemed to have a pretty good amount of wall space available. I love how they change up the climbing formations every couple weeks so you don't get bored. Oo, and they also offer workshops and outdoor rock climbing outings, which I will be totally taking advantage of. I can't wait to get on those walls again!!

I've been going to Mission Cliffs about a 6 months now and I've been to a few other indoor climbing places including another Touchstone gym.There are many top rope walls with enough room for people to climb especially on a crowded weekend afternoon. There is also a bouldering section, exercise machines and treadmills.Also, the staff is friendly and knowledgeable.

I love this place! Been there over a dozen times.Come in on the weekdays before 3pm and get in for $10. $5 for full rental equipment. I never come in at any other time lolStaff is friendly on helping you pass the belaying and safety tests, but it's best to come in knowing how to do it so you can get straight to climbing!Wall paths are changed every so often (there are a lot!). There is also a huge bouldering section. There is a small weightlifting section with the essentials. Very hardcore looking.I'd get a year pass if it wasn't out of my budget, but I think it would be worth it as I would go a lot!

It may be busy but with routes that change often and yummy shirtless men with sexy muscular backs Mission Cliffs is better than a bar when it comes to relieving after work stress. It is a better deal to buy a monthly pass than a 10 day pass if you think you will use your membership. Who doesn't love rock climbing? The combination of fearless adventure, heart pumping exercise and confidence building is amazing. I'm impressed.

Despite the horror stories I've read about regarding dried blood on the walls/holds or whatever, I actually found the facility to be quite clean, and the ropes were in much better shape than its East East Bay sister, Diablo Rock Gym.  One thing is true though, the belay test is definitely more relaxed here than Planet Granite.

How great is a climbing gym that also has great yoga, weights and cardio.  Not to mention a sauna.The old timers are so helpful.  It is great to climb with them because you learn so much and they are very kind.You can do either soft yoga or butt kicking.  Kate and Elise kicks my but, but but they are is sooo supportive.

Got introduced to this place at a company event.Climbing is great exercise and a lot of fun.  It was hella harder than I thought it would be.  But I can see how this would be a great place to work out regularly... mix the climbing with the weight lifting and cardio equipment and you don't need to go anywhere else.  Problem is the location.  If you don't live near here, it's just not as convenient as a gym near home or work.

Mission Cliffs is my favourite gym. I've been climbing here since I moved to SF from Canada about a 1.5yr ago. There are a ton of climbs from beginner to advance. The staff is great and they have a way of changing up the routes on a regular basis to keep you pumped projecting interesting routes. If you're interested in climbing/bouldering competitions, they host a few annually....the atmosphere is completely chill so you can relax and get your climb on! If you're looking to take your lead test here, the folks provide awesome technical and safety pointers. Just ask! One tiny gripe that I have is that it gets cold in the evenings sometimes...so just remember to bring a hoodie / light jacket to wear in between climbs!Of course, you should definitely try out the other local gyms that are also part of the Touchstone Climbing network (free for Mission Cliff members) or Planet Granite.Oh and on your off-days they have Yoga classes - need I say more?

Definitely a cool place for beginners and up.What's cool about this place is that if you just want to try it, you can.  There is no committment to be a member, you can just try it once and see how you like.  Not only that, but they have discounts on certain days of the week to come try.  Discounts for women, college students, etc.Also a good place to meet people.  Most everyone there is friendly and will assist you in climbing.  At first it was kinda nerve racking... but after your first couple of climbs, you want to conquer more!

This was my first visit to Mission Cliffs. I've been to a couple of other rock walls including the one in the UC Davis ARC and I'm a little surprised at some of the negative comments that MC got.It could use some work? The cardio area is too small? It could be cleaner? Come on people. Have you guys ever climbed on real rocks? Rocks are pretty much really hard dirt. Sometimes birds and bears poop on them. And there are no yoga classes out in the wilderness. What a bunch of divas. I thought this place was great. I went on a Saturday afternoon and I didn't think it was too crowded. The staff people that WE interacted with were very friendly and cool. I also must add that the equipment that they sell is as cheap if not cheaper than at Sports Basement. I checked.Anyway, I'm even considering becoming a member because you can use their other Touchstone climbing gyms.

So, back in the day, when you know, I wasn't such a drunken lush, I used to a pretty decent climber....but now, I haven't been climbing regularly in about 2 years....so I figured, "hey, lets be active today rather than get drunk" (gasp!) Soooo, I finally made it to Mission Cliffs....And while I prefer to climb outdoors, this place is a pretty nice gym...nice bouldering area, and the walls have some sweet routes on it as well...although, I'm so ungodly out of shape currently and unable to hold to the wall, the best I could muster was a 5.10. How sad. But I think I'll be coming back soon, so I don't embarrass myself...and then I can start climbing again.I took one star off due to it being pretty crowded, but I guess its just popular, and really, I didn't have to wait that long to do the climbs I liked...and also the other gym equipment could be a bit more plentiful/nicer....but overall I'll be back, and macking those climbs once more.Hopefully. I'm kinda of a lush :)

Walk in to this place off the street with $28 in hand and 45 minutes (7:00 weeknights) later you'll be climbing 5.8's.  But 5.8's won't be enough to satiate your need.  You see climbing is like crack-cocaine, so you'll come back, eventually buy your own gear and yet another monthly gym membership.  You'll dream about granite all day long and lose interest in your "real" job.  A year later after getting fired from your 5th retail stocker night shift you'll go bankrupt and the sport will completely consume you.Save your $28, walk past the entrance and do us addicts a favor and free up the routes.
Great gym. Good safety practices. The routes are challenging and interesting. And the bouldering problems are really fun!

A great place to climb.  Though I'm usually there weekday evenings, my favorite time to go is right when the gym opens on weekend mornings, and barely anyone is there yet.  I've been a member for a few years now, and I was happy that they made so many upgrades to the gym (a whole new wall, studio that offers yoga & spinning classes) without raising monthly fees.As for climbing itself, I love a workout that doesn't feel like a workout.  Being on the wall is the closest I've ever come to understanding what the phrase "in the moment" means.  The cares of the day just fall away because I'm so focused on what I'm doing.  It totally clears my head.  I think that the biggest misconception about climbing is when people say "Wow, you must have really strong arms".  It's not just arms - you've gotta use your whole body!

Mission Cliffs offers a great way to challenge yourself mentally and physically.  Climbing is a unique way to get in touch with your body's strengths and weaknesses in a fun way.  It is a great exercise in discipline and persistence to climb.  What a great reward it is to be able to work a problem through completion that once was impossible to even approach.  This place is great for body- and soul-strengthening!!**************************Wow.  I just read what I wrote about MC, and that was waaaaaay boring.  I guess those are just the "deep" feelings that I have about the MC experience.  On the surface though, this place seriously rocks (no pun intended)!!  Amazingly fun AND challenging, rocking climbing is not something that should intimidate you.  It's new, but it's completely doable.

Good place to climb, although minimal weight equipment. Most people seem to stick to the bikes upstairs anyway.The paths are changed every few weeks by climbers with different styles, so no matter how tall you are or what your skill, you'll find something new coming your way on a regular basis. Take note that while there are many short paths for beginnings between 5.5-5.8, there tend to only be 1-2 paths on the tall walls between 5.7-5.8, so in this range you'll spend most of your time upstairs or waiting in line for the limited mid-range paths on the tall walls.Where MC really excels is in the 5.9+ range - there are oodles of 5.10 and 5.11 paths for the hardcore climbers, and lots of lead climbing options. The boundering area upstairs is also a good little spot, and there are plenty of friendly folks who are more than happy to give you helpful tips.I've found the climbing classes to be "ok", and you really need to be motivated to learn and ask a lot of questions to get strong benefit out of them, but still something everybody should do as they progress.People may compare IronWorks and Planet Granite, but hey, it's climbing, it's fun, leave the ego on the ground and just climb the frakin' wall. :) Climb on, baby!

Love the fact that there's a gym along with the various difficulties in climbing here.  Everybody should do indoor climbing at least once in their lives.  I actually used to have a fear of heights so I used this place as a means to get over my fears.  Sure enough, I was able to conquer my inner wussyness within a month after using this facility.  If you become addicted, it's probably best to buy your own equipment (shoes, harness, etc) at places like REI.  Life is short, climb hard.

Mission Cliffs knows rock climbers. Unfortunately, too many rock climbers know Mission Cliffs. Weekdays after work, the place is too crowded for comfortable climbing. But the fact that it is repeatedly crowded means they're doing something right. There's a relaxed atmosphere throughout the space, which is counter-intuitive to the usual grunting and testosterone found at a typical gym (I'm looking at you, Gold's.). Members are helpful and polite, the staff is cool and knowledgeable: what's not to like? Well, a few things: better ventilated locker rooms, more indoor bike parking, and a larger gym area would be great. How to accommodate these requests in a limited warehouse space is a real trick, but I'm confident that Mission Cliffs will improve its space as the members (and visitors) evolve and improve.

I have a soft spot for MC. This is where I learned how to climb. It has an excellent climbing community and is fun to hang out and do some climbs.It is definitely not as nice and modern as Planet Granite Sunnyvale or Chrissy Fields. The holds at MC are also old and soft. That is why I am removing one star from this neighborhoodly climbing gym that I enjoy going to.

I am in love with this place! I found out about it from a friend and when I moved into the neighborhood, I went immediately.I couldn't afford the initiation fees at first, so I thought I would wait. And, lo and behold, in January, there are no initiation fees! How amazing! So I joined. I climb about 2-3 times a week right now and I love it. They redo some of the routes pretty often, so there is always something new to climb. The routes are pretty dead on about the ratings (although sometimes I feel they should change them slightly). There are also a lot of different types of routes (overhangs, all arms, all legs, stretches, etc.) which makes it a lot of fun!Also, the gym workers are very nice and helpful. They are willing to teach some things here and there and they really help with the safety aspects (belaying and tie-ins). Its great! I can't wait until I get good enough to do some more lead climbing.One last thing. The community there seems great too! There are always people vying for routes during the busy times, but they are very courteous, so that is pretty nice.

Once in a while, the handholds will come loose, but I like the added thrill. It's a social sport.  I like to teach people how to belay, but of the 25 I've taught, only 2 have returned. 10/26 update: please check your harness if it's older.  RIP TS.

"Where everybody knows your name."  Can't tell you how much I love this place.  It feels like a second home sometimes.  I got into climbing over a year ago cause I hate to exercise, have a short attention span and love to hang out and talk.  So far it has been a match made in heaven.  I have met a bunch of great people, finally have some definition in my arms and found a use for brightly colored caribiners.  Did I mention how fun it is to check out hot guys and then proceed to totally whoop their asses on climbs?  Pretty satisfying all together.

As a climbing gym, Mission Cliffs is fantastic. Excellent route-setters and a fun, down-to-earth environment. The crowd varies from elite cliffhangers to people who don't even rock climb, but most everyone is friendly and approachable. The staff, in particular, is helpful, knowledgeable and very chill. Why four stars instead of five? Some of the climbing and workout equipment is a little on the vintage side, but the building just got a nice face lift that brightened things up and improved the ventilation. I have a feeling that other improvements are on the way.

This is where you want to come have fun and hang friends. It was a double date (sort of) and we decided it's time to do something different. For one day pass, class, equipment rental it is $28. Very good deal!! Instructor is very knowledgeable in instructing students. We had a great fun afternoon!!

Mission Cliffs is located on Harrison Street in San Francisco and it is a rock climbing facility as well as a workout gym area. I love  wall climbing here. The membership fee is not overpriced like similar gyms around. The staff are friendly and willing to help. I definitely recommend this place who wants to loose a few pounds and gain some muscle. If you go on weekdays before 3 pm, it is really cheap to climb but make sure you take a lesson on terms and processes because you will be tested before you're allowed to climb.

I haven't been here in a little while (and I have a 10-pack of visits gathering dust), but this climbing gym is awesome.The top-roping and bouldering are really fun (the bouldering can be very challenging), and the people who climb here are generally friendly, supportive and helpful.They also have free weights and cardio equipment so that you can warm up before hitting the walls!

First and foremost, let me say that I love Mission Cliffs! Here's why:Recently my best friend has become obsessed with exercise. Which is great, she looks awesome and has a great time doing it. I was a little skeptical when she told me she had started rock climbing. Really? Rock climbing... indoors...? But I went with her and checked it out. I am hooked. We've been going together for a few months now and I can honestly say it's my favorite way to work out since I quit playing soccer 5 years ago. It feels like a community thing. People are nice, helpful, and completely into what they're doing. And no one is too pushy or tells you what to do, or anything like that. The staff are helpful and, might I add, quite attractive. Also, hot guys! They are there! Often in the steamy confines of the bouldering area, which gets pretty crowded at times. I really don't have anything to complain about. They have a sauna. Towels. Workout equipment. $70 monthly membership rate includes unlimited yoga and kickboxing classes, which is extremely reasonable. Sure, the rentals are kind of gross, BUT, they do offer 10% off on the equipment they have for sale. Which is nice. For the record, they do spray the shoes with lysol. So it's sanitized stank....I've found that the routes are fairly well balanced when it comes to intro levels and advanced. The gym doesn't seem to be a place for super-advanced climbers, however. It'll do for me for a while.

Went here for the first time a couple of weeks ago. The climbing was fun and everything is great except the guy with the messed up face that works the front desk was a jerk. He acted like we were inconveniencing him by being there. I guess I should expect to run into arrogant hipsters in the mission but I'll probably start going to Planet Granite and never come back here just because of that guy. Hopefully the owners will get rid of him so his negative vibes won't bother anyone else. The other staff members were very nice.

While I'm fairly new to climbing, I've actually been to a number of indoor rock climbing gyms due to the fair amount of traveling I do.  And I have to say that this is my favorite by far. Yeah, I know Mission Cliffs has homecourt advantage for me (I'm a member), but they really have some great terrain, and, super helpful staff.  I mean, through and through, the staff is knowledgeble and willing to pass that on to anyone who asks. Finding a belay partner is hardly a problem and they've got plenty of wall - from vertical overhangs to stems to flakes and cracks - to test your meddle, mostly top roping but also many lead routes.  And the routes are changed on a wall-by-wall basis every couple of weeks, so things stay fresh.And, as some of the other reviewers have mentioned, they've added several classes that are free to members (or are included if you've paid for the climbing day pass); things like kickboxing and spin and yoga - good aerobic complements to the workout you get climbing. Bottom line is that if you want to start climbing (or your kids do - they host great birthday parties and after-school sessions), this is the place to do it.  By the way, if you are a member at Mission Cliffs, you can go to any of the Touchstone gyms as well (there are several around the Bay area).

Its that stressful part of the week for me again where Tuesday through Thursday just seem to run together with no break(thank goodness for the Warrior's game tonight). Last week at this same time a friend convinced me to leave class early and learn to rock climb to shake of some of the stress I had. At first I was like whatever my name isn't Tom Cruz and this ain't Mission Impossible 2.  I was wrong I am Tom Cruz. I've been wrong about a few new activities I've gotten into lately.I was kind of amazed at how I got into climbing after getting a few pointers and spending extra money on getting the right gear.   It was pretty expensive for my first trip but well worth it. Now for the climb. I was nervous only because I still have child hood nightmares of falling out of trees and windows when I was up to no good.  Once I was actually on the wall nothing mattered but getting to the top and it was also a great physical challenge. I went up twice from different spot and wow it seemed like forever to make it to the top the second time. So if you can't make it to where you're supposed to be or just need  a change of pace try Mission Cliffs for a good workout plus they have all the normal gym/fitness club stuff also.

I got into climbing ever since going to Chelsea Piers in New York. The instructors there told me to check this place out and I'm glad they did.The wall here is huge and there are lots of differing levels from 5.5 - 5.13 for crazy challenging climbs. AND it's cheap. 18$ for an entire day of climbing ($5 to rent equipment). Gym is a little outdated but has everything you need to build up your climbing muscles. No frills place with friendly people all passionate about climbing. Definitely check this place out!

Took my first rock climbing lesson here and thoroughly enjoyed my experience! I bought a groupon here with my friend so we had a pretty sweet deal. The facility is HUGE and I really like the two story thing, with the lessons being on the second floor and having a very beginners rock for it. The bouldering options is also pretty good and they've got rocks of literally every level, from small to very very high up. The little gym that they have there looks pretty legit although I have yet to try it out. Other than here I've only been to planet granite and I still prefer this place over that, if only they open one closer to where I live!

I got hooked !!!!!It was my first time rock climbing this passed Sunday. I have to admit I was little intimidated by the size of cliff when I saw the website for the first time, but once I started climbing, it was not an issue at all. My friend spent a good amount of time explaining and teaching me certain techniques before I took a test, so I was prepared enough to climb. I am glad the person who tested me asked me everything before I started climbing. It's totally safe to climb, but for a first timer like me, it was good to have lessons by my friend and a test by someone who is very knowledgeableIt was my first time climbing, so I cannot say anything about how it is compared to the other climbing gyms. It was the day after July 4th, so it was little crowded, but not so much.I had a lot of fun and would like to go back there again. The staff who I interacted were all nice.

$28 belay safety class includes an all day pass, shoe and harness rental. SO worth it!Totally beginner-friendly. I climbed here for the first time EVER last weekend  My forearms hurt like a B*#%H for two days afterwards (yes, poor technique), but it was so much fun. I would def come back  regularly if I still lived in the Bay Area.

This is the second time I've been there.  The last time I went was about 5-6 years ago for what it's worth.  Anways, I went with some buddies, and I'm sure I can speak on behalf of all of us that we had a blast.  This was a first time for all four of us, really.  The facility was great in my opinion - it wasn't too crowded when I went, but I'd imagine that if you were to go during more "peak" periods it would be insanely difficult to get your routes in.  The only reason I say four stars is that me and my three buddies found half of the staff to be helpful, but very sarcastic (not the good kind either) at the same time.  Seemed like they were almost talking down on us sometimes.All in all - great place

I hate to give 3 stars when i see so many people giving more, but I will try to give a reason:I was really enthusiastic about trying indoor rock climbing. I had never done it before. One friend told me about this place and I went to check it.Parking was very hard...Which already made me kind of worried about joining the place. The place sure was cool. But it was really sad to get there full of enthusiasm and be received by 2 bored employees at the front desk. They didn't care much about explaining me details... I told them I wanted to try and that it was gonna be my first time, asked about how it is for begginers.... All they did was hand me a flyers with prices and say that there were classes for begginers at specific times.. and that was it. less than one minute...I left and decided not to join... Because one of the things I like the most about places I exercise is being in a friendly enviroment.

I miss this place. I was a member for 1.5 years before I lost my climbing partner due to a bum shoulder and weird (but benign!) growths in his hands. Why is this place great? Unlike at major chain gyms, you don't feel like an anonymous drone in the elliptical-using, iron-pumping mass. You get to know the regular climbers (the seasoned ones will provide advice) and the people at the front desk know your name. The routes in the climbing and bouldering area change pretty regularly and there's always a good mix of easy to medium to hard routes. Sometimes, it does get crowded, but for the most part, everyone has pretty good climbing etiquette. If you're a beginner, don't be intimidated! I knew nothing about climbing before joining. This place offers plenty of classes to further improve your skills and you'll get to know the staff better too (they're great teachers!). Climbing may not be for everyone, but it's pretty darn rewarding physically and mentally if you stick with it.Oh yeah, parking is pretty easy around the back, but with the new condos coming in, the street parking may get tougher.

MC seems to me to be the crown jewel of the Touchstone gyms. The bouldering area has all the features you would expect, but nothing mind-blowing. WAY back in the day their bouldering area included a cave that went from the first floor up to the second, but they did away with that to make room for fitness equipment, which has since become somewhat dated. Surprisingly, bouldering doesn't get too crowded here during peak hours, probably because most people are taking advantage of MC's truly great walls.MC has some great top rope climbs. The back wall is really tall and always has a cool route in the corner that involves some stemming. When I start to get pumped, I head straight there to work some different muscles. One wall has a couple of overhanging parts, another has a sort of cave that you climb out of... tons of variety, typically good route setting... what more could you ask for? One quick note about the routes: they are usually easy for the grade. That is to say that a 10c at MC would be a 10a or 10b at any other gym.The real highlight of MC is the lead wall, which usually offers some great traversing routes. This probably doesn't apply to 99% of the people who read this review, though, because if you are capable of leading 12s and 13s, you probably already know this about the gym. In fact, if you're that good of a climber and you live in the bay area, you have probably already been here a bunch of times and would have little reason to look the place up on Yelp at all.

I am SOOO hooked on this place. it is a blast. I think the staff is pretty friendly too. The $28 you pay for the first time for an hour lesson and equipment is much worth it. They teach you how to tie the ropes and are really patient with you. I see some pretty ripped people that go there and it inspires me to go. I don't know about the other equipment stuff...since I do have a 24 hour fitness membership but I know that you can't go wrong with this place. a $10 day pass and $5 shoe/saddle equipment rental before 3 PM is totally worth it. The membership options are good too but I can only make it on weekends.
I like this gym and what it offers but some of the staff are pretentious and sort of rude.   the equipment is good but I wonder if the other climbing gyms have better and more knowledgeable staff.

Largest climbing facility I've been to.  They're consistent about creating fresh climbs (with funny names).  On a weekday it's cheap: $15 for an all-day pass and all equipment.  The guys with their shirts off provide delicious eye candy - or induce some shrinking, depending on your taste.  You can take a novice or beginner climber here too: spend a few minutes teaching him/her how to tie in and belay.  The staff is cool with this.  Then they'll test him/her ("What are the 5 things you need to check?") and you've got a climbing partner.  I've never gotten dropped!

(Climbing....)I recall the first time I stepped into Mission Cliffs, thinking "It seems alright (ok - I was starting to like the space by then). But it's not MetroRock (Boston, MA)."  I still miss my old climbing haunt, primarily because of friends back east, but Mission Cliffs is starting to grow on me. Great routes, helpful staff. Amazing how a course of an indoor rock climbing wall can humble you sometimes. Why go: 1. Climbing is a great workout - MC has a great variety of routes for different experience levels2. Classes (which I'm yet to experience) - They seem to have a comprehensive list of available weekly events3. Routes, cardio equipment and space4. Staff Not-so-great points:1. Location (with regards to where I live/work)2. Bathrooms / Locker Rooms get 3 stars out of 5.  3. There are kids' birthday parties held on some afternoons (well, more like every weekend). Undeniably, even I would want to have my birthday shindig here - but often the chorus of screaming kids can be very distracting. The earlier you go in the day, probably the better.  (....Climb on.)

I went climbing for the first time ever this past weekend at Mission Cliffs. I took the $28 introductory course with Steve, who was really patient and easy-to-follow. I found the class to be a great deal because it included the belaying lesson, equipment rental, and access to the entire gym. I'll need to go back to learn some climbing techniques, but I had a great time! Started out climbing the unmarked half-size walls on the second floor and eventually made my way to 5.4 and 5.5 rated climbs downstairs... although I now realize that I "cheated" as I am supposed to stay on my colour-coded path... oops! But I still get kudos for getting to the top, right?Overall, the staff at the gym were really friendly and helpful. I'm definitely a fan of the sport and of Mission Cliffs!However, I did have to take one star off because the gym has a fragrance of smelly socks... a bit yucky, especially when one is first starting out. Also, be careful not to leave anything inside your cars when parked around the gym -- there's tons of broken glass on the roads.

I've been here and it's freaking awsome....orientation is easy to understand even for those who don't speak very well English. i went with some friends and spend the whole day there. every wall has a number and that number means how difficult is to climb. i think i tried 30 something or 40 something...it was damn hard i almost gave up but i push my self to the top.. if you feel that you are in a plateau in your life right now. then try mission cliffs to feel that rush of adrenaline and feel that you are alive again. this is also a good place for a date...especially if its your first date. trust me you wont regret it.

If you want to climb/boulder in the bay area, this is the place to do it! The routes are great, the staff is always helpful and friendly... free towels, nice restrooms/showers/sauna, indoor bike parking, weight room, aerobic equipment, internet, tables... great hours... oh, and free classes for members (spinning, yoga, etc). And you can't really beat the price!

Mission Cliffs is the only gym I've never gotten sick of.  Of course it's only the third gym I've ever tried to attend with regularity, but even so there's a lesson to be learned here.  Gyms are boring.  You go, you sit in a puddle of somebody's sweat, you displace some mass.  Repeat 3x weekly.  I've never been able to keep that up for more than six months before the tedium became more than even the most diverse ipod could relieve.Mission Cliffs (and by extension climbing gyms, but this is the one I go to) turns that paradigm on its ear.  You go, you look at a puzzle, and you use "the biggest muscle you have--your brain!" (as Laura said to Urkel in the episode where he built a jetpack to get to the top of a rope), in conjunction with your other smaller muscles, to reason through it.  At other gyms, doing other workout routines, there's no motivation to push yourself--or if there is it's semi-abstract, eg the goal of fabulous muscles.  When you climb, the goal is very real, very tangible, and the fabulous muscles come as if by magic, a side effect of repeatedly pushing yourself to the top.

I don't really know of any other climbing places but this one is pretty awesome. I went to a pretty posh private high school so I went here every Friday and rock-climbed which was really awesome. I mean you think that you might get tired of rock-climbing but they are constantly charnging the routes and naming it really funny things.  They had a "CSI" and "Lost" climbs.  I'm not sure if the way you climbed them really reflected the show but it was weird to be climb the "Friends" rock pathway. During the whole way I was trying to decipher that possibly the rocks were friends characters and kept plaing old episodes in my head and before I knew it I was at the top and relived several seasons.  Sweet.

Mission Cliffs stinks, but only in terms of the locker room smell. The quality of the routes are excellent and the people are generally friendly. Its the best place in the city to get your climbing in. Oh wait, its the only place (for now).

What an awesome place!It's huge, with tons of climbs, which are changed up rather regularly.  I don't see how anyone could get bored here.  Plus there's also yoga.  And bouldering.  And cardio equipment.  And weights.  There really isn't the need for a regular gym membership.  Everything is here!Plus they offer cool clinics and workshops and classes which will help you get the most out of your climbing or bust out of your climbing rut.  Everyone here is such an expert-- but not a jerk about it at all.  Just very helpful and passionate about climbing.Sure, there are times when it gets busy, but I've also found times when it's really quiet and laid-back as well.  Just depends what kind of mood you're in.There's also a very respectable gear shop with most everything you'll need to look cool climbing.  Of course, they also do equipment rentals as well.  I mean, what don't they do?  Mission Cliffs just amazes me.  I can't imagine moving someplace where there isn't a climbing gym as good as this one.

OH boy! I like Mission Cliffs a lot. I had never been indoor rock climbing before I came here, but I'm glad this was the place to start off my rock climbing endeavors. My boyfriend and I had been wanting to come here, and for the record, this is a great place to go if you and your hubby want to try something new. Anywho, so we came in for the 2 o' clock session, and apparently it was some special because we ended up paying 20 dollars per person versus 28. Our instructor..I don't remember her name..was kind of mean. She trained us, but got REALLY frustrated with me for not getting the hang of tying the ropes and what not. What! I'm a newbie. Give me a break! After I practiced the steps OVER and OVER..I finally got it, so she became more tolerable. Honestly, she made me more nervous than comfortable. Moving on. Once our instructor decided we were ready to venture on our own, she gave us a pass to roam around and find other rocks to climb. I had a blast!

I love climbing. I love having my ass kicked. I love it when I notice that I'm doing it better than I did last time. I love hanging out and talking crap.Gets kinda crowded. Kinda too pricey for my broke ass. But those problems can't be helped.

You'll find me here a couple of days a week minimum. Yep, I like climbing, so I love Mission Cliffs. Why not 5 stars? It is getting very crowded lately.Hawk and Flea design the best routes. Keep up with them, guys!

This place is great.  VERY accommodating welcoming of new climbers.  They have  tons of routes of various levels from super easy to OMFG difficult (5.13b).  Lead climbing, top rope, bouldering, they even have tons of yoga classes here as well.  And enough weights/cardio equipment to get a weight lifting/cardio workout in too.  A fantastic deal for $71 a month.  SUPER FUN

Yes, Mission Cliffs is great for climbing, but I actually use it for yoga almost as much. The teachers are really friendly and good and for unlimited classes at the $69 monthly membership fee it is such a deal for the yoga alone. I wish the gym area were bigger, but I know they've been trying to expand, so hopefully it's only a matter of time.

I've been climbing here for over 4 years and have loved every minute of it.  The place is huge and has a wide variety of routes and bouldering problems.  They have also recently added classes like boxing and spinning.I have also enjoyed the wide range of people at the gym and the low key atmosphere.  If you are new the the city this would be a great place to meet new peopleoh yeah, it's great exercise too.
