When I decided it was time to join a gym, my mind went through the same routine it would always go through when thinking of joining a gym - I'm going to pay some ridiculous initiation fee, go for two weeks, then never see the place again.Mission Cliffs was able to change this for me.  Not only is it a great way to keep fit, but it's also incredibly fun.  Once you get over your fear of heights.  And get over the fear of the rope breaking.  And learn to trust the person belaying you.But these aren't the hurdles everyone has, per se.The upsides to the place is it's relatively cheap compared to other gyms, it has the standard gym equipment if you feel like doing some cardio (although you can cardio on the walls...technically), towels, great staff, and the locker room is usually pretty clean.The only downside I can think of is that on the weekends it's kind of like a Chuck E. Cheese with all the kids running around, but as long as they stay off the 10a routes they are easy to ignore.

I have been climbing at Mission Cliffs for a few years now.  Great, helpful staff. The rock climbing set-up is amazing - routes for all levels, and a large bouldering area.  They've just recently added more cardio machines and I've never had to wait for one, even during peak hours. Excellent free weight area too.Thursday nights are particularly crowded, so you can literally be climbing over someone, and you have to be careful that someone is not going to repel onto your head.Good classes - I've taken the spin classes and yoga. The studio is big, clean and well lit.

Man, if you don't remember that you are a total fat ass... come here. I forgot that I'm some huge monster of height and weight and went rock climbing today.... I have spent 10 minutes writing this so far because I can't fully use my fore arms... so numb. some dude was showing off by doing pull ups with his pinkie, or something else unbelievably amazing awesome. My friend totally kicked my ass on the walls.I'll be back you 5.10, and I will conquer you!

Man, I miss living in Berkeley.  I miss Ironworks.  I am one of the lucky ones who gets to go to the climbing gym during weekdays from 10-12 when NO ONE is out climbing.  Alas, since I have moved to SF I typically prefer to drive to Berkeley for my climbing fix, because spending 25 minutes looking for parking takes more time than driving over the bridge.  There was even a time when I gave up and went home.I have a membership at another gym because the weights room at MC sucks compared to, say, Ironworks.  I do like climbing in the back, the new space which is usually less crowded and better lit and ventilated.  It'll do in a pinch, Mission Cliffs.

I have been climbing at Mission Cliffs for about 6 years - ever since I moved to San Francisco. I love it. I love that they change the routes regularly. I love that I find cool people there, and have made friends from climbing. I love the staff, who, while sometimes a bit too-cool-for-school, clearly love what they do. I love that they've added walls and classes, and fitness equipment, too. (Though I would swoon if they added those treadmills with the TVs attached to them! How bout it, guys?)I might have to move from the Bay Area (for job reasons and long-distance relationship reasons). When I think about moving, MC is one of the first things I think about missing. I wish I could bring it with me. Most big cities don't have gyms like this (okay, SF has more than one) - and if they do, they are EXPENSIVE. I love MC also for being affordable.My one complaint is that climbing has gotten trendy over the past several years - even with the addition of new walls over the years, MC is REALLY REALLY crowded at certain times of the week. So... even though it is wonderful, I don't want you to join - because I want it all to myself, all the time.

I LOVE Mission Cliffs. They changed my life and because of them I am a pretty good climber. The staff is great & professional and the classes awesome. Franco rocks as teacher :)  The BEST climbing gym in 3 states (NY, AK & CA) :) Thanks Kristen, Mike, Steve (No longer there), Kelly (no longer there), Adam (no longer there), Jonathan, Sherry (bad ass chick), Donna and the new girls whose name escapes me. Stephanie? Love them all. Thanks Mission Cliffs for changing my life :) xoxo

I love this place, as well as Berkeley Iron Works in the East Bay. My only complaint...not enough up-to-date cardio equipment.  But then again, this is a rock climbing gym, not a full service health club.  It's great for what it is. Next time, though, I'll stick with bouldering.   I need to find a real, strong man who can belay me on the main wall.  (But isn't that always what a good woman is looking for? lol)Last time I climbed with my close Asian female friend.  I am a tall, full figured Black woman.  Needless to say, when it was time for me to come down, I lifted her off the floor!  That's a little bit of a hit to the ego.  Kinda made me feel fatter. So, alas, I need to go with a strapping man next time.  Any takers? Good workout.  It is mad fun.  It gets crowded on the weekends, so be patient and listen VERY CAREFULLY to the belay instructions.

I've been spoiled by Mission Cliffs. The chill staff, the cool music, the myriad climbs... and the bouldering! You don't think it's much, tucked away in the corner over by the cardio equipment, but then you see just how extensive and challenging it is. The facilities are well maintained and  fellow climbers have been - in my experience - courteous and friendly.The climbs are fun and get you to twist in ways that you weren't aware you could do what with gravity, basic laws of physics, the unspoken yet universally acknowledged guidelines on how not to contort yourself into unsettling positions. It's just glorious.

Ugh. This place just bugs me. Well, really it is just one guy behind the counter. Of the four times I've been there, he's been royally stuck up three of those times. (He wasn't there the other time). Climbing gyms can have an amazing atmosphere, but having to deal with this guy (he's the shorter older employee) as soon as I've entered always leaves me with a bad taste. He's rude, doesn't explain anything and just generally doesn't exemplify the relaxed, welcoming atmosphere I want from a climbing gym.Relax dude. Just be nice.

This place has it all.. and that means a lot of people are here too :) If you like the social scene, you'll find that here. If you're more of a loner climber (with a buddy, of course), you'll have to come in the off hours. I'm kind of in between, but this place rocks climbing!.

Perfect for climbing - great variety of routes, helpful staff, mellow crowd.  There's also a cardio area which is pretty basic (just what I really need).  The women's locker room is well kept.  I'm a fan!

This is definitely a fine gym if it the most convenient option for you. The walls are tall and there are quite a few route, but if you going during their peak times, there will be mobs of people.  You might need to wait for an open rope. You might feel pressured by others to finish up on your rope and move along. If you try to go bouldering, try not to fall on anybody or get fallen on.

Having been climbing both indoors and out for over ten years I say with confidence that Mission Cliffs is somewhere between "seriously hella sick" & "bomb diggity".Are there really that many hot people out climbing every day?  Yes.Not the social type?  Go early.  Want to rub elbows with cool peeps having fun?  Go late.The bouldering section is one of the most diverse I've seen between here and Reno & the walls offer problems which keep me up at night.  Actually, just because of the bouldering, I went about six years before discovering that chimney route at the opposite end of the gym!The downside?  Finding one of these sick routes too late & not sending it before another sick route takes its place.The staff?  Someone needs to bring these people donuts.
really packed, but a great environment. people are very friendly

I've climbed here a few times, and have enjoyed myself each time. They have a nice variety of climbs - from beginning to crazy upside down stuff. The staff is very friendly, and the people watching is great! It's laid back and attitude-free. It may be on the smaller side, but at least you won't get overwhelmed if you're a novice like me.
Staff was friendly and helpful. There are some good long climbs. The place gets crowded, though. And parking in that area is not great.

There's so much to write about this gym that I'm just going to sum it up with this.  Mission Cliffs isn't just a gym, it's a family.  The best gym experience I've ever had.  I worked as a personal trainer for 3 years with two of the largest gyms in the country and they just don't compare.  This isn't just a climbing gym either.  Their weight room is simple but fantastic and aerobic/yoga classes are some of the best I've ever seen. No matter where you are in the bay, this gym is worth the trek.

Excuse the colloquialism here, but, Mission Cliffs SF smells like dog.I could give it 5 stars because I love climbing, but judging on its being a climbing facility, Mission Cliffs SF is lacking in one too many ways. If you love the smell of hippies and sweaty feet, this is the place for you. Of course, I'm being high maintenance with that remark, since once you're 15 feet above the fray, the air gets better (albeit warmer). Coming from the brand new Planet Granite in Sunnyvale, however, my olfactory senses were at once offended. Yes, the terrain and routes here are more varied and consistent than at PG, but even after a few wonderful sessions I couldn't help but wrinkle my nose and look longingly at the doorway that promises fresh air. Bouldering is essentially impossible because of the stench below - are climbers deathly opposed to deodorant?! The locker room is just as filthy and run-down, if not more grotesque with all that sloppy wetness. Whatever semblance of a "gym" they attempted on the upper level doesn't work, because climbers don't want to bulk up, and hippies just aren't into that sort of thing. I've heard many great things about their yoga and pilates classes, however, I cannot personally so comment for lack of participation. Anyway, I'd rather be holding on for dear life in the wild or going back over to Planet Granite than to get my climbing fix here. But then, of course, if you are used to wearing nose plugs or are more hardcore than I am, then I'm sure you don't even know what I am talking about.

went indoor rock climbing for the first time ever. was SOOOOOOOO fun! i seriously would have kept going if the place didn't close!my friend taught me the basics, and they tested me to make sure i knew how to tie the climber knot and belay. while i was working on my knot, my "tester" had to go do something and another older guy came and took his place and he was kind of intimidating. i felt a little interrogated, and after he saw that i was getting flustered, he eased up and softened his tone a little bit. but after the test, it was all fun from there! they have many difficulty levels of climbing, and it's nice to have a graduation of challenges. to see your goal, and to be able to accomplish it within a day is an awesome feeling. then i kept wanting to go to the next level and try. and it's a really fun activity to do w/friends or even a casual date while getting a work out.

a friend invited me to boulder and work out at mission cliffs today, so i jumped to re-check out this climbing gym. and... i was kinda let down. we started off bouldering,could have been the extraordinarily busy, but it was crowded and lots of bros jockeying for routes. i wasnt feelin it.  Still got a good 2h session of climbing, weights and cardio but this place feel short of what i see at Planet granite.
Love it best during the day (less crowded.) Great variety and levels of routes. Meets all my needs.
Great indoor climbing.  Bouldering area is especially fun.  Friendly for first-timers.

i think one of my old old friendster (shoot ... that means i have to login to the site) testimonials sums up the great experience of mission cliffs:"Spiff turned down a career in rocket science for a desk job. I think it's just so she can say, "it's not rocket science!" to her co-workers when they inevitably look bumbling compared to her. They would have felt a little consolation if they had seen her dangling off of the rock climbing wall unable to complete a measely level 10. Well untill next week anyways when she climbed to the top and rang the bell repeatedly untill she was asked to stop by someone who worked there."this is the greatest indoor climbing place i've come across outside of cornell's lindseth wall ... each time you go, you leave with a great sense of accomplishment and rockin arms

Cool place! Friendly, helpful staff. Good climbs all over ranging in many difficulties from very easy to very difficult. Uses the standard rating system for climbing. Also have a decent sized bouldering area. I recommend coming during the day in the middle of the week otherwise you will definitely be waiting for a climb. Slightly pricey, but no more than most climbing gyms. Also have a very small weight and cardio gym inside.
I love everything about this gym. Ease of getting in and out, being able to work out and boulder in one session, the atmosphere (industrial-modern-crunch), the friendly people.

I've been climbing here for 3 or 4 years and do not plan on switching to that other gym anytime soon!  The staff is super duper friendly and helpful.  The people here are great.  I often go by myself and pickup a random partner.  The routes are fun and challenging (more so than the "other gym" in the city)  = )  Mission Cliffs was just approved to expand into the building next door which will include a brand new fitness area and additional bouldering.  Can't wait!  If you're deciding on a climbing gym to join... look no farther!  This place is great for young and old alike.  The kiddies will need a signed parental waiver to climb.

Damn, I sure do suck at indoor rock climbing. Sad I know. But I still had fun even though I felt like I had a wedgie the whole time and my arms we're burning like crazy when I left. I definitely wont wear jeans next time especially low-rise because I was paranoid the whole time that my butt crack was exposed. Parking is right on the street and no meters people! I know, effin' sweet.

Great place to climb on weekday nights, rainy afternoons, and other times when there is no way you could be outside. Really cool staff, good walls, and open until 11.oo pm on Tuesdays and Thursdays! Don't recommend going to weekend afternoons, because there are usually lots and lots of people, way too many kids, and you'll probably have to wait to climb.

get's SUPER crowded weeknights, but pretty empty weekends. And once it gets crowded... damn the funk is on. Pretty good routes to climb, a lof of lead climbing routes. Staff is alright, nothing negative or positive on that front to comment about.Prices are reasonable, and better than planet granite.Def worth the trip, not sure about the membership.

Great climbing gym, friendly staff and nice equipment.  Climbing gives a nice alternative to the traditional free weights, leg presses and treadmills.  It's a friendly environment where you can chat it up with other climbers.  There is a wide range of skill levels so you don't have to feel intimidated if you can't climb a 5.11b yet, there are plenty of 5.5-5.9 levels around.  The gym membership is $60 a month which includes full access to their cardio equipment and normal weight lifting area, free classes for yoga, pilates, spinning, etc.  They also group events outside of the gym coordinated a few times each month.

Decent lead climbing and ok bouldering make this a pretty average climbing gym.  The planned expansion will hopefully give this gym some elbow room.  Because the biggest complaint I have is that it's quite crowded, often, and it's simply too busy to get a great customer experience.  And due to size constraints it's got a pretty meager fitness gym.  Ironworks and GWPC have much better equipment and much larger workout areas, if that's what you need from your gym.I've been a member for a few years and I come here regularly, but it does have some room for improvement.  They definitely need a revamped air handling system, because the funk does get out of hand sometimes.  The lockerooms definitely need better ventilation.I do have a good time at this gym and I'm not going to stop coming, but I'd love to see some upgrades.  Also, it's been 3 months since the routes were changed.  I'd love to see more regular route setting, so we(members) don't get bored out of our minds.

Solid gym, but very crowded.  If I could, I'd give them 3.5 stars, but I'm leaving room for improvement.  Great routes and vibe, but overly crowded with a tiny gym area.  Worth checking out, but don't expect the perfect gym.

It's the best place in San Francisco you can go for the most all over body work out you can get.  They're not cheap but competitively priced and you really don't have choices in San Francisco to chose from.  I love the way my body feels after a workout.  It's seriously the best exercise that won't bore you to tears.  I'm there every week, sometimes more, and wish I could fit it in every day.  Love it.

Have to give it 4 stars since I've been a member here for years and years and until PG opened in the Presidio it was the only place to get a climbing workout in SF - so I come here 2-3 nights a week. The route setters are pretty solid and set for both small and tall people (I am small), routes are consistent in ratings, and the people that work the desk are mostly super friendly and cool. I am a member at PG and can say I like the routes at MC much better. One star off because the crowds are insane any workday after 6pm, wish it was open until 11pm more than just Tues and Thurs because of said crowds, gym equipment is old, and climbs could be changed more frequently. Otherwise its a stellar place for indoor climbing.
Hard to believe, but it's been the first time I've ever been literally tied up. Only partner up with someone you trust... That doesn't have ADD for seizures. That would suck

I go here a lot...cause it's close to where I live.  But there are definitely places that are better and cleaner than here.  Does not smell that great in the bouldering area...especially in the afternoon.  Try to go in the morning, less people, less sweat...less waiting.  The crowd there is pretty friendly...give it a shot..you might like it more than I am giving it credit for.
As a member I've really enjoyed the climbing and yoga.  It's great for beginner climbers.  Can get busy at times, but that also creates a fun vibe.

Mission Cliffs offers an exhilarating, fun, and completely out of the ordinary way to get a workout.  I love the constantly changing courses (it seems like they change them up monthly) and friendly atmosphere.  The only problems are that it can get a little crowded late in the day and it can be a little expensive, if your not a member.
i have been here several times to go climbing and it is definitely a good climbing gym. there are plenty of routes and levels to choose from.parking is also pretty good in the area.

must say that i was very impressed with this spot. never actually been rockclimbing in the outside world but have had a great time in the cozy confines of a wherehouse in the mission. the place is very clean and has a nice fitness center as well. the staff was very friendly and helpful and you feel very safe with them holding your lines. i have heard from many that this spot gets very crowded during peak hours and weekends so i would have to recommend only going on weekdays in the mornings. but its very possible to have a great time here. if you have any interest in climbing this is the best spot in the city.

A very big and fun climbing gym with lots of natural light and without a total bro-jock vibe. And they have kids programs. On the downside it's expensive, very very dusty and they don't have a roommate or domestic partner membership. They also use harsh smelling cleaning chemicals while they are open which is always sad when you are doing cardio and breathing heavily. The yoga/ fitness class room has no windows which is sad.

I love Mission Cliffs even though it gets really busy and it is hard to find a spot to climb sometimes. But if you go earlier in the day, it is lovely - no crowd at all! I have started going to the yoga classes and really like the Wednesday 7 pm classes. I am looking forward to trying the kickboxing classes. Nice, cute, friendly and funny staff ;-)  Because the gym is so popular with climbers, rocks do get slippery so take tons of chalk with you!

I have to admit that I'm new to climbing, so you can take my opinion with a grain of salt. I liked the gym overall, and would go back if I had more time in the bay area. i went last wednesday night and was impressed by the selection of routes, BUT it was way to busy to comfortably climb many of them. When I finally got on a route someone rudely passed me on a route that crossed mine without saying a word. kinda pissed me off. And then...it happened to my partner...twice. I would definitely not go back on a wednesday night and try my luck some other time in hopes of finding a more courteous crowd.
I'm under the impression that Mission Cliffs rates their routes a bit easier than other gyms, but when you are trying to show off to a hot climbing partner that definitely works in your favor.
Where I go to feel weak and under-defined.  Seriously though, rock climbing is really, really, really fun.

Granted they do have a great set up. Granted I haven't been there in a few years. Granted it is really cool to have a rock climbing gym in the middle of the Mission District.....Nonetheless, I feel the need to balance some of these glowing recommendations with some of my experiences at that Gym.I am not a cute tattooed 20 something. I'm not flirty. I'm not edgy. I definitely don't look like most people's image of a rock climber.However, I really like climbing. I wanted to show my kids how much fun rock climbing can be and teach them a few basic knots and how to belay. When we went to the Gym, we were completely ignored for 15 minutes while the attendants flirted with a departing customer who was 20, cute, flirty and edgy. We waited and I tried to keep my kids still while I tried to fill out the paperwork and get registered. After about 10 minutes of no attention whatsoever, on of my kids went and sat on a weight machine and grabbed the lift bar. We got a glare for that and I quickly pulled my son off the machine. No one spoke with us, but one of the attendants went over to the now vacated weight machine and wiped of some invisible fingerprints left by my 8 year old son. When I finally did speak to an attendant, he was cold and unfriendly and let me know that I could not teach my own kids and that we would have to take a class but there were no classes available now. We left.I tried to go back again with just my older son on another occasion. Again, we were ignored for an extended period of time. During the wait period, as the desk attendant finished an interminable telephone conversation, my son an I floated over to the edge of a group learning knots with a teacher. I was pointing to what they were doing and whispering names to my son, when the desk attendant approached me and informed me that we would have to pay $40 each if we wanted to join the class. Properly chastened, we went back to the desk and waited again. After another 5 minutes, we were allowed to sign up my son for a one hour slot with a belay er from the gym (I was not authorized of course, to belay my son). I do think the gym is a great idea. I would love to support it and be part of its community. However it does suffer a tinge of elitism. Its a lot more fun to head up to Glen Park or Berkeley's Indian Rock and boulder,  than to pay buckets of cash to snotty nosed, lycra clad desk clerks/athletes with attitude...

Not participating in many daytime (or shall I say, daylight) activities much, when a friend suggested we go rock-climbing, it brought instant memories of my once athletic youthfulness. I climbed here before, years ago... this place has grown up so much. Great place; however at times it can be hectic... unsupervised kids running around, lack of identifiable employees if you need help.. but the single most worst thing is the smell. After an hour or two it still gets hard to bear the funk.

Not bad for a birthday adventure. Aside from the horrible smell of feet, Mission Cliffs is a great place to get a workout and have fun at the same time. I heard about this place through my cousin who said that he had a really great time. I concur. Just get some Air Wick going on because the feet smell is not good. =( LOL
Wow, it's a lot bigger than the last time I went there in the 90's.  :)  Great venue for parties too...  Go wellsphere.com!
Great place..  cheap happy hour midday rates.. friendly staff and huge variety of skill level rocks to climb.  i just started and its a great place for beginners.

Hit this place up on Sunday for a birthday party- great fun, even for a first-timer- you have to start somewhere, right? I think the whole party enjoyed it, and after the staff had checked out our knots and knowledge, we were off climbing.  Don't know about a membership, but it's a great time, and a good workout- we were all ready for lunch afterwords. Give it a try!

J says: Fun fun fun!  My first time climbing and this was a good place to start.  We missed the safety course (they run one for beginners/people who need a refresher a couple of times/day) but the guy at the check-in was really nice and took time out to just teach our little group of 4.  The walls all have clearly marked paths of varying difficulties and it wasn't too crowded this Sunday afternoon so I was able to try out a number of different climbs.  $18 for a day pass and then $5 to rent shoes & gear, pretty reasonable we thought.

great place to climb for beginners and fun environment.  the staff is really nice.  good climbs toomy only negative thing to say is like any gym it gets really crowded from 6-8pm during the middle of the week and it is really distracting.  also some of the music sucks.  there is a guy who plays Tool alot.  thxalso a bit expensive for a one shot.  seems over $20 to climb once is a bit for a beginner because your hands will only hold out for an hour or maybe two.

Of all the climbing gyms that Touchstone owns, this one is the best. It's the biggest, their routes are the most interesting, and the climbers are serious. The reason for this review today is that they have (finally) updated their locker rooms and it's just a much more happy experience to shower and change there now. I have been climbing for almost two years, but never wanted to spend any time in the locker rooms... until now! Also try GWPC in Oakland; they're never too crowded.

I would give it 5 *'s as it's really rad-@$$, but i'm partial to berkeley ironworks 'cause it seems bigger, and as we all know bigger is better.  the staff is friendly, some of the routes are 50' high, which I think is super, and there's lots of variety.  can be crowded on T-W-Th weeknights, but they just expanded it with a cool rib thing and other hossly features that disperse crowds.  like the arch.  yep, about says it.

So on my most recent trip back to SF, I had to check out Mission Cliffs....again. I went for the first time a couple of years ago and was mostly impressed but that was back when I was a gym newbie...so what did I know?? This time...not so impressed but easily fixable. First of all I have to say the people at the desk (especially the older baldish guy) were extremely nice. I brought 2 friends with me, 1 never had climbed before and the other had climbed like twice in her life. The girl at the desk said I could show them what to do then she would check them out. We were upstairs and I was going over belaying with them. I was tied in and climbing up few feet, just so she could get the real feel of it.  This guy was nearby teaching a class and runs over to me and basically screams at me and tells me I shouldn't be climbing when I am not being belayed properly. I didn't realize I was really "climbing" a 5.4 anyways. So the whole checking off process of my friends took too long. There was only one girl who was checking everyone out, they just seemed under staffed. And I also noticed that no one really walks around the floor like they do at other gyms I have been to.The one thing I really liked about this gym was the longer routes. Most gyms only have like 30 feet walls so that extra 10 feet really makes a difference and I Ioved it. I really enjoyed a few of their routes. The bouldering area was ok. The crash pads looked pretty beat. And it was also pretty crowded up there, too crowded then what I thought it should be for a beautiful Sunday afternoon. The place did seem a little dirty and outdated to me but we are climbers and we like dirt!

I love this place.  I climb about once a week.  The staff here is really nice and their class for beginners is GREAT!  Be ready to pony up som dough - it's about $20 to climb and another $5 or so for rental.  If you're going to climb regularly, you can get a 10 visit pass which cuts the cost a bit, but the membership is worth it if you go often enough.  The gym is a bit quaint - the walls are definately the focal point.
A fun way to workout --two days later my shoulders are still sore.

First of all, I love rock climbing.  That said, Mission Cliffs is OK, but could use some work.  The bouldering area gets crowded after work, they don't change up the problems very often and the crash pads really suck.  For the amount of time I've spend doing routes, I've been pretty satisfied. (agree w/ others that the ratings are inconsistent) The other climbers a generally pretty friendly; though the desk staff not so much.  I know this is mainly a climbing gym, but the cardio and weight area are definitely lacking.  Very limited and old equipment.  This place has been sufficient for now, but I'm looking forward to Planet Granite opening in the Presidio.

This place is amazing!  The staff is helpful, friendly, and full of information and knowledge!  It is an ideal and fun way to workout.  Massive rock climbing walls that build muscle and challenge the mind, giving you both a physical and mental workout.  There is also a decent amount of gym equipment (weights, treadmills, etc.)  You can either drop in or pay month-to-month (without a year contract).  For all you singles out there, this place attracts many good looking men, if that doesn't motivate you......I think it's a good way to spend an open afternoon or to just get out of the apartment and try something new.  You may not be able to climb up the ranks in your job but I swear after a few trys you'll be on the top of Mount Everest!

I went for my first time ever and my friend took me bouldering. A word to the wise, if you haven't been before be sure to either do something where you are strapped in with a rope or are being spotted and be sure to move the crash pads underneath you. It was fun, until I fell and broke my ankle. I had to get surgery and be off it for 2 months. I'm fit, but I am a klutz and probably take too many risks with my body, thinking I'm immune. After I fell the workers were really nice, and they told me what I did was nothin. They'd seen much worse. Hmm, woulda been nice to know that ahead of time. Anyhow, try it out, it's fun and invigorating, but respect your body's limits and do what you need to make sure you are safe. I learned the hard way.

Where I usually climb (Sweden), you follow the color of the holds rather than the tape. The route setting style is also rather different from what I'm used to. Sadly, I prefer the European route setting. But, leaving that out...Huge plus for towel service. Yay!I am also a big fan of the walls in the back. However, ropes and holds are dirty and worn out in a few places. It's not like the ropes are going to break, but we've had to abort climbs halfway through because ropes have expanded somehow and won't fit the standard equipment we've been using. Bummer. Also, some of the climbers can be very obnoxious and rude, not giving way to other people. I really hate that.

if you don't have a climbing partner, it's okay!!  the front desk is super helpful and they'll use the PA system to help you find one.  usually someone comes up to you in like 2 minutes!oh, i think the one girl with the glasses is really rude to everyone & not helpful at all.  she always think you're wrong & is an idiot.  i had handed this other guy my keys & id card for the belaying device because i didn't want to carry anything, and when i went to pick my stuff up she only gave me my keys.  and i'm told her i gave them my id card too, and she just scoffed at me (because she couldn't find it).  so she just thought i was retarded, but it turns out that she dropped my id card when grabbing my keys.

For some reason, I've jumped out of an airplane but I've never gotten up the gumption to try rock climbing...till last weekend.  My friends got me in on their monthly guest pass (score!) and shoe/harness rentals were just $5 (didn't get a belay hook thingie).  It was really really intimidating-looking at first, all those knobby things (hmmm...) protruding all the way up the monstrously high walls, but once you get going it isn't that bad!  Sure, all my muscles hurt for two days straight, but no matter... And the people here were really chill and non-competitive, which is nice.  I was worried about muscle-bound aggro-freaks but everyone was laid back...and lotsa buff people to gaze at.

I've been climbing in the Bay Area for about 1.5 years now. I am a member at Planet Granite, but a 10-pass holder at Mission Cliffs. I've been to PG San Francisco, PG Sunnyvale, PG Belmont and Mission Cliffs.I haven't been back to Mission Cliffs in a couple months, but I finally went back to try to use up my 10-pass. Note, I am going to rate the facility, not rate the sport of rockclimbing. Here are my impressions:PLUSES:1. I like the features of the rock. Tall walls, with interesting features in places. 2. The place is a little more relaxed. In Planet Granite, you are not allowed to teach your friend how to belay and tie-in. They don't care at Mission Cliffs... if your friend passes the test, he passes the test, doesn't matter how he learned. I like that philosophy.3. More attractive men, by far. ;-) Although I'm married, so doesn't matter to me, but maybe it is important to some others out there.MINUSES:1. The gym is poorly maintained, given the traffic. I prefer Planet Granite. Planet Granite is cleaner... but more importantly, Planet Granite routes use better holds that aren't just tape marked. In my opinion, Mission Cliffs probably gets the same amount of traffic as Planet Granite (thus, make the same amount of revenue, given prices are pretty equivalent), but they refuse to invest in new holds. They reuse old ones over and over again.. and they mark routes with tape. Planet Granite, on the other hand, typically has nice, newer holds and uses the same color holds to mark a route. Also, when the carpet gets worn out, PG replaces the carpet at a greater frequency than MC. I don't understand why Mission Cliffs is hoarding our money... and refuses to invest in making the gym nicer, given PG SF opened, and they now have competition.2. Ratings are sandbagged. Climbed a 5.10b as a warm-up, thinking it would be a good warm-up. It was like a 5.9.3. Staff has attitude. Well the girl at the desk had attitude, maybe the other staff members are fine. I was on my 9th day of my 10 pass.. and I don't mind that she asked me to show my belay card. But my belay card accidentally ripped off, given it is just a piece of paper. So I didn't have it. I explained it to her (and I have a lead climbing belay card from Planet Granite on my harness)... and she still treated me like I was trying to circumvent the system and get in the gym w/o taking the belay test (even though I told her I lost it, and I am happy to take another belay test). She gave me attitude, and gave me the impression that she thought I was lying. She asked me to sign another waiver.. which is fine, I don't mind. But to me, it seemed a little ridiculous. I am on my 9th pass of 10, so I am sure I couldn't have gotten in the gym on the previous 8 times without signing the waiver at some point.  There were even a couple of newbies taking the belay test, and they also were complaining about her horrible attitude. Get some nicer staff people, especially since there is now a competing gym in SF.
Shits getting way too crowded

lovely climbing gym. it's nice and big, with lots of walls to climb, tons of top ropes and routes, and skylights at the top that let in natural light. they have a gang of cardio and strength training equipment as well.the staff was super helpful. the other patrons were just as friendly. my pal and i came, took the safety class, and climbed until we couldn't make fists with our hands anymore.

this place has kind of changed my life.after my first visit I realized that my standard exercising routine for the past year has been missing:1. happy, smiling people around me.2. a mental challenge.3. joy.4. big windows with lots of pretty light.5. a clean locker room6. healthy looking patrons.so as soon as it was possible i ran to that nasty corporate chain workout place that i've been going to and quit, with a really big smile.then i joined mission cliffs.
An exceptional climbing gym with lots of varied terrain, from the debutante to absurdly difficult. Unfortunately it can get somewhat crowded during the evenings.

A really good place to rock climb.  The staff is nice.  You need to pass a test before you can climb but they're helpful enough.  It cost $23 for a one day pass with rentals but I'm not sure if that's a good price or not.  It was really crowded when I got there so don't be afraid to grab an open rope, even if someone is climbing near your path.  Just wait for the person to be done then head on up.  They had a good variety of challenging paths so overall it was a good time.  The crowd seems really nice too.  Nobody was acting like an arrogant jerk or anything.

Nice place to climb whether you're just getting started or getting ready to take your shot at the Nose on El Capitan.  Routes and boulder problems for rock monkeys of all levels.  Plus, if you don't have a belay partner, they will get on the PA, make an announcement, and find one for you!

Having been brought back into the climbing fold this year by a friend, my experiences with MC have been great! I took the beginner class just to make sure I wasn't going to make a complete ass of myself. I hoped it would be a little of safety and a little techinique, but it is called a "safety" class, so that's basically all we did. If  you have a friend willing to show you the ropes don't bother with the class. I like that yoga, spinning, and kickboxing classes are included in the $63 membership. I used to go to Saturday morning yoga, but a combination of being busy and lazy has stopped that routine. I'd like to try a weeknight yoga class, but considering I'm there Tuesday and Thursday most weeks, another day seems kinda insane. Tips:eating something before climbing - cliff bar, sushi, whatevs - it helps!go during the day or after 8pm or on a weekend to avoid major crowdsyou don't need your own belay device, you can borrow one from themif you do decide to buy gear, members get a discount that makes it the same price as say REI or Amazon, plus you get to feel good about supporting a local business.

just changed gyms and left mission cliffs. and now i've realized that i was really just in gym-despair and so used to the annoyed guys who didn't know how to lift weights and broken cardio machines that i thought it was actually better than it was. nope. far worse.rockclimbing areas still seem great. wayyyyy too crowded. gym equipment is broken and outdated. oh well...

I haven't been here for about 7 or 8 years and the service Patrick and I got were not good.  We paid for the gear and we had to test on ropes not once did the guy come and show us how to tie the ropes. Two stars for this place.

five stars for a fun workout and tons of free yoga and no meatheads and close to home and work and indoor bicycle parking and no initiation fee january.mission cliffs is my favorite new feel-good hang-out.

well i went on a Thursday night. $23 for rental and to climb. + $5 for lessonsFrank was our teacher and he was really patient and strict about safety.a little crowded but i guess i went at the right time. Warning: it was somewhat energy consuming and i got a little finger and feet cramps as a first time climber.  highly recommend people with strong upper body strength

Decent climbing. However I agree with the others. The walls are filthy please take some time to clean the walls, overhangs, and the beams at the top. Also stop playing music that puts people to sleep. People are working out and pushing themselves up these walls. Playing music that makes Morrissey sound like the most upbeat artist alive is pretty sad at a gym and climbing center.

I will title this: "Fat kid, in the skinny gym."I could gush about Mission Cliffs for pages, but I'll try and keep it short.I am probably the least fit regular in there, but I don't mind. The staff is super friendly and don't mind helping you out if you need it. The price is right if you climb in the morning but can't afford the monthly rate, but if you can, do it! I will admit I don't enjoy climbing in the evening. It's way too crowded, and I feel rushed. The morning crowd is great. A group of 50+ year olds climb with gusto and new parents bring their babies in their car seats. Bring your coffee with you and keep it on the bleachers, and don't forget your granola bar (it ok if you do, you can just buy one at the front desk). If your partner bails on you, you can always go up and boulder or if your feeling social, have the staff announce that your looking for a belay partner. As far as classes go... Yoga is great, it's catered to climbers and focuses on really engaging muscles and holding poses (at least the classes I've been to). If you're a bit rusty on the basics be sure to go to the all-level classes and let the instructor know. Warning: these are not your 24hr fitness yoga classes! You will sweat, you will feel stretched, and you will be relaxed when you get finished. As far as the other classes go, Cardio boxing completely kicked my ass but I had so much energy coming out of it I couldn't sleep until 1am.Ok, enough with the rambling... it may not be as shiny and new as planet granite in the presidio, but it has a great feel, great smell, and great people.

Awesome place. It is such a friendly place with no competition of who is doing better than the other. Everyone there is supportive and very happy to help out. The yoga classes are pretty good too. Haven't tried out the equipment yet, maybe today!

Awesome awesome place!  Where else can you get climbing, fitness, yoga and biking in one?  I'm not that great of a climber, but I love how anyone can challenge themselves.  I give props to the ashtanga yoga class on fridays - probably the best yoga class I've found in SF so far (just be prepared to get cozy with your neighbors)

I went to Mission Cliffs last week for the first time. Me and my girlfriend took the 2:30pm intro class for $20 bucks each, included the equipment and an all day pass, and had a very good learning experience and a lot of fun.  It's not hard to learn how to wall climb and the instructor was very very helpful an caring.  There was only 6 of us in the class, which made it easier to learn.  I would recommend everyone to go to this place and take the class and have fun.

this place, along with the other touchstone gyms, is the bomb.consistently good bouldering routes, great top roping with some cool features and corners (yosemite wall!).the only downside is that it does, as noted in many reviews, get crowded, but hey - that's the price of success I guess!
a great alternative to the same ol routine at the gym.  and way more fun.  The have specials on classes, ladies nights etc.

It's so much fun- for what it is! I did the baby climb up in the back, and it was tough, and climbing may not be for me, but I love this gym. It's got the full walls to climb, bouldering, and a nice sauna and locker room (for the ladies- not sure 'bout the gents). I wish there were more fun activity places like this for variou sports, in the city.

How can you beat working out in a gym where everyone is happy to be there?  Some many excellent climbs and the bouldering is epic.  The place has expanded with spin and yoga but nothing tops climbing to the apex of the roof and surveying the collective enjoyment of the place

I'm addicted....so much so that I've become a member and can't wait to climb every week.  A great work out that gives you a sense of accomplishment. only complaint is that some of the folks here are not so friendly (on average I'm treated with respect) but every once and while you get someone with a little attitude... come on- belaying and tying knots are hard..and well yelling at folks doesn't encourage learning...
This place is fun too bad I couldn't go any higher than I wanted to. Good price if you go before a certain time and you can come in and out throughout the whole day.

I come here once a year and my friend takes me to boulder. LOL. It is probably the best workout you can probably get and you don't even know you're working out. It is a lot better than running on the treadmill or your ballys or 24 hour fitness membership! you're bouldering and rock climbing and time goes by quickly! it is so much fun and the people around you help you out too! super friendly. they also have weights and a few treadmills and stuff.

definitely my favorite place to climb.  the people here are a lot friendlier than at ironworks.  lots of v1s and v2s so it's great for beginners.  nights are pretty busy so try to go in the afternoon (it's cheaper too).  first time?  don't worry, you can rent your equipment here and take a beginner's class.  anyone need a bouldering partner?

Great place to climb on weekday nights, rainy afternoons, and other times when there is no way you could be outside. Really cool staff, good walls, and open until 11.oo pm on Tuesdays and Thursdays! Don't recommend going to weekend afternoons, because there are usually lots and lots of people, way too many kids, and you'll probably have to wait to climb.

i thought rock climbing was reserved for buff, brawny mountain men who hunt and eat off the fat of the land, but after corey finally convinced me to go to mission cliffs with him (he went to the sex & the city movie with me so it was the least i could do..) i was surprised to find that the real rock climbing demographic was hugely diverse, consisting of men & women, young & old, toned & not-so-toned. and what ya know, i LOVED it! rock climbing is like the workout equivalent to ebay shopping - but instead of "shop victoriously" we sweat victoriously! granted it took me 30 minutes to leave the ground, but once i made my first ascent i was hooked. its been 3 months and ive visited a few other climbing gyms (i love that our membership grants us access to a handful of gyms in the area), but none so fun as mission cliffs. they change their routes often, the staff is super helpful and knowledgable about climbing, they offer boxing, aerobics, spinning, yoga and pilates classes as well, and they are pet friendly! only hitch: smelly feet.
its a decent gym, slight attitude-ish.

A solid climbing gym. A little old and dingy compared to some of the palaces they are building these days, but the route setting is solid.The place gets damn packed in the evenings, but that is also the only time I am a better climber than half the people there. So it is a love/hate kind of thing for me.

I just got back from hosting a birthday party for my now 12-year old daughter and a bunch of her friends, and Mission Cliffs was a great choice.  The staff were patient and encouraging, helping each kid overcome their respective fears and difficulties to climb higher than I would have expected--several of the girls reached the top of the big wall.  My 7-year old son got all the way up one of the beginner walls.Even though it was getting a bit crowded on a rainy Saturday, no one seemed to mind the kids running around, acting silly, and swinging on a big rope that was there.  (thank you fellow climbers for having remembered that you were once kids as well!!!)  Also there was a fooz ball table that some of the kids used between climbs.They have a small party room that was fine, but nearly maxed out with 15 kids and 10 adults.They charged $20/climber with no hidden costs at all and were super-easy to coordinate with.  I think it is great to give kids the chance to try different sports and challenge themselves in different ways.  It's all part of growing up.  And, this is the kind of experience that first-timers can share with kids who have been several times.

I'm revising my review because they've made a real big effort to clean up, renovate and expand the place.   I would say that they have great routes for top roping but it can get pretty busy especially the bouldering area which is quite small and enclosed.

Woohoo! I love this place. They give you a quick instruction on safety which covers everything you need to know, and then you're off to go a'climbing. They rent you the gear, and the holds are all labeled according to difficulty; the courses are changed every now and again to make things interesting. The bathrooms/lockers are always really clean and well lit. It can get really crowded at times, and at those times I wish it were bigger with more climbing walls - but hey, this is SF, and space is a premium. I like that they have a curved wall with vertical & upside-down holds where you can watch the super-ripped practice their Spiderman routines.

If you're looking to win physical challenges like I am, then this is the place for you!  Not only does it have a full range of standard gym equipment, it also has a good sized bouldering cave and a couple good sized climbing walls.  Climbing is a great way to prepare for that obstacle course, and it will give you that edge you need to conquer the Sundae Slide and get that final flag.  So if you're serious about physical challenges like I am, Mission Cliffs is the place for you.

This gym is pretty small compare to the other gyms I've gone. The're tends to be a lot of people climbing on certain days and can be crowded at times. Depending on what route you want to climb, you have to wait for other people to finish before you start your route. Also, the locker rooms smells really bad and its really small. There aren't that many lockers with that amount of that use the gym.

My experience was a solid four stars while I attended this gym.  Unfortunately things changed for the worst when I canceled my membership.  4 months after canceling my membership, I checked out my credit card statement and noticed a recurring charge from Touchstone.  It took me awhile to realize that Touchstone was actually the Mission Cliffs.I didn't think this would be much of an issue to re-cancel my membership and get a full refund because I hadn't been there in months and their records showed this.  At the very least, I expected them to give me credit towards a membership (of equal length that they had charged me) if I had wanted to go back to the gym.  The short answer, no.  Donna (the MC manager) lacks in her costumer service skills.  Her email responses took more than a week and required me to write reminder emails for her to get back to me.  She never replied back to my last email (written months ago).After losing hundreds of dollars to Mission Cliffs, you can count on me not signing up again.  My suggestion, head to Planet Granite in the Presidio.  They have much more climbing, there is plenty of air to breath and there are more exercise machines.

This gym is technically right on.  I know because I have been rock climbing indoors and outdoors for over ten years.  However, the customer service is demeaning and austere.  Behind the service counter a customer will often find a "hard core" attitude and frowns.  The result is that while this business has everything going for it, the severe staff manages to take the fun out of climbing and makes for an unwelcoming atmosphere.

my boyfriend and i enjoyed an intro climbing class there last weekend. really fun. the instructor (sadly his name escapes me) was really great. funny. personable. thorough.  after seeing their facilities and finding out about their yoga classes etc... im seriously considering a gym membership for the first time in my life.
A fun place to burn some calories and get fit.  Not your super luxury gym, but fun, local, and lots of nice people working & working out here.

me likey. a lot. When I was a kid, my family would hike up Mission Peak in Fremont. I'd jump from rock to rock like a mountain goat. I LOVE to climb stuff.The jungle gym was my thing. I remember when it was okay to hang upside down from a steel structure geodesic dome, 12 feet above the ground with only tambark to break your fall. I remember when there were Robot structures with 20 foot slides at parks. Now they have punk-monkey ones that are four feet off the ground. How's a kid ever wanna climb a wall with out crying in front of it?  It's amazing I haven't broken a major bone yet. You shoulda seen it, it would have made you laugh. Little woman crying like a sad, little monkey in Dark Blue Scrubs one size too huge with a surgical hair net. Now, that's hot. The ER doc put Lidocaine in my finger to numb it so he could take off the pinky nail. I said sobbing, "Now I know why women get epidurals, that hurts!" (ER doc and my friend the ER nurse laugh-all the while the needle is jerking from his laughter). After he was done, I said when can I try to go climbing. Next year. Awesome. I'm absolutely thrilled. Meet Joy and her throbbing, disabled finger. Nice.Anyway, it's one of the reasons I have been a little shy about coming back until last May-I used my shoes for one time and made a new climbing buddy named Tiffany at Mission Cliffs during our Belay class who I could never get there because she had a boyfriend and she had lots of sexy time with. She then moved back to go to Penn State and haven't heard from her since. =(Then, insult to injury- some dumb, ass monkeys stole my rock shoes out of my car last year.Anyway, I finally got my rock shoes! Go to REI people and get hooked up!So yesterday, I was a happy monkey.New rock shoes that didn't kill and a climbing buddy who showed me new stuff. I was told by said climbing buddy that they change the routes almost every sixty days so that no one gets bored. I'll tell you one thing, Mission Cliffs ain't boring and if you say that, we can't hang. If you wanna see Joy as a monkey, come here.Be sure to bring some bananas.I'm hungry after trying 5.5.-5.10 routes.

I agree with the rest of the posts, this place is a damn good place to learn to climb. The only thing that can be improved is if they had more beginner to intermediate level climbs. This place can be easily twice as big and still have a wait for some of the climbs.

Great place to get a good work out and get ready for some summer outdoor climbing.  They have a really good bouldering area and are constantly changing the routes to keep things interesting.  Sometimes seems to be more of a social gathering place than a climbing gym, but if you go at the right hours when the crowds are a bit thinner, its really a great place.  Staff come off a bit arrogant if you don't know you, but after a while most come around.  Sometimes parking can be a pain, but usually not too bad

From the Belay safety class that actually teaches you everything you need to know (ask for Shira, she's the best!) to the rental shoes you don't mind wearing and the fun names for all the routes, it is an amazing way to spend an afternoon.  The evening crowd thins out around 9 and it's a great time for beginners to drag their belay partners out for some fun.

They make you take  a class the first time you come there if you didn't have a prior climbing experience.  The trainer was knowledgeable, very professional and overly concerned about safety as it usually is.  Better safe then sorry I say.  BTW, you have to have a partner to catch you if you fall.  Yes, you will be all tied up from your waist and the crotch area but you still need someone to hold the other end of the rope so you stay in the air in case you fall as opposed to falling on the ground.  Speaking of the ground, it's nicely padded so even if your buddy falls asleep, the chances are you will survive the potential fall.  The cost is $20 and it cover all the equipment rental (shoes, harness etc) and the same day use of the facilities.  Climbing is a great way to exercise and have fun doing it. 4 stars because the rental shoes stank!  I'm bringing my own shoes next time.  Another excuse for shopping.  Good place for dates or families, but not for people who just want to exercise on his/her own as you need a climbing partner.

come during peak hours and it's like a goddamn ninja training camp.i kid you not-- 20 people scaling walls all at once, people descending from the ceiling, and more back muscles than you'll ever find at any meathead gym.love it

i love to be challenged. i love the notion of staring at something and planning out the most logical way to attack it, usually with no assistance from anyone else. that may make me a loner, but it also just might make me a badass.mission cliffs is the san francisco portion in a bay area family of gyms - touchstone. they're not known for their weights, although they have them. or even known for their yoga, spinning, or kickboxing classes, which they also have. but mission cliffs is known for its climbing and, within the entire touchstone family of gyms, it is known for its realistic rating of routes and problems. you see, indoor climbing is not merely a fun way to build strength, endurance, and sex appeal, it also attempts to be the doppleganger of problems you might face outdoors - on real rock. this is one popular misconception - that this place is only for entertainment. mission cliffs is a serious climber's test of their abilities. whoever they have selected to lay the routes at this gym tries their hardest to challenge each level of climber; something i have yet to see copied at any of the other touchstone gyms i have visited.the gym offers classes to better the skills you hone on the walls, equipment to rent if you don't own, information for safe and fun climbs, opportunities to meet like-minded individuals, and almost limitless chances to put your logic and physicality to the test. the best part, though, is that there exists no "shirt required" policy at this gym. i love being able to work out without a shirt. not sure if it's a vanity thing, a heat thing, or just the preference to not wear a shirt, but whatever it is, it's nice.the rates are extremely reasonable considering you get full access to all of the gym's facilities when you join. most gyms do not offer that much freedom. but really, all you'll need is a good pair of climbing shoes, some motivation, some energy, and those well-set routes - you'll be happy for hours.

This place is an indoor climbing heaven. My old climbing gym in Seattle wasn't near as large as this place! They have over 80 climbing rope routes, with a huge indoor bouldering area, and a full weight room. Touchstone is one of those places that has their shit together with a full team of route setters that travels around their gyms to change routes and provide you with an ever-changing apparatus to get your climb on!!! when I first started going there, I saw all of these people with shirts saying "20 Ton Capacity", and I was like WTF.....Well there is a gigantic cranelift that sits near the bouldering wall that has a 20 ton capacity.....har har.....LOVE IT! I do have a couple of complaints as an experienced climber, and that is the climbing etiquette! People! If people are climbing up a route, DO NOT GO UP A ROUTE THAT INTERSECTS THAT ONE! PLEASE! IT IS ANNOYING TO HAVE SOMEONE UP YOUR BUTT WHEN U ARE CLIMBING! Also, some of the top ropes are pretty manky(and kind of scary). Pros: Awesome setting team, great top rope routes, great bouldering, good prices, and sweet lead routesCons: Can be kind of busy(After work), some of the climbers can be rude, and the weight gym is a bit old.

This was my first time climbing so intensely. Previous to this visit I've only gone to City Beach in Fremont, CA was is also fun place to hold group events. I like the venue especially since there seems to be such a close-knit feel amongst the regular climbers here. There are a lot of different climbing routes, workout machines, equipment rentals/sales, yoga classes, and showers here. It was a super fun place climbing with my friends. I managed to pass the test on how to rope up and how to belay. Personally did 4 climbs starting with 5.5 and ending with 5.8. I was hurting at the end of the night but it was a great, healthy workout for all the muscles I don't normally use or have neglected to use in a while. I found in one visit I found it to be a very fitting place and activity for me to do top rope climbing. I am looking forward to doing more of this in the near future. Highly recommend this place. The staff is real nice too!

Every time I go here, I dream of becoming a "real" climber that actually climbs things in the great outdoors but alas, it's urban climbing for me.  This place is awesome and highly recommended as something different to do with a friend besides the usual cocktail (though I'm a big fan of that as well).  The staff is incredibly friendly and helpful.  And once you learn how to belay, etc., you can go off on your own and "climb" to your heart's delight!

ok, maybe it's a bit stinky, but i love this place.  climbing makes me happy!  the tuesday night yoga classes with helen are nice and stretchy--helps to counteract all the soreness.  as an added bonus--i'm actually growing some muscles.
Excellent, large climbing gym with a variety of routes for all skill levels.  Given the height of some of the climbs, they may not be appropriate for people with fear of heights.

are you bored by treadmills and exercise bikes, and by the gym in general?  look no further for excitement, b/c indoor rock climbing is the perfect way to work out while actually having fun.  they provide all the safety training and equipment rentals.  full membership to mission cliffs allows you to visit any of the touchstone climbing gyms (like berkeley ironworks).  they also have workshops and plan trips for real outdoor rock-climbing.  moreover, standard gym equipment is also available, as are various fitness classes, but those are better at the berkeley branch.

rock climbing ..... its so hard but so fun at the same time. this place has so many different levels to choose from it's probably the best indoor rock climbing facility i've been to. pricing is not cheap but its not something you can find anywhere in the city so its very well worth the price. i would love to frequent this place but i dont have the time...

I really like this place.  I prefer the climbing & bouldering routes here to the ones at Planet Granite, because they involve much more thought and technique.  The place is a bit smaller, so routes don't get as long/tall as Planet Granite and if you go often, you'll run out of new routes, but for me, it's great variety since I primarily go to PG.  I really dig the bouldering area, although it doesn't offer as much straight up overhanging stuff as PG, but it's got cool arches and tricky moves.  I also love the corners in the toproping area because you have to get really creative with your moves to figure out the routes.  I'm definitely a fan of this place.  If I move back to SF, I'll definitely get a membership here.  A good thing to note about that is if you want variety, you can cross over to Ironworks in Berkeley.  Sweet deal.  I do have to say I'm annoyed that they won't give me a lead test because I don't have a friend who can take it with me.  I need to make more climbing friends or tell my lame friends to learn how to lead climb.

my regular indoor climbing spot, decent facility with an array of fitness machines, free weights, and treadmills.  i usually go in the morning hours to avoid the crowd of after work climbers, if you bike there they are cool with you locking up you bike inside on the guard rail.  large showers and a sauna! great experience every visit. (if you bring newb friends make sure they're nails arent done, and jeans are ok if you must but make sure they arent low rise cause crack kills)

the staff at mission cliffs is really friendly, especially the guy who helped me get my harness on and helped take care of me with my injury.  the courses are great for beginners and advanced folks.  the lockers are really nice with sleek showers. however, i expected the staff to help out with bouldering...  it'd be five stars if they had boulders.

i love this place.  i used to go to iron works when i was at cal and just signed up (no initiation this month!) here.  great place to work up a sweat and have fun.  my company sponsors a membership to equinox, but that place blows pretty hard and i'd much rather spend my time at mc.
I give 5 stars because I'm afraid the staff will kick my ass if I give any less. LOL! Great place.

I had a great first rock climbing experience here (despite being emasculated by a female climbing partner).  For first timers I would definitely suggest the safety course... it helps with the panic when your forearms go numb and you feel gravity being more and more relevant...
i really love this place, but it should really be open later... like until midnight everyday.
Fantastic climbing gym, just a few blocks away.
I'll keep it simple. This place rocks. No better establishment and community in San Francisco. Simple as that.
great staff, best indoor climbing I've been too, and the other exercise equipment is a big plus.

i purchased the groupon deal for mission cliffs a while back and finally used it last week. while rock climbing isn't something i do frequently, it's always a fun activity to change your daily routine. i've done rock climbing walls in recreation centers and such, but i've never seen a place that's solely dedicated to the sport. this place was like the god father of all rock climbing establishments i've been to. the atmosphere is very laid back and it doesn't have that meat market feel that most gyms have. most people here are on a mission, that is, to get their climb on. the introductory class was very informative and teaches you all you need to know to brave your first wall.  our instructor was thorough and made sure we knew everything before setting us free to climb our hearts out. if you're looking for a place to work out and do weights this isn't it. missions cliffs is striclty for the climbing enthusiast who just wants to climb to the heavens, or at least close to it. they've got a few cardio machines and a weight room, but honestly, save that for 24 hour fitness or crunch.
